CONTENT:
<!-- Page 1 -->



# ARDS- Newer treatments

Dr Ganjam Yasaswini

---

<!-- Page 2 -->



# Dark side of spontaneous breathing?

Watanabe, Rika et al. “Pneumomediastinum as patient self-inflicted lung injury in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome due to COVID-19: a case series.”

Acute medicine & surgery vol. 9,1 e796. 30 Sep. 2022, doi:10.1002/ams2.796

---

<!-- Page 3 -->

(TPP: pressure difference between Airway pressure & Alveolar pressure) & may L/T Either distension/collapse of Alveoli

**Potential decreased cardiac output from:**
*   decreased pre-load
*   increased pulmonary vascular resistance

**Decreased compliance**

**Lung volume loss De-recruitment**
(Baby lung)

---

**High risk of VILI from excessive trans-pulmonary pressure with consequent**
*   tidal overdistension (volutrauma)
*   increased dead space

*Associated with:*
*   Lower pleural pressure (TPP: -ve)
*   Higher V/Q

---

**High risk of VILI from:**
*   tidal recruitment (atelectrauma)
*   local stress raisers resulting in excessive trans-pulmonary pressure

*Associated with:*
*   Lower V/Q
*   Alveolar inhomogeneity

---

**Low risk of VILI due to alveolar collapse/consolidation with no V/A**

*Associated with:*
*   Shunt
*   Higher pleural pressure (TPP: +ve C/H w/g lung)

---

**Lung Diagram Labels:**
*   (a)
*   (b)
*   (c)
*   Sternum (pointing to top of lung)
*   Spine (pointing to bottom of lung)

---

**Interventions:**

**MV with LTV**
*   Reduction of volutrauma ✓
*   Reduction of atelectrauma ✓

**Prone position**
*   Reduction of volutrauma
*   More homogeneous distribution of trans-pulmonary pressure
*   Improvement of V/Q matching
*   Reduction of atelectrauma
*   Increase of alveolar recruitment

**HFOV**
*   Reduction of volutrauma
*   Reduction of atelectrauma
*   Increase of alveolar recruitment

**Higher PEEP**
*   Reduction of atelectrauma
*   Reduction of alveolar inhomogeneity
*   Increase of alveolar recruitment
*   Indirect reduction of volutrauma

**LRM**
*   Reduction of atelectrauma
*   Reduction of alveolar inhomogeneity
*   Increase of alveolar recruitment
*   Indirect reduction of volutrauma

**ECLS**
*   Reduction of volutrauma
*   Reduction of atelectrauma

---

**Handwritten Notes:**
(a) -> Low TV to prevent volutrauma
(b) -> Higher PEEP to prevent Atelectasis-trauma
(c) -> proning to prevent shunting in dependent parts.

---

<!-- Page 4 -->



# Goals of ventilation in ARDS

How to achieve better oxygenation?
*   Prevent over distension of baby lung (functional part of lung (a)) (by low tidal volume)
*   Recruit collapsed alveolar units (by optimal PEEP)
*   Prevent inhomogeneity in ventilation between dependent and non dependent regions. (**Prone positioning**)
*   To prevent VILI (By reducing stress and strain)

---

<!-- Page 5 -->



# Newer treatments in ARDS

*   Prone ventilation
*   EIT → Electrical impedance tomography
*   Inhaled drugs
*   HFOV
*   Inverse ratio ventilation
*   ECCO2R

---

<!-- Page 6 -->



# Prone positioning

*   Trans pulmonary pressure (Ptp) is defined as the difference between the airway pressure (Paw) and pleural pressure (Ppl)
*   $$Ptp = Paw - Ppl$$
*   Ventral transpulmonary pressure exceeds the dorsal transpulmonary pressure and greater expansion of the ventral alveoli than the dorsal alveoli

Eur Respir J. 2008;20(4):1017.Intensive Care Med. 1986;12(3):137

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



## Supine position

*   **Cross-sectional view:**
    *   Ventral lung
    *   Dorsal lung
*   **Sagittal view:**
    *   Ventral alveolus (overdistended)
    *   Dorsal alveolus (collapsed)
*   **Physiological parameters:**

| Region            | PTP/TPP      | Blood flow |
| :---------------- | :----------- | :--------- |
| Ventral alveolus  | +++ (High TPP) | ↓          |
| Dorsal alveolus   | ---          | ↑          |

*   **V/Q Status:** V/Q Mismatch



## Prone position

*   **Cross-sectional view:**
    *   Ventral lung
    *   Dorsal lung
*   **Sagittal view:**
    *   Ventral alveolus (decreased overdistention)
    *   Dorsal alveolus (decreased collapse)
*   **Physiological parameters:**

| Region            | PTP/TPP | Blood flow |
| :---------------- | :------ | :--------- |
| Ventral alveolus  | +       | ↑          |
| Dorsal alveolus   | ---     | ↑          |

*   **V/Q Status:** V/Q Matched (Improved)
*   *(Figure reference: 12.9.2)*

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



# Prone positioning

*   Alters the mechanics and physiology of gas exchange
*   Improves mortality in selected population
*   Refractory hypoxemia that is unresponsive to ventilator optimization

**How does it alter mechanics of gas exchange?**

*   Reduces the difference between the dorsal and ventral pleural pressure
*   ~~Ventilation more homogeneous~~
*   Decreases alveolar overinflation and alveolar collapse.
*   Improves perfusion of previously dependent lung, reduces shunt
*   Minimize stress and strain on alveoli.

---

<!-- Page 9 -->



## Supine position

*   **Cross-sectional view:**
    *   Ventral lung
    *   Dorsal lung
*   **Sagittal view:**
    *   Ventral alveolus (overdistended)
    *   Dorsal alveolus (collapsed)

| PTP | Blood flow |
| :-- | :--------- |
| +++ | (Downward tapering red arrow, wider at top) |
| --- |            |



## Prone position

*   **Cross-sectional view:**
    *   Ventral lung
    *   Dorsal lung
*   **Sagittal view:**
    *   Ventral alveolus (decreased overdistention)
    *   Dorsal alveolus (decreased collapse)

| PTP | Blood flow |
| :-- | :--------- |
| +   | (Upward tapering red arrow, wider at bottom) |
| -   |            |

10.B-21

---

<!-- Page 10 -->



# Proposed mechanisms for prone response

| | Physiologic effect | Clinical result |
|---|---|---|
| **Improved configuration between lung and thorax** | | |
| Heart is dependent | More homogeneous Ppl gradient in ventrodorsal and cephalocaudal planes | Improved ventilation distribution |
| Smaller volume of dependent lung | | Increased FRC (↓ shunt) |
| **Abdomen is unsupported*** | | |
| Secretion mobilization | Improved bronchial drainage | Improved ventilation |
| Improved aerosol delivery | Improved effect of aerosolized meds | Improved ventilation |
| More homogeneous perfusion | Less dependent perfusion | Improved V/Q matching (↓ shunt) |

---

<!-- Page 11 -->

proning
**Contraindications**
*   Acute bleeding (eg, hemorrhagic shock, massive hemoptysis)
*   Multiple fractures or trauma (eg, unstable fractures of femur, pelvis, face)
*   Spinal instability
*   Raised intracranial pressure >30 mmHg or cerebral perfusion pressure <60 mmHg
*   Tracheal surgery or sternotomy within two weeks

**Relative contraindications**
*   Shock (eg, persistent mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg)
*   Anterior chest tube(s) with air leaks\*
*   Major abdominal surgery
*   Recent pacemaker\*
*   Clinical conditions limiting life expectancy\* (eg, oxygen or ventilator-dependent respiratory failure)
*   Severe burns\*
*   Recent lung transplant recipient\*

---

<!-- Page 12 -->



# Complications
*   Nerve compression (eg, brachial plexus injury)
*   Crush injury
*   Venous stasis (eg, facial edema)
*   Dislodging endotracheal tube
*   Diaphragm limitation
*   Pressure sores (eg, facial)
*   Dislodging vascular catheters or drainage tubes
*   Retinal damage
*   Transient reduction in arterial oxygen saturation (differentiating) (dlt derecruitment (temporary) of Alveoli dlt proning (initially))
*   Vomiting
*   Transient arrhythmias

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



# Prone positioning

<mark>PROSEVA</mark>
✓ Does the early application of prone positioning improve mortality in severe ARDS?
*   RCT
*   01.01.2008. – 25.07.2011- France and Spain
*   Adult patients with severe ARDS who were intubated/ventilated for <36 hours at inclusion PaO2:FiO2 <150mmHg (20KPa) with FiO2 ≥0.6, PEEP ≥5, TV~6ml/kg, confirmed after 12-24 hours of ventilation
*   Excluded if contraindication to proning
*   474 patients randomized from 3449 patients with ARDS Intervention-Prone for at least 16 consecutive hours, for 28 days, or until improvement to set standard Control-Supine (semi-recumbent position)
*   Primary outcome: all cause mortality at 28-days 16% in prone vs. 32.8% in supine (P<0.001) adjusted odds ratio 0.42 (0.26-0.66) No increase in adverse events in prone group
*   <mark>Conclusion- Patients with severe ARDS have improved mortality with early and long proning session</mark>

crisp info on ALL
trials done

# EIT

Image of a patient in a hospital bed with medical devices attached to their chest and abdomen.

*   Bedside tool- non radiological imaging of lung based on resistivity properties
*   To assess regional distribution of the ventilation in lungs-facilitates better optimization of PEEP
*   EIT guided peep titration the oxygenation is better, driving pressures are lower however does not have mortality benefit → Plat - Total PEEP
*   Requires increments or decrements to PEEP for optimal oxygenation

Zhao et al. Ann. Intensive Care (2019) 9:7
Somhorst et al. Critical Care (2022) 26:272

<!-- Page 15 -->

*   ✓ Sedated and paralyzed
*   ◎ PEEP titration started from 5-8 cm H2O at steps of 2cm H2O increments for 2 min until plateau pressure <35 cm H2O or unstable blood pressure
*   ✓ Then decreased in decrements of 2 cm H2O
*   ◎ The best point of intercept between collapse and overdistension percentage reflects the optimal PEEP

*Handwritten Notes:*

When you are titrating PEEP, when you are starting at a lower level & going to a higher level, if some amount of lung is recruited automatically Pplat will fall.
↓
This shows that the PEEP titration you are doing is fruitfull & much of lung is recruitable.

→ On the contrary: If you keep on increasing PEEP and your Pplat is also increasing → that means your PEEP is not able to recruit any part of the lung.

HFOV : High frequency oscillatory ventilation

*   **High RR** with very low **Vt(1-3ml/kg)**
    *   *Handwritten note*: 3 breaths/second = RR = 180/min
*   HFOV delivers breaths at **very high frequencies (typically 3-15 Hz)** and **low tidal volumes**, resulting in **minimal airway pressure fluctuations**.
    *   *Handwritten note*: 3 breaths - 15 breaths/sec
*   ✓ **Constant airway pressure promotes alveolar recruitment and improves V-Q matching and prevents atelectrauma**
*   **Decreases both barotrauma and volutrauma**
*   *Handwritten note*: Trials
    *   **OSCILLATE- Patients treated with HFOV had a significantly higher mortality and therefore it should not be used as standard treatment**
    *   **OSCAR- HFOV improved oxygenation but did not improve 30 day mortality**

# APRV: AIRWAY PRESSURE RELEASE VENTILATION

*   CPAP with intermittent pressure release phase.
*   Maintains adequate lung volume and recruitment.
*   Time cycled release phase to a lower set pressure.
*   In APRV, patients are predominantly ventilated at a high continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), referred to as the "**Phigh**," which recruits alveoli and prevents their collapse. This facilitates oxygen diffusion and reduces atelectasis.
*   The "**Plow**" phase, typically brief, allows for passive exhalation and CO2 removal.

**FIGURE 3** | Airway Pressure Release Ventilation (APRV) is a pressure-limited, time-cycled mode. The Time Controlled Adaptive Ventilation (TCAV™) method of setting the APRV mode includes the following settings: 1) upper airway pressure ($P_{High}$); 2) lower airway pressure ($P_{Low}$); 3) time spent at $P_{High}$ ($T_{High}$); and 4) time spent at $P_{Low}$ ($T_{Low}$). Combined, $P_{High}$ and $T_{High}$ form the continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) Phase and impact end-inspiratory lung volume. The CPAP Phase releases to the combined $P_{Low}$ and $T_{Low}$, which form the Release Phase and impact end-expiratory lung volume. During the TCAV™ method of APRV, the ventilator cycles between the CPAP and Release Phases. During the release phase, the $T_{Low}$ set to terminate at 75% of the peak expiratory flow rate halts alveolar instability. Subsequently, the CPAP Phase maintains alveolar stability and recruits lung volume over time (hours to days).

CONTENT:
## IRV :- Inverse Ratio Ventilation

_→ Normally in COPD/Asthma pts, most of times during ventilation alone, we are asked to prolong Expiratory time to prevent AutoPEEP._

*   **Mean airway pressure** is closely related to oxygenation, **a ventilation mode that can raise the mean airway pressure without increasing the Pplat could be a useful means of maintaining oxygenation.**
    _→ less dependent on total Insp. time → More Insp. time → More Mean airway pressure → More oxygenation_
*   The inspiratory time exceeds the expiratory time during IRV (the inspiratory to expiratory [I:E] ratio is inversed), increasing the mean airway pressure and **potentially improving oxygenation.**
    _useful in ARDS, (CO2) is not the main problem, its oxygenation, so Insp. time ↑ helps to improve oxygenation_
*   **The inspiratory time to expiratory time ratio was fixed at 2:1, and the tidal volume was initially set at 4–7 ml/kg predicted body weight.**

**High risk of hemodynamic instability due to auto peep.**
_High PEEP → ↓ Diastolic filling time → ↓ EF → shock_
_(Adding of Each breath) (Breath stacking)_

---

<!-- Page 24 -->



# Pressure controlled inverse ratio ventilation

54:35 (Handwritten note)

**Diagram Annotations:**
*   **Pressure Graph:**
    *   End-expiratory alveolar pressure (is not Zero, on less time given for Expiration)
*   **Flow Graph:**
    *   Inspiration
    *   Expiration
    *   Auto PEEP develops
    *   We can see that Expiration is not completing before starting new Inspiration.

Depiction of flow and airway pressure characteristics during a pressure limited breath provided by pressure-controlled inverse ratio ventilation (PC-IRV). **End-expiratory alveolar pressure is positive** at the end of the shortened expiratory period. **Airflow has not ceased, and auto-PEEP has developed.** A pressure limited breath without inverse ratio ventilation has similar pressure and flow characteristics except that flow has ceased at the end of expiration, and there is no auto-PEEP present.

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# Inhaled vasodilators

*   Important physiologic benefits (eg, improved hypoxemia, lower pulmonary arterial pressure, and improved right-ventricular function and cardiac output) without systemic hemodynamic effects.
*   Inhaled prostacyclins are as effective physiologically as Inhaled NO and cost less.
*   Short term physiological benefits
*   Mortality benefit- yet to be proven, no role for routine use.
*   Rescue therapy for severe refractory hypoxemia in ARDS- Reasonable but controversial.

Respir Care2014;Feb;55(2):144-5

---

<!-- Page 26 -->

Inhaled vasodilators (green circles) preferentially dilate the pulmonary vessels (red lines) that perfuse functioning alveoli (white circles), recruiting blood flow away from poorly ventilated units (black circles). The net effect is improved ventilation/perfusion matching.

<!-- Page 27 -->

*   If patients respond, they do within 24 hours.
*   Increase in PaO2/FiO2 ratio by 10% - significant response.
*   Patients likely to respond- high baseline pulmonary vascular resistance, PEEP responsive. (PEEP reaches the Alveoli, vasodilator dilates that side pulm. capillary)
*   Prostacyclins are low cost and easy to administer- no mortality benefit.
*   Inhaled iloprost improved systemic oxygenation without effect on systemic hemodynamics.

---

<!-- Page 28 -->

ECCO2R
*Extra corporeal CO2 Removal*

*   ARDSNet group demonstrated that the ventilation of ARDS patients with a low tidal volume (VT) of 6 mL/kg (vs. 12 mL/kg) significantly reduced mortality
*   However, recent results have shown that pulmonary hyperinflation still occurs in approximately 30% of ARDS patients despite this so-called “protective” ventilation
*   Studies suggest a beneficial effect of VT reduction, even in patients already at a plateau pressure (Pplat) < 30 cm H2O . The decrease in the VT and Pplat will also decrease the driving pressure, which has recently been identified as a major risk factor for mortality in ARDS patients
    *   {ULTRA LOW LPV}
*   A reduction in VT to less than 6 mL/kg to reach a low Pplat level may induce severe hypercapnia that may increase intracranial pressure, causes pulmonary hypertension, decreases myocardial contractility, reduce renal blood flow, and releases endogenous catecholamines
    *   {low TV ↓ low minute ventilation ↓ ↑ CO2 ↓ PH ↓}

ECCO2R

*   Acute hypercapnia can be a barrier to the use of guideline recommended lung-protective ventilation (LPV) and non-invasive ventilation (NIV) strategies.
*   Extracorporeal carbon dioxide removal (ECCO2R) therapy removes CO2 from a patient's blood with an extracorporeal circuit to effectively manage acute hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis that can result from lung-protective mechanical ventilation strategies.
    *Done when using ULTRA LOW LPV strategy*
*   ECCO2R therapy-enabled LPV and ULPV strategies may provide a cost-effective survival benefit in patients with moderate ARDS.

## Radiological phenotypes- personalized ventilation strategies?

*   **Non-Focal ARDS:** Diffuse alveolar opacities on CT; potentially more recruitable- benefit from higher PEEP
*   **Focal ARDS:** Localized loss of aeration, primarily in lower lobes- need lower PEEP to avoid overdistension



## RALE Score: Radiological Assessment of Lung Edema scores

*   Developed from plain chest radiographs to quantify pulmonary edema extent and density. Higher RALE scores correlate with lower PaO2/FiO2 ratios and worse survival outcomes.
*   Useful for prognostic enrichment in clinical trials targeting pulmonary edema resolution.

---

<!-- Page 36 -->

**<u>Physiological phenotypes</u> and personalized treatment?**
*   PaO2/FiO2 ratio
*   Ventilatory ratio (VR)
*   Driving pressure
*   Transpulmonary pressure.

These variables help assess oxygenation, ventilation, and lung mechanics to guide treatment strategies.
*   In pediatric ARDS, oxygenation is assessed using the <mark>oxygenation index (OI)</mark> or <mark>oxygen saturation index (OSI)</mark>.

---

<!-- Page 37 -->



# Protein Biomarkers in ARDS: Key Takeaways
Advances in protein biomarkers enhance understanding of ARDS pathophysiology, prognosis, and phenotype assignment, primarily studied in blood and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF).



## Biomarkers:
*   Alveolar Type III Procollagen Peptide (PCP-III): Associated with fibroproliferation in ARDS, showing high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis. *[handwritten: when found in BAL fluid]*
*   Routine Serum Biomarkers: In COVID-19, biomarkers such as ferritin, CRP, and d-dimer correlate with prognosis, but their role as actionable interventions remains unclear.



## Phenotyping Approaches:
Machine learning identify distinct ARDS phenotypes (hypo- and hyper-inflammatory) based on multiple biomarkers.
The hyper-inflammatory phenotype is linked to worse outcomes and has shown differential treatment responses in clinical trials.
The integration of protein biomarkers into clinical practice could enhance decision-making and improve patient outcomes in ARDS.

# Salbutamol vs Formoterol vs Salmeterol

*   Formoterol moderately lipophilic can stimulate the receptor directly, also a significant fraction enters the cell membrane in the form of a **depot**, from where it leaches out gradually to interact with the receptor $\rightarrow$ longer duration
*   Salmeterol highly lipophilic is taken up into the cell membrane & approaches the receptor by slow lateral diffusion through the membrane $\rightarrow$ slower action
*   Once at the receptor, the long side-chain of salmeterol also binds to an **secondary binding site (exosite)** $\rightarrow$ allows salmeterol to contact the $\beta$2 receptor repeatedly while the drug remains anchored allowing for an **extended duration of action**.

| | Salbutamol | Formoterol | Salmeterol |
|---|---|---|---|
| Potency | moderately potent | very potent | potent |
| Onset of action | rapid | rapid | delayed > 10 min |
| Duration of action | 4-6 h | > 12 h | > 12 h |
| Mechanism of action | direct | membrane depot | exosite |
| Clinical role | rescue/acute use | rescue and maintenance | maintenance |

*   Most preferred : Formoterol It is a selective long-acting $\beta$2-agonist
*   200-fold greater activity at $\beta$2-receptors compared to $\beta$1-receptors
*   It has a quick onset and long duration of action

# Difficult-to-treat asthma
\* HDICS - LABA
+ OCS

*   Difficult-to-treat asthma that is uncontrolled despite prescribing of medium or high dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) with a second controller (usually LABA) or with maintenance OCS.
*   It does not mean a (difficult patient).
*   In many cases, asthma may appear to be difficult-to-treat because of modifiable factors such as incorrect inhaler technique, poor adherence, smoking or comorbidities, or because the diagnosis is incorrect.

    *   Mild

    *   Moderate

    *   Severe

*   It is a subset of difficult-to-treat asthma.
    *   asthma that is uncontrolled despite adherence with maximal optimized high dose ICS- LABA (OR)
    *   Treatment with systemic steroids for 50% of previous year to prevent it from becoming uncontrolled.
    *   and treatment of contributory factors, or that worsens when high dose treatment is decreased.
*   Also sometimes called 'severe refractory asthma'. However, with the advent of biologic therapies, the word 'refractory' is no longer appropriate.
*   Asthma is not classified as severe if it markedly improves when contributory factors such as inhaler technique and adherence are addressed.

<!-- Page 1 -->

## MECHANISMS OF TRANSUDATIVE EFFUSIONS

*   Cardiac failure
    *   mcc plef world wide
    *   Transudative
    *   ↑ Hydrostatic pressure
*   BIL => 60-85%
*   (R) > L

Pleural effusions related to CHF are classically bilateral (60%-85%) and larger on the right side. When unilateral, they occur more commonly on the right, with a ratio of 2:1 right-sided to left-sided.

Dr Bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 2 -->

HEPATIC HYDROTHORAX [short notes]
Transudative plef associated with Liver disease

*   Mechanism:
    1.  Transfer of fluid via diaphragmatic pores into pleura
    2.  ↓ Oncotic pressure [Hypoalbuminemia]

Common C.F.

Rx: dietary sodium restriction, diuretic therapy, and symptom management with thoracentesis.
Other options
*   transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) \*
*   liver transplantation

Chest tube placement, with or without pleurodesis is often ineffective
IPCs have been used in refractory cases of hepatic hydrothorax, sometimes as a bridge to transplantation.
Indwelling Pleural Catheter

Dr Bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 3 -->

# Exudative effusions

*   **APPEARANCE OF FLUID:**
    1.  Commonly straw color, non viscid, odourless
    2.  Reddish - blood tinged (RBC: 5000-10,000)
        *   Plef hematocrit / Serum hematocrit > 0.5
    3.  grossly blood - hematocrit (hemothorax)
    4.  Black - aspergillus, rhizopus oryzae, metastasis, (melanoma)
    5.  Anchovy sauce ≈ Liver abscess related
    6.  HIGHLY VISCOUS: malignant mesothelioma - (due to hyaluronic acid)
        *   pyothorax - due to cells and debris

*   **ODOUR:** feculent - anaerobic bacterial infection

Pus => Empyema

Dr Bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# ADA

**ADA:**
ADA is _higher in TB_ than in other exudative effusion

(ADA) Adenosine → inosine

Cutoff: 40-45 U/L
**Sensitivity 92%, specificity 90%**

**TWO OTHER MAIN DISEASES THAT CAUSE ELEVATED ADA**
_RHEUMATOIDPLEURITIS_
_EMPYEMA_

*   Other causes: _neoplasm_, _Q fever_, _brucellosis_, legionnaires disease.
*   ISOENZYMES: ADA1 & ADA2
*   ADA2 more specific the origin of ADA is **pleural tissues rather than cells in pleural fluid**

# Essay


## Malignant effusion
*   (mc): metastasis \*
*   1° tumors pleura



### Metastasis
=> Lung [Adeno ca], Breast, Lymphoma / GI malignancy



## Mechanism



### ↑ Entry
1.  ↑ Vascular permeability [↑ VEGF] \*
2.  ↑ Vascular hydrostatic gradient
    *   [↓ pleural pressure: Atelectasis] ✓
    *   [↑ venous pressure: SVC obst] ✓
    *   [↓ oncotic pressure: hypoproteinemia] → Lung Malig → unknown Mechanism
        *   Nephrotic Syndrome
3.  Non vascular entry: Chylothorax

# Diagnostic Approach

**I. CXR:**
*   **MC Unilateral BIL in 10-15%**

    *   ③ **Mesothelioma**

**II. USG chest:**
*   **Parietal pleural thickening > 10mm**
    *   (Associated with >1cm s/o malignancy)
    *   Pleural nodularity ✓

**III. CT chest:**
*   pleural thickening > 10mm (Further evaluation includes):

# Parapneumonic Effusion

Effusion related to Pneumonia | Bronchiectasis (lung Abscess)

Empyema: Frank pus in pleural space



## Risk factors:
1.  Dm
2.  Alcoholism
3.  Immunosuppression
4.  Cancer
5.  Poor dental hygiene
6.  Severe pneumonia



## Pathological stages:



### Synpneumonic / Exudative
*   Influx of Inflammatory cells from adjacent lung infection
    *   Cytokines
*   Permeability to influx of Protein rich fluid [sterile]
*   N Glucose vs pH
*   Antibiotics sufficient ✔



### Fibrinopurulent
(Pus + bacteria + loculations)
*   Bacterial invasion +
*   Fluid accumulation
*   ↑ WBC, ↑ LDH, ↓ pH
*   ↓ Glucose
*   ↑ Procoagulant activity => fibrin deposition + loculation
*   - ABs + Drainage



### Organising
(Pleural Peel)
*   Proliferation of fibroblasts => fibrous pleural peel
*   Rx: Decortication

CONTENT:
Here's why:

*   **Parapneumonic effusion:** This is a collection of fluid in the pleural space (the space between the lungs and the chest wall) that occurs in the setting of pneumonia.
*   **Uncomplicated:** This means the effusion is sterile and resolves with appropriate antibiotic treatment for the pneumonia. The fluid is typically an exudate, but it hasn't progressed to a complicated effusion or empyema.
*   **Complicated parapneumonic effusion:** In contrast, a complicated effusion involves bacterial invasion of the pleural space, leading to inflammation, fibrin deposition, and sometimes loculations. This process consumes glucose and produces acid, causing the pH to drop.
*   **Empyema:** This is frank pus in the pleural space, representing a severe form of complicated effusion. The pH is typically very low.

**Key biochemical markers for differentiating parapneumonic effusions:**

| Characteristic                                  | Uncomplicated parapneumonic effusion | Complicated parapneumonic effusion | Empyema |
| :---------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------- | :--------------------------------- | :------ |
| **Appearance**                                  | Slightly turbid                      | Cloudy                             | Pus     |
| **pH**                                          | **>7.30**                            | <7.20                              | NA      |
| **Glucose level, mg/dL**                        | >60                                  | <40                                | NA      |

### Empyema (Handwritten: Outside = 0 bhue angb)
*   Lenticular shape & Compression of surrounding lung
*   Margins of collection create obtuse angles with chest wall.
*   Thick smooth wall.
*   No vessels close by.
*   Split pleura sign $\oplus$

### Lung abscess (Handwritten: bhue angb)
*   Often rounded with similar dimensions in different views with in lung
*   Contact with chest wall made at acute angle.
*   Thick irregular wall!
*   Vessels seen passing through or near collection
*   Split pleura sign $\ominus$

An empyema grows in the pleural space: the pleura acts like an envelope, resulting in obtuse angles ($\uparrow$) where the empyema contacts the chest wall.

An abscess is like a ball in the lung, growing circumferentially: it'll be round & form acute angles ($\uparrow$) where it contacts the inner chest wall.

# Unexpandable Lung Continuum



## Early Stage: Lung Entrapment

*   Active inflammatory process
*   Partial lung re-expansion
*   Active infective / malignant process impacts pleural surface & avoid lung expansion
*   Exudative plef
*   Initial slow pressure change f/b rapid drop on pleural manometry

**Rx:** Treat-underlying disease



## Late Stage: Trapped Lung

*   Remote pleural inflammation
    *   => fibrous peel over pleura
*   Very low re-expansion
*   Poorly treated entrapped lung may be responsible
*   Transudative plef
*   Rapid drop in pressure on pleural manometry

**Rx:** Decortication

*   **Normal lung re-expansion:** steady slow decrease in IP

*   **Trapped lung:** rapid drop in IP

# Chylothorax



## Def:
Accumulation of Chyle in pleural space due to thorack duct rupture



## Causes



### Trauma
* Surgical
* Cardiothoracics (usually during)
* Road accident



### Tumor
* Lymphoma
* Bronchogenic Ca



### Others
* LAM (Lymphangioleiomyomatosis)
* SVC OBSTRUCTION
* Filariasis, paragonimiasis (Lymphatic #)
* **Yellow nail syndrome**



## CF

* Dyspnea (space occupying fluid)
* Pleuritic chest pain and fever – rare
* **Malnutrition** – loss of protein, fat, **electrolytes** and impaired immunologic status – **lymphopenia**

Dr Bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 30 -->

[C Milky white effusion]



## Diagnosis

*   Pleural fluid triglycerides > 110 mg/dL.
*   If the pleural fluid triglyceride level is between **50 and 110 mg/dL**, **chylomicron analysis** is done.

*   Distinguish between **chylothorax**, **empyema** and **pseudochylothorax**
    *   ✓ On centrifugation: **supernatant clear** (**empyema**);
    *   Remains opaque – **chylous** and **chyliform pleural fluid**
    *   ✓ On adding ethyl ether – **high levels of cholesterol** – **turbidity clears**
    *   *(Note: -> white colored Plef)*
*   To identify the site of **thoracic duct disruption magnetic resonance lymphangiography** done.



## Rx

*   Dietary management: **fasting ± TPN**, **low-fat or fat-free diet** with **MCT supplementation** *(Note: medium chain fats)*
*   To administer **somatostatin** or its analogue **octreotide**,
*   Pleuroperitoneal shunt,
*   to percutaneously **embolize the thoracic duct** using a **transabdominal approach**,
*   ICD + Pleurodesis, IPCs ???
*   Thoracoscopy with **pleural abrasion** to create a **pleurodesis**,
*   Thoracoscopy with attempted **ligation of the thoracic duct**, or
*   Thoracotomy with **ligation of the thoracic duct**. (y CT surgery)

<!-- Page 21 -->



# Which mode ?

*   ✓ Sedation and paralysis needs to be continued after intubation to allow controlled ventilation.
*   ⭐ (VCV) > PCV
    Volume Control Ventilation > Pressure Control in many intensive care units because a pre-determined tidal volume is assured.⭐
*   In Pressure Controlled mode, one should watch exhaled tidal volume as it keeps changing with respiratory mechanics.
*   Worsening bronchospasm might significantly limit the tidal volume leading to severe hypoventilation which might go un-noticed

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# GENERAL STRATEGY

*   Relatively low tidal volume (5-8 ml/kg) // low minute ventilation with a high inspiratory flow (80-100 l/min) → short inspiratory time and therefore a low I:E ratio. Air trapping [if] Expiration compromised => ↑ Expiratory time
*   Compromising the Minute Ventilation of the patient → hypercarbia. Mild hypercarbia is not detrimental and well tolerated in most cases, an approach called 'permissive hypercapnia' ≈ Permitting mild hypercapnia to exist in IMV (> 7.2)\*
*   Ventilation should be sufficient to maintain pH > 7.15 - 7.2, with a low tidal volume in order to avoid plateau pressures > 30 mmHg. ✓
*   Adjustment of the trigger is essential for both diseases, usually adjusting by -
    1 to -2 cmH2O for pressure (Pressure trigger) and 2 l/min for flow (Flow trigger).
*   Too sensitive a trigger → respiratory alkalosis,

# DURING INSPIRA



## Scenario 1: No Extrinsic PEEP (Left Side)

*   **External Pressure (PEEPo):** 0 cm H2O (labeled "outside")
*   **Internal Pressure (PEEPi):** 15 cm H2O (labeled "intrinsic")

*   **To Generate Inspiration:**
    *   A pressure drop of **-15 CM H2O** is required.
    *   This implies overcoming a **15 cm H2O** pressure difference.

*   **Summary of Effort:**
    *   **Int PEEP:** 15 cm H2O
    *   **Ext PEEP:** 0 cm H2O
    *   Condition: [Less than external environment]
    *   **Total Effort:** 15 cm H2O effort



## General Note (Top Right)

*   Extrinsic PEEP is 80% of intrinsic
*   (Example value): 20 PEEP



## Scenario 2: With Extrinsic PEEP (Right Side)

*   **External Pressure (PEEPo):** 10 cm H2O
*   **Internal Pressure (PEEPi):** 15 cm H2O
    *   (Additional pressure point/label near PEEPi): 9 cm H2O
    *   (Pressure difference indicated above lung): -5

*   **To Generate Inspiration:**
    *   A pressure drop of **-5 CM H2O** is required.
    *   This results in **↓WoB** (Decreased Work of Breathing).

*   **Summary of Effort:**
    *   **Int PEEP:** 15 cm H2O
    *   **Ext PEEP:** 10 cm H2O
    *   **Total Effort:** 5 cm H2O effort

<!-- Page 27 -->



# External PEEP
✓ Reduces work of breathing ✓
✓ Improves patient ventilator synchrony ✓
* Use 5cms of PEEP
* Slowly increase to 80% of Auto PEEP

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# EXTERNAL PEEP IN COPD VS ASTHMA



## COPD (smiley face)
*   more than 40% of inspiratory muscle effort can be expended to overcome auto-PEEP and that adding extrinsic PEEP can reduce WOB and improve patient-ventilator interaction.
*   Extrinsic PEEP has also been shown to be effective at preventing ventilator-induced lung injury in other forms of lung injury and hence may be of added benefit in this situation.



## ASTHMA (sad face)
*   Adding extrinsic PEEP in some patients with severe asthma has been shown to worsen auto-PEEP -> ? occasionally difficult to measure auto-PEEP reliably, and if the extrinsic PEEP > auto-PEEP then gas trapping will likely worsen.
*   This has led some to recommend minimizing the use of extrinsic PEEP or not using it at all in the ventilation of patients with severe asthma (with a low PEEP).
*   If extrinsic PEEP is used then careful monitoring is required (Low PEEP +).

CONTENT:
# Immunology of TB in a Nutshell

Inhalation of M. tuberculosis-infected aerosol
↓
Uptake by **macrophage** and **inhibition of phagolysosome formation**
↓
Presented to **CD4 T cells** → Secretion of **IFN gamma**
Macrophage activation → Epitheloid cell formation → TNF Alpha
↓
More **macrophage chemotaxis** → more Epitheloid cell formation
↓
Fusion of epitheloid cells → (Langhan cell) Giant cell formation
↓
**SOLID GRANULOMA FORMATION & CONTAINMENT**

---

**IFN-γ → maturation of the phagolysosome in infected macrophages, expression of inducible nitric oxide (NO) → killing of mycobacteria.**

---

Delayed Type Hypersensitivity
If macrophage-activating response is weak → DTH reactions & lung tissue destruction.
↓
At the center of the lesion, the **caseous material** (**lipid of cell membrane**) liquefies.
Invasion & Destruction of Bronchial walls & vessels → cavities are formed

---

<!-- Page 127 -->



# IMMUNE CELLS INVOLVED IN TB
A combination of both Innate and Acquired immunity acting in an orchestrated manner.

| INNATE IMMUNITY         | ACQUIRED IMMUNITY |
| :---------------------- | :---------------- |
| * Epithelial barriers   | * Th1 response    |
| * Phagocytic cells (Macrophages and Neutrophils). |                   |
| * Dendritic cells.      |                   |
| * Natural killer cells. |                   |

---

<!-- Page 128 -->



# INNATE IMMUNITY


## Functions in 3 stages
*   Recognition by Toll like Receptors [TLR] (checked)
*   Phagocytosis or engulfment of bacilli by mononuclear cells (checked)
*   Phagolysosome Fusion (crossed out)

---

<!-- Page 129 -->



# Entry mechanism of M.tb – THE BEGINNING



## Uptake of M. tuberculosis

1.  **Complement receptors**
2.  **Mannose receptor**
3.  **Scavenger receptors**

Phagosome
TLRs



## Phagocytosis –

*   Phagocytosis of M.Tb by alveolar **macrophages** and dendritic cells.
*   Engulfment of **opsonized bacilli** (which has preformed humoral elements like antibodies and complement split products) by **Complement receptors (CR 1,2,3,4)**
*   Engulfment of **non opsonized bacilli** (has terminal mannose moieties) through **mannose receptors**
*   Other receptors which play an important role in bacterial binding are **CD14 receptor and scavenger receptor type A.**

---

<!-- Page 130 -->



# Entry mechanism of M.tb – THE BEGINNING



## Uptake of M. tuberculosis

1.  Complement receptors
2.  Mannose receptor
3.  Scavenger receptors

Phagosome
TLRs



## Phagocytosis –

*   Phagocytosis of M.Tb by alveolar **macrophages** and dendritic cells.
*   Engulfment of **opsonized bacilli** (which has preformed humoral elements like antibodies and complement split products) by **Complement receptors (CR 1,2,3,4)**
*   Engulfment of **non opsonized bacilli** ( has terminal mannose moieties) through **mannose receptors**
*   Other receptors which play an important role in bacterial binding are **CD14 receptor** and **scavenger receptor type A.**

---

<!-- Page 131 -->



# PHAGOLYSOSOME FUSION INHIBITION: THE GREAT ESCAPE

*   If this phagolysosome fusion is prevented, Mtb survives inside the macrophages.
*   Mechanisms
    *   ① Inhibiting the maturation of Phagosome.
    *   ② Inhibiting the calcium signals leading to ineffective Phagosome-lysosome fusion.

---

**Diagrams:**

**Nonpathogenic bacterium**
*   **A**
    *   Early endosome
    *   Sphingosine kinase
    *   Phospholipase C
    *   EARLY PHAGOSOME
    *   Ca$^{2+}$ (+)
    *   Late endosome/lysosome
    *   Destruction (handwritten)
    *   PHAGOLYSOSOME

**Pathogenic mycobacterium**
*   **B**
    *   TB (handwritten)
    *   X (no fusion)
*   **C**
    *   Coronin 1
    *   Ca$^{2+}$
    *   Calcineurin (-)
    *   X (no fusion)

---

<!-- Page 132 -->



# ACQUIRED IMMUNITY:
? THE RESCUER

*   Macrophages express MHC II and display the bacterial antigen → Th1 response activated
*   IL-12 produced by APC's leads to differentiation of T - lymphocytes.
*   Th1 produces IFN-γ - THE CRITICAL MEDIATOR.
*   These response happens 2-8 weeks after infection

---

**Diagram Notes:**

*   **Top Diagram:**
    *   (Macrophage-like cell) --MHC II--> (T cell)
    *   IL12 (from Macrophage-like cell)
    *   (T cell) ↓ TH2 response
    *   ↓ IFNγ
*   **Bottom Diagram:**
    *   PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor (blocking interaction)
    *   (T cell) -- PD-1 -- PD-L1 -- (TB-infected Macrophage)
    *   (T cell) -- TCR MHC complex -- (TB-infected Macrophage)
    *   Inside TB-infected Macrophage: (bacteria)

---

<!-- Page 133 -->



# IFN - γ : THE TERMINATOR

- IFN-G
  - Stimulates **maturation** of **phagolysosome**
- IFN-G
  - Stimulates expression of **iNOS** leads to production of NO.
  - NO combines with other oxidants to form **RNI** (**Reactive nitrogen Intermediates**)
- IFN-G
  - Mobilises antimicrobial peptides.
  - Stimulates autophagy.

---

<!-- Page 134 -->

TNFα = ~~~~~~ 8888



# GRANULOMATOUS INFLAMMATION


## : DAMAGE CONTROL

*   Th1 response also leads to formation of granuloma and caseous necrosis.
*   Activated macrophages – differentiate into "Epitheloid Histiocytes".
*   Activated macrophages – secrete TNF α and other chemokines → Recruitment of monocytes and lymphocytes.
*   These Epitheloid cells fuse to form giant cells & granulomas.

---

<!-- Page 135 -->



# PROGRESSION OF DISEASE

*   In individuals with immune deficits, → the infection progresses and the ongoing immune response results in caseation necrosis.
*   Defects in any of the steps of a TH1 T cell response (including IL-12, IFN-γ, TNF, or nitric oxide production) result in poorly formed granulomas, absence of resistance, and disease progression.
*   Reactivation of the infection or reexposure to the bacilli in a previously sensitized host results in rapid mobilization of a defensive reaction but also increased tissue necrosis.

---

<!-- Page 136 -->



# GRANULOMA

*   Necrotic granulomas are structured around a central core of necrotic cell debris in which much of the bacteria are concentrated.
*   Fully formed tuberculous granuloma consists of a central zone of caseating necrosis, surrounded by cellular infiltrate comprising activated macrophages (epithelioid cells), DCs, T-lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and fibroblasts.
*   Macrophages are centrally located and have the ability to differentiate into multinucleated giant cells.

A mature, caseating tuberculous granuloma with an area of central necrosis surrounded by a typical cellular infiltrate.

*   Mycobacteria Tuberculosis
*   non-tuberculous mycobacteria
*   Fungal : Cryptococcus neoformans, Coccidioides immitis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis (cc HB)

*   Sarcoidosis (*)
*   Bronchocentric granulomatosis (✓)
*   Inflammatory bowel disease (*)

**Exposure/Toxins**

**Aspiration pneumonia**
*   Vasculitis (→ Wegner's granulomatosis (handwritten))
*   Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA)

**Autoimmune diseases**

**Malignancy**
*   malignancy (handwritten)

---

<!-- Page 139 -->



# Specific roles of immune cells in tb immunity

1.  CD4+ T cells : (IFNγ)
    *   Carry out **Apoptosis** of infected macrophages through Fas/Fas ligand interaction, production of cytokines like **IL-12** (✓), **TNF-α** (✓).
    *   Critical for the cytotoxic function of **CD8+ T cells** (✓), mediated by **IL-15** (✓).
    *   Control the **intracellular** (✓) growth of M.Tb via production of **RNI** (✓)\*.

2.  CD8+ T cells :
    *   Can directly (kill M.Tb) (✓) via **granulysin*** - controls both acute as well as chronic infection.
    *   Have role in *control of latent infection*, supported by reactivation of latent infection following *depletion of CD8+ T cells* (✓).

---

<!-- Page 140 -->



# REGULATORY T-CELLS [new]

Treg cells : prevent autoimmunity reduce excess tissue destruction but may also permit persistence of chronic infections
Regulatory T cells are mainly involved in suppression of host immunity.
? Mtb may induce expansion of Treg cells → delay onset of immunity and may permit replication

---

<!-- Page 141 -->



# CYTOKINES

*Handwritten notes (top left):*
- L

*Main content:*
- Protective cytokines are **TNF alpha, IFN gamma, IL - 12,**
- Negative influence on immune response - **IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, TGF-B.** (TH2 influence)
- IL 12 : Under influence of **IL12, CD4 cells produce : TNF alpha, IFN gamma,**
- INTERLEUKIN - **4** responsible for suppression of Th 1 type of response (suppress the production of **IFN gamma**) and **thus host fails to contain the disease, leading to development of severe and disseminated forms of TB.**
- TGF β produced by monocytes & dendritic cells can suppress **CMI**, **INVOLVED IN TISSUE DAMAGE AND FIBROSIS**

- (Asterisk) IL4 TGFβ ↓ CMI

# Evasion of host immune response by m.tb

1.  ✓ Modulation of antigen presentation to avoid elimination by T cells: The **ManLAM, trehalose 6,6'.** dimycolate (TDM, also known as _cord factor_), regulate IFN-✓γ inducible genes including those involved in antigen presentation by _MHC class II machinery_.

# HOST BIOMARKERS FOR TUBERCULOSIS

Identification of clinically relevant biomarkers is required for better diagnosis, treatment and prevention of TB.

Hence biomarkers indicating disease status would boost development of better drugs, vaccines and diagnostics.

IL-6, IL-10, TNF alpha are most promising markers for active TB, while FOX P3, IL-4, IL-12 are most promising biomarkers for immunological correlates of protection.

FOX P3 T regulatory cells are an important predictive biomarker for MDR TB and chemotherapy.

PD-1 T cells is an useful biomarker to monitor treatment outcomes.

# RASMUSSEN ANEURYSM

*   It is a Rare phenomenon caused by weakening of Pulmonary artery\* wall from adjacent cavitary tuberculosis. (low pressure vessel)
*   Progressive weakening of arterial wall occurs as granulation tissue replaces both adventitia and the media.
*   The granulation tissue in the vessel is replaced by fibrin → in thinning of arterial wall, pseudoaneurysm formation and subsequent rupture → Massive hemoptysis
*   Rx : Embolisation (Blocking localised branch of PA)

Due to movement of fungus in cavity & damage to capillaries

(LN)

# COPD In pulmonary tuberculosis



## Mechanism:
*   *Pulmonary* cavities may obliterate or distort *airway* leads to obstruction
*   Lung parenchymal *inflammation* in tuberculosis may lead to *destruction* of the pulmonary *extra-cellular matrix (ECM)*, a feature similar to that of *COPD*.
*   *Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs)* are involved in the *pathogenesis* of both *TB* and *COPD* by *degrading components of ECM*
*   Prognosis is bad if *obstructive air way disease is severe*

COPD I: Infection related [Post TB]



## Flowchart: Mechanisms of airflow obstruction due to tuberculosis
1.  TUBERCULOSIS
2.  Leads to increased MMPs (Matrix metalloproteinases) secretion
3.  Leads to Destruction of extracellular matrix
4.  Leads to Chronic airflow obstruction

# WHY MULTI DRUG THERAPY ????

The letters in the quadrants represent the first-line drugs used in Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for Tuberculosis:

*   **H**: Isoniazid

<!-- Page 243 -->



# THE BASIS



## Initial Intensive phase (IP) 2 months :

In an untreated TB patient, there are naturally occurring drug resistant mutants.
For example occurrence of drug resistant mutants would be roughly ~1 in 10⁶ to isoniazid (H) that are capable of multiplying and will not be affected by a single isoniazid → frequent failures observed with monotherapy of patients.
If two or more drugs are given concurrently, in the initial Intensive Phase when the bacterial load is high, the chances of survival and selection of drug resistant organism will be low as mutants resistant to one drug may be susceptible to other



## Role of continuation phase (CP) 4 months :

fewer drugs for a comparatively longer time will ensure elimination of persisters which are responsible for relapses.

# Pyrazinamide

*Bactericidal*



## Mechanism of Action
*   pyrazinamide to pyrazinoic acid (pncA gene)
*   mycolic acid, disrupt mycobacterial cell membrane and its transport function



## Activity
*   More active in acidic medium.
*   It is more lethal to intracellularly located bacilli and to those at sites showing an inflammatory response, probably because pH is acidic at both these locations.



## Metabolism
*   METABOLISM (Liver > Kidney)
*   No drug interaction (with the liver)



## Adverse Effects
*   Hepatotoxicity
*   Hyperuricemia
    *   arthralgias, anorexia, nausea and vomiting, dysuria, malaise, and fever



## Special Considerations
*   Hemodialysis removes pyrazinamide; therefore, the drug needs to be redosed after each session of hemodialysis.
*   Require dosage adjustment in pts with renal disease.

## TB - HIV: THE RELATIONSHIP

*(Handwritten notes near title: CD4 -> TB, HIV <- CD4, HIV <- MΦ -> TB)*

### Vicious Cycle Flowchart Elements:

*   Worsening immuno-suppression in PLHIV
*   Decreased IFN-γ T_H1 lymphocytes *(Handwritten: 2)*
*   Mycobacterium tuberculosis clinical disease
*   AIDS *(Handwritten: 1)*
*   Increased viral replication
*   Macrophage cytokine production (IL-1, 6 & TNF)
    *   *(Handwritten notes below: TB -> macrophage activation, cytokine coil, increase of HIV replication)*

### EFFECT OF HIV ON TB

*   HIV induces TB through killing of CD4 T cells within granulomas
*   HIV manipulation of macrophage function prevents M.TB killing
*   Functional disruption of local immune response in granuloma

### EFFECT OF TB on HIV

*   ? Immune activation due to TB may increase proportion of CD4 cells that are targets of HIV
*   Greater HIV replication in stimulated macrophage infected with M.TB observed
    *   *(Handwritten notes below: TB MΦ infection, HIV replication inside)*

DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACR

---

<!-- Page 330 -->

# TB HIV

*   In early stages pulmonary TB presents in a typical manner [Like in UB]
*   In late stages : a primary TB-like pattern with interstitial infiltrates, little or no cavitation, pleural effusion, and intrathoracic lymphadenopathy, LN TB, CNS TB etc $\rightarrow$ Disseminated Everywhere

All asymptomatic HIV patients and those, in whom active TB is ruled out, should be offered Isoniazid Preventive Therapy (IPT) for six months.

In TB HIV Co infection :
*   If ART Started first there is risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS)
*   Start ATT first and merge ART with 2 weeks to 2 months

CONTENT:
# ART Regimen in PLHIV Receiving First-line (Rifampicin-containing) anti TB treatment
*Most common* [DSTB]

TB + HIV



## Scenario 1: (HIV Pts in general)

Tenofovir, lamivudine and Dolutegravir (TLD) is the preferred regimen for all PLHIV

* The first line (Rifampicin-containing) ATT can be used with Double-dosing DTG
  * 2HRZG + 4HRG
  * *Because Rifampicin is given?*

* TDF 300 mg (*Tenoform*) + 3TC 300 mg (*Lami*) + DTG 50 mg at bedtime +(DTG 50 mg) in the morning to be given for the entire duration of ATT

✓ DTG 50mg to be continued till 2 weeks after completion of Rifampicin-containing anti-TB treatment

DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 336 -->



# ART Regimen in PLHIV Receiving First-line (Rifampicin-containing) anti TB treatment



## Scenario 2
Women of childbearing potential who do not wish to take DTG-based ART
*   Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Efavirenz (600mg)
*   ATT: 2HRZE + 4HRE



## Scenario 3
If Efavirenz is contraindicated (HIV-2/HIV-1&2/prior NNRTI exposure)
*   Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + [Lopinavir (200 mg) + ritonavir (50 mg) twice daily]
*   Rifampicin must be replaced with Rifabutin 150 mg in anti-TB treatment regimen

---

<!-- Page 337 -->

(HIV ART → OPD)


# Management recommendations for TB diagnosed in patients already receiving ART

1.  On **TLD Regimen**
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen
    Double dosing of **Dolutegravir** \*

2.  On **TLE regimen**
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen

On **TL + PI regimen** (Tenofovir, Lamivudine + PI)
*   (a) (If possible, give TLD) Consider changing to DTG-based regimen if patient has not received or not failed on DTG
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen
*   (b) ART: If the same **PI-containing** regimen has to be continued
    -> ATT: **Rifampicin** must be replaced with **Rifabutin 150 mg** in anti-TB treatment regimen

**PI*** + DTG
*   Double dosing of **Dolutegravir 50 mg** to be given for the entire duration of anti-TB treatment and **not beyond** (since patient had Rifabutin) ✓\*
    -> ATT: **Rifampicin** must be replaced with **Rifabutin 150 mg** in anti-TB treatment regimen

PI=Lopinavir/r, Darunavir/r, Atazanavir

---

<!-- Page 338 -->



# ART for TB-HIV Co-infected Patients on Bedaquiline or Delamanid

*   (TLD *) DTG-based regimen should be the ART regimen of choice for PLHIV on Bedaquiline / Delamanid-containing DR-TB regimens. Dolutegravir can be used safely and at the usual dose.
*   (✓) If PLHIV are already on NRTI + DTG regimen (TLD), the same is to be continued with BDQ/DLM containing DR-TB regimen (→ DTG).
*   (✓) If PLHIV is on NNRTI/PI-based ART regimen, a DTG-based ART regimen must be used when co-prescribing with BDQ/DLM containing DRTB regimens due to drug-drug interactions. (X PI X BDQ/DLM [non] concomitant)
*   (℗) TB-HIV co-infected PLHIV requiring a PI-based second-/third-line ART need coordination between SACEP (great A.D. clinical expert panel) and the linked DR-TB centre for considering a non-BDQ/DLM DR-TB regimen. (PI + BDQ/DLM => Intensive monitoring, need to be given)
*   (✓) In case an effective DR-TB regimen cannot be made without Bedaquiline/ Delamanid, the necessary DR-TB regimens using new TB drugs may be given with PI-based ART but with intensive monitoring for toxicities of Bedaquiline/ Delamanid.
*   (✓) PLHIV on ARV regimens with boosted PI, if treated with Bedaquiline-based ATT, should be monitored closely.
*   (Ⓝo) No dose adjustments are needed when Delamanid is used with Tenofovir, Efavirenz and Lopinavir/Ritonavir., but more frequent ECG monitoring is advised (TLER).

---

<!-- Page 339 -->

PT WITH HIV DEVELOPING TB
In a nutshell



## OLD REGIMEN X DRTB

*   Tenofovir, lamivudine and Efavirenz ✔
*   Tenofovir, Lamivudine & Nevirapine / Protease Inhibitor ✔

**DS TB**: In efavirenz ART Regimen Rifampicin can be given.
In Nevirapine / PI based regimen Rifabutin used in place of rifampicin.
**DR TB**: Efavirenz PI and BDQ DRUG INTERACTIONS (close monitoring)



## NEW REGIMEN

*   Tenofovir, lamivudine and Dolutegravir (NEW) (TLD)

**DS TB**: Double-dosing DTG in combination with rifampicin-containing ATT ✔
**DR TB**: Dolutegravir can be safely given with BDQ / DLM in DR TB ✔

---

<!-- Page 340 -->



# ATT IN LIVER DISEASE

101

---

<!-- Page 341 -->



# HEPATOTOXIC DRUGS

H, R, Z, Bdq, Eto, PAS and and rarely FQ.
*short MDR drugs*

In patients with pre-existing liver disease with persistently abnormal liver function test, a shorter oral MDR/RR-TB regimen will be avoided due to presence of H(h), Eto and Z.

Safe in liver disease
*   Aminoglycosides
*   Clofazimine (CFZ)
*   Cycloserine (CS)
*   Ethambutol (EMB)
*   Linezolid (LZD)
*   FQs

*Acc - EF_L*

---

<!-- Page 342 -->



# CHILD PUGH SCORE

| Clinical and Lab Criteria | Points* 1 | Points* 2 | Points* 3 |
| :------------------------ | :-------- | :-------- | :-------- |
| Encephalopathy            | None      | Mild to moderate (grade 1 or 2) | Severe (grade 3 or 4) |
| Ascites                   | None      | Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive) | Severe (diuretic refractory) |
| Bilirubin (mg/dL)         | < 2       | 2-3       | > 3       |
| Albumin (g/dL)            | > 3.5     | 2.8-3.5   | < 2.8     |
| Prothrombin time: Seconds prolonged | < 4       | 4-6       | > 6       |
| Prothrombin time: International normalized ratio | < 1.7     | 1.7-2.3   | > 2.3     |

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class obtained by adding score for each parameter (total points)
Class A = 5 to 6 points (least severe liver disease)
Class B = 7 to 9 points (moderately severe liver disease)
Class C = 10 to 15 points (most severe liver disease)

---

### Box 1 Grades of renal impairment in chronic kidney disease (CKD)

**Stage 1 CKD:** Normal creatinine clearance and function but urinary tract abnormality, for example, polycystic kidney, structural abnormality.
**Stage 2 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 60–90 ml/min
**Stage 3 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 30–60 ml/min
**Stage 4 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 15–30 ml/min
**Stage 5 CKD:** Creatinine clearance <15 ml/min with or without dialysis.

# PRESUMPTIVE TB

A Pt with any one of the following :

*   Fever > 2weeks

*   Hemoptysis
*   Significant wt loss

# PRESUMPTIVE DRTB

*   It refers to the patient who is eligible for rifampicin resistant screening at the time of diagnosis OR/and during followup
*   This includes :

RECURRENT CASE: A TB patient previously declared as successfully treated (cured/treatment completed) and is subsequently found to be microbiologically confirmed TB

LOST TO FOLLOW-UP (DR TB): A patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more.

Ultra is non-inferior to the Xpert MTB/RIF assay

Ultra has a higher sensitivity than Xpert MTB/RIF particularly in smear negative culture-positive specimens and in specimens from HIV-infected patients

# WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING

*   NAAT and LPA may not detect clinically relevant mutations outside the rifampicin resistance determining region (RRDR) of the rpoB gene.
*   One such example is the I491F mutation that has been responsible for an outbreak of MDR-TB in Eswatini and remains a grave public health concern.

*   WGS provides a comprehensive review of the entire Mtb genotype with a 96% concordance for culture-based sensitivity testing.
*   It provides genotypic sensitivity to most drugs required for treatment of MDR-TB.
*   Can provide individual Pt centered DR TB Rx.

Kpad Ulbre: IS -> 6110 1081

For some countries, it remains an important tool not only in case diagnosis, but in formulating public health policy by assisting in tracing TB contact cases in outbreaks.

Coll F, McNerney R, Preston MD, et al. Rapid determination of drug-resistant M. tuberculosis whole-genome sequences. Genome Med 2015; 7: 53.

---

<!-- Page 379 -->

TB LAMP

Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) is an isothermal PCR amplification technique that can be performed in peripheral health care settings.

Prepare lysate
Add 30 µL mix
Dried lamp reagents
40 min / 67°C
Fluorescent signal detection

*   TB-LAMP requires less than one hour to perform & generates a result that can be detected with the naked eye under ultraviolet light.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
24

<!-- Page 380 -->



# TB LAMP → Diagnosis not resistance

*   TB-LAMP may be used as a replacement test for sputum smear microscopy to diagnose pulmonary TB in adults with signs and symptoms consistent with TB (conditional recommendation, very low-quality evidence).
*   TB-LAMP should not replace the use of rapid molecular tests that detect TB and resistance to rifampicin. (only D/S not for resistance)
*   In settings where the Xpert MTB/RIF assay cannot be implemented TB-LAMP may be a plausible alternative.

The use of loop-mediated isothermal amplification (TB-LAMP) for the diagnosis of TB : policy guidance 10 August 2016 Policy brief
DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
25

---

<!-- Page 381 -->



# LF LAM: Lateral Flow urine Lipoarabinomannan assay

*   Detects a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell walls. (urinary antigen test)
*   Recommended for use in HIV-coinfected patients (where a sputum sample cannot be obtained).
*   42% sensitivity in HIV patients with TB symptoms cannot distinguish between mycobacterial species, and can cross react with other fungal diseases
*   Can be used as initial test in peripheries in areas of high TB endemicity only, to determine whether symptomatic patients with HIV should be referred for further confirmatory testing

# NEW SKIN TEST (TST + IGRA)

*   C-Tb is the next-generation skin test for detection of Tuberculosis. It has high specificity and contains the same antigens used in IGRA i.e., ESAT 6 and CFP 10. It is unaffected by BCG vaccination status and hence can be used as a tool for latent TB diagnosis

Rapid communication: TB antigen-based skin tests for the diagnosis of TB infection – APRIL 2022

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Antigenic structure of M.Tb

3 main groups –
* actively secreted,
* cell wall-bound, and
* cytoplasmic.

The first two are those initially encountered by the immune system and are thus likely to play a role in the induction of protective defence mechanisms and in pathogenicity

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 20.

# Antigenic structure of M.Tb

Antigenic Structure Cell wall (insoluble) antigens
*   **Peptidoglycan layer** - maintains shape & rigidity
*   **Arabinogalactan layer** - survival of M.tuberculosis within macrophages (ARABS - survival)
*   **Mycolic acid layer** - principal constituent, confers very low permeability, acid fastness and reduces the entry of most antibiotics (mycolic acid)
*   **Outermost layer** - lipids, glycolipids & mycosides (mycosides, mycolic acid)

Cy-Tb (formerly known as the C-Tb test, Serum Institute of India) contains a 1:1 ratio of two recombinant proteins of ESAT-6 and CFP-10 was previously produced by genetically modified Lactobacillus lactis, by Statens Serum Institute (Denmark).

# C-tb / Cy-Tb

C-Tb is the next-generation skin test for detection of Tuberculosis.

*   Easy-to-use (Simple) / Point-of-care (On field) / Specific test (based on ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens of MTb)
*   C-Tb can become an excellent diagnostic test for management of latent TB due to its high specificity for detection of *M. tuberculosis* infection.
*   Unaffected by BCG vaccination status

# Mycobacterial killed Whole-cell/fragmented vaccine

The entire pathogen that is either killed (inactivated) or weakened (attenuated) so that they cannot cause disease. They are known as the whole-organism vaccines.

52

<!-- Page 408 -->



# Mycobacterium vaccae

*   Heat-killed preparations of *M. vaccae* (MV or SRL72) have been extensively studied as adjuncts to standard anti-tuberculous drug therapy for more than decade.
*   It was hypothesized that inactivated MV works by stimulating the host immune responses to antigens shared with Mtb.
*   In addition to markers of cell-mediated immune stimulation, individuals treated with MV had increased antibody titers to the heat shock proteins HSP60 and HSP70 – which are known to be immunostimulatory – in the first month of treatment, as well as raised levels of the cytokines IL-4, IL-10 and TNF-α from ex vivo stimulated PBMCs with inactivated Mtb.

---

<!-- Page 409 -->

MV - V7
Of the therapeutic vaccines under consideration, MV is the most advanced in the clinical pipeline.
After the initial set of small scale studies, a single dose of intradermally delivered MV was felt to be insufficient for a robust clinical response, and trial protocols were modified to include multiple doses.
MV therapy was again associated with rapid sputum culture clearance of Mtb.
However, definitive evidence for MV in treatment outcome in large-scale studies is still awaited.

---

<!-- Page 410 -->



# Mycobacterium indicus pranii

*   MIP comprises **killed M. indicus pranii**, previously known as Mycobacterium w- non-pathogenic mycobacterium closely related to M. avium.
*   There is an ongoing **phase III efficacy and safety trial** for preventing pulmonary TB among healthy household contacts of sputum positive TB patients in India and first results are expected soon (**ICMR**).
*   In summary, **MIP** has shown robust evidence of **immune stimulation**.
*   Evidence of efficacy, however, is **still lacking** or awaited in either treatment, or prevention of active TB following high risk exposure.

---

<!-- Page 411 -->



# RUTI® for MDR-TB



# RUTI
(Handwritten note: : Detoxified liposomal fragments of MTB)

*   RUTI is composed of **liposomes** (highlighted) containing **detoxified fragments of Mtb** (underlined) that was cultured under conditions of hypoxia/stress that can induce **poly antigenic** (highlighted, handwritten ✓) cellular response against non-**replicating bacilli** (highlighted, handwritten ✗)
*   RUTI has improved efficacy against **non-replicating** (highlighted, handwritten ⭐) bacteria (NRB), that are hypothesized to contribute to the requirement of prolonged treatment, as well as relapse (circled).

# RUTI

In human studies, a combined phase I/II clinical trial was conducted to test the tolerability and immunogenicity of different RUTI doses in HIV positive and negative patients.

The results demonstrated that RUTI vaccination had reasonable tolerability profile of RUTI® and a good polyantigenic response in HIV- and HIV+ subjects.

# Live attenuated vaccines

VPM1002 (BCG ΔureC::hly)
_a recombinant BCG technology_

VPM1002 is a recombinant BCG (rBCG) in which the urease C gene has been replaced by the listeriolysin O (LLO) encoding gene (hly) from _Listeria monocytogenes_.

Generated in order to induce a broader immune response against mycobacterial antigens.

A phase II/III clinical trial with VPM1002 is currently ongoing in India to for the prevention of recurrence of active TB in adults following completion of standard therapy (NCT03152903).

# Subunit vaccines

This type of vaccine is constituted of a protein subunit of *Mtb*.

It contains just enough antigenic determinants that are necessary to stimulate a long-lasting protective immune response.



## The subunit approach

Only uses the very specific parts (the subunits) of a virus or bacterium that the immune system needs to recognize.

# Viral vectored vaccines

*   This type of vaccine uses live viruses to carry recombinant DNA molecules that encode the antigenic proteins of Mtb. Transfer of this recombinant DNA into humans causes protein expression, which elicits a protective immune response against Mtb.

    *   **Vector entry into cells**
    *   **Viral antigen/host MHC-1 loading**
    *   **Stimulates host immunity against the pathogen**
    *   **Expression and possible secretion of pathogen antigen in human cell**

# Modified Vaccinia Ankara 85A
*(handwritten: viral vector)*

A viral vector comprising a recombinant replication deficient modified **vaccinia virus, Ankara (MVA)** that allows insertion of large immunogenic sequences and is efficient at **induction of specific T cell responses**.

MVA expressing **antigen 85A (MVA85A)** was shown to **induce a robust Ag85A-specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses** and protected animals to the same extent as BCG following low-dose aerosol infection.

*(handwritten: Subunit: H56/IC31: ESAT6/Ag85B)*

# Modified Vaccinia Ankara 85A
*(Handwritten: Antigen 85A)*

The vaccine has completed a small non-randomized phase I study to evaluate its safety and immunogenicity in 12 healthy volunteers latently infected with TB (NCT00456183)
It showed that MVA85A is immunogenic in LTBI individuals as well as in BCG vaccinated but Mtb-uninfected individuals

Limitations:
*   Small sample size
*   Heterogenicity of the population
*   The vaccine induced a persistent Ag85A-specific polyfunctional T cell response until week 24 post vaccination. *(Handwritten: (6m))*

# The evolving evidence and experience world-wide



## Nix TB trial
*   6-month BPaL regimen – with oral medicines Bedaquiline, Pretomanid and Linezolid (1200 mg)
*   90% of patients with highly-resistant, treatment intolerant/nonresponsive MDR/RR-TB achieved relapse-free cure status 6 months after end of treatment
*   Linezolid likely responsible for most adverse events and all dose modifications



## ZeNix TB trial
*   6-month BPaL regimen – with Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid (4 arms: diff. dose, duration) led to the recommendation that the **optimal dosing of Lzd is 600 mg daily** offers the best balance in terms of efficacy and safety in Pre-XDR-TB patients above 14 years of age
*   optimal efficacy (**91% success rate**) in highly-resistant, treatment intolerant/ nonresponsive MDR/RR-TB, with possibility of dose reduction in event of toxicity or poor tolerability
*   the Lzd dose modification (i.e., interrupted, reduced, or discontinued) if needed after 9 weeks of treatment duration



## TB PRACTECAL trial
*   Stage 1 – 6-months – 3 arms (BPaL, BPaL+Moxifloxacin, BPaL+Clofazimine)
*   Stage 2 – 6-month BPaLM regimen – with oral medicines Bedaquiline (B), Pretomanid (Pa), Linezolid (L)(600 mg) and Moxifloxacin (M)
*   **favorable efficacy** (treatment success rate 89%) and
*   **safety** (more than 2 times lesser grade >3 adverse events as against in the prevailing standard of care)

# Nix TB AND ZeNix TB

The initial, pivotal trial conducted by the TB Alliance (Nix-TB) was an open-label, single-group study from South Africa which showed that 6 months of BPaL (bedaquiline, pretomanid and linezolid) resulted in favorable outcomes in 90% of patients with XDR-TB and MDR-TB which was non-responsive or treatment intolerant.

However, these astounding success rates came at the cost of considerable toxicity, as the dose of linezolid used in this study was 1200 mg a day.

A follow-up study (ZeNix) by the same group across 11 sites in 4 countries showed that 600 mg of linezolid was an equally effective, but less toxic dose.

*   ✓ Infection especially in children → post viral bronchiolitis
*   ✓ CTDs
*   ✓ Transplant → B.O. obliterans → HP
*   Environmental / occupational
*   Drug induced

<!-- Page 46 -->

- Small airways obstruction may lead to
- A reduction in airflow
- Increased airways resistance
- Gas trapping
- Inhomogeneity of ventilation
- Early diagnosis and treatment is needed to **prevent disease progression**

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 17

---

<!-- Page 47 -->



# DIAGNOSTIC METHODS for SAD

*   **Pulmonary Function Test**
    *   Spirometry ✓
    *   Oscillometry ✓
    *   Exhaled NO ✓
    *   Plethysmography \*
    *   Dynamic compliance \*
    *   Inert gas washout \*

*   **IMAGING**
    *   High resolution CT
    *   Hyperpolarised helium ✓
    *   MRI ✓ (can show ventilation pattern)
    *   2D gamma scintigraphy ✓
    *   SPECT ✓ (single photon emission CT)
    *   PET ✓

*   **BIOPSY**

Dr. Bharath Kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
18

---

<!-- Page 48 -->



# SPIROMETRY

*   In health, the main site of airways resistance is the 4th-8th airway generation
*   FEV1 largely reflects large airways obstruction $\approx$ MEFR
*   Forced Expiratory Flow between 25 and 75% of the FVC (FEF25-75)- latter part of the vital capacity is affected by increased resistance in small airways as lung volume decreases.
*   **DISADVANTAGES**
    *   Poor reproducibility as it is dependent on the FVC
    *   There is poor correlation with other markers of small airways disease such as gas trapping and histological evidence of small airways inflammation

Dr. Bharath Kathi MD DNB. FIP FACIEDARM

---

<!-- Page 49 -->



# FEV3 / FEV6 Ratio

*   The ratio of forced expiratory volume in $\text{\textcircled{3}}$ and $\text{\textcircled{6}}$ seconds (FEV3/FEV6) has also emerged as an earlier and $\underline{\text{more sensitive marker of small airways}}$ disease compared with other spirometric measures

# DYNAMIC COMPLIANCE
asked on (10 marks) (OPD)

$C = \frac{dv}{dp} = \text{change in volume per unit change in pressure}$
*   Static means we are not taking airflow into consideration
*   Dynamic means we are taking Air flow (movement)

$\checkmark$ Dynamic compliance, defined as the change in lung volume during airflow produced by a given change in transpulmonary pressure, is normally independent of breathing frequency.

$\circledast$ In normal persons, dynamic compliance closely approximates inspiratory static lung compliance (80%) and remains essentially unchanged even when breathing frequency is increased up to 60 breaths per minute.

$\checkmark$ This indicates that lung units that are parallel with each other normally fill and empty uniformly and synchronously, even when airflow is high and the change in lung volume is rapid.

*   The rate of filling and emptying of a lung unit depends on its time constant—that is, the product of its resistance and compliance.

$Tc = \text{Resis} \times \text{Comp}$

# Dynamic compliance

*   Lung units with high resistance take longer to fill and empty more slowly compared to units with low resistance. [Handwritten: SAD, Filled slow, Emptied late]
*   Patchy narrowing of small peripheral airways produces regional differences in time constants.
*   At low breathing frequencies, when the rate of airflow is low, ventilation is fairly evenly distributed.
*   As the breathing frequency increases: ventilation tends to be distributed to areas that offer the least resistance to airflow. So lung units fed by narrowed airways receive proportionally less ventilation than do areas of the lung where the airways remain open.
*   This frequency dependence of compliance was first noted in a patient with emphysema.

### 3. NUCLEAR MEDICINE

Scintigraphy uses radioactive tracers to obtain images of organs and/or record their functioning. It is a powerful tool that has been widely used to visualize and characterize intrapulmonary drug delivery in airways diseases such as asthma and COPD. It allows the measurement of overall lung deposition, and, to some extent, regional deposition (such as the lung periphery).

The accompanying scintigraphic images from a patient with asthma show aerosol deposition of radioactively labeled albuterol particles in the (a) posterior thorax and (b) anterior thorax, which were recorded sequentially, with the patient repositioned between views. Red areas indicate regions of highest radioactivity and black of least radioactivity.

<!-- Page 63 -->



# SPECT : Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography


## ? 3D VENTILATION SCAN



### Single-photon emission computed tomography

Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a 3-dimensional nuclear imaging technique involving use of radioactive tracers to highlight certain features of organs/tissues, such as the patchy distribution of small airways disease. Single-photon emission computed tomography images are sometimes combined with traditional computed tomography images to correlate functional and structural features.

The accompanying Technegas ventilation SPECT/computed tomography (CT) fusion image shows the axial dimension of a 68-year-old man with moderately severe COPD. It highlights well-ventilated areas of the lung (bright yellow), less-ventilated areas (red) and nonventilated areas (black). Green indicates emphysema.
It is apparent that poorly ventilated areas tend to correspond with areas of emphysema.

# CPAP & BPAP

*   **CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure)**
    *   Maintains a constant pressure throughout the breath

*   **BPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure)**
    *   Two levels of pressure applied
    *   Expiratory positive airway pressure/EPAP
    *   Inspiratory positive airway pressure/ IPAP
    *   Difference between IPAP & EPAP is pressure support
    *   Modes: Spontaneous (S), Timed (T), Spontaneous/Timed (S/T), PAC

<!-- Page 26 -->



# SPONTANEOUS MODE ( S )

*   Breaths are patient triggered & patient cycled
*   No option to set RR
*   RR is determined by the patient
*   Ventilator delivered breaths = patient's spontaneous RR

Disadvantages:

*   Patient's RR ↓, ventilator delivered breaths ↓
*   Ventilator will not deliver breaths if patient is not breathing

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



# TIMED MODE (T)

*   Breaths are machine triggered (time trigger) and machine cycled (time cycled)
*   Operator sets RR and inspiratory time
*   Ventilator starts IPAP after preset time interval (depends on set RR)
*   Ventilator switches to EPAP after preset inspiratory time

**Example**
*   Set RR 15 & inspiratory time 1 second
*   Ventilator delivers a breath after every 4 seconds (60/15=4)
*   Ventilator ends IPAP for 1 second (cycles into expiration/ starts EPAP)

**Disadvantage:**
*   Ventilator delivers fixed number of breaths regardless of the patient's spontaneous RR
*   Poorly tolerated by patients because of lack of interaction between the patient and ventilator
*   Used very rarely

# Goals of NIV

*   **Oxygenation**
    *   CPAP/EPAP/PEEP
        *   Alveolar recruitment
        *   Maintains upper airway patency
        *   Decreases work of breathing by counteracting the effects of auto PEEP

*   **CO₂ removal**
*   **Unloading respiratory muscles**
    *   IPAP/PS
        *   Augments tidal volume & alveolar ventilation

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Physiological effects of NIV

*   Alveolar collapse
*   Alveolar oedema
*   Consolidation

These conditions contribute to:

*   V/Q mismatch
*   Shunt
*   Decreased compliance
*   Decreased FRC

These, in turn, lead to:

*   V/Q mismatch $\downarrow$ Hypoxia
*   Shunt $\downarrow$ Hypoxia
*   Decreased compliance $\downarrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue
*   Decreased FRC $\downarrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue

NIV (Non-Invasive Ventilation) addresses these issues:

*   Hypoxia $\uparrow$ NIV (via $\text{FiO}_2$)
*   NIV $\uparrow$ Decreased compliance (via $\text{EPAP/PEEP}$)
*   NIV $\uparrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue (via $\text{IPAP/PS}$)

---

<!-- Page 57 -->



# CPAP

*   CPAP increases FRC
*   Increases mean airway pressure
*   Maintains upper airway patency
*   Lung recruitment
*   Decreases work in case of auto PEEP
*   EPAP is necessary to ensure sufficient expiratory flow to flush carbon dioxide from the ventilatory dead space, enabling removal of carbon dioxide from the ventilator circuit and preventing rebreathing.
*   Fixed CPAP/ Auto CPAP
*   It does not unload respiratory muscles

---

<!-- Page 58 -->



## How to set CPAP/EPAP/PEEP?

*   Start with 3 to 5 cm H₂O CPAP
*   1 cm H₂O increments
*   Increase CPAP
    *   To relieve obstructive apneas
    *   To improve oxygenation
    *   Ineffective triggering in the presence of auto PEEP

* *Increase IPAP equal to EPAP increments to maintain a constant pressure support*

High PEEP
*   Leaks
*   Patient discomfort

Low PEEP
*   Ineffective triggering
*   Trigger delay
*   Upper airway obstructions leading to arousals

<!-- Page 60 -->



# IPAP & Pressure support

*   Provides ventilator assistance
*   Unloads inspiratory muscles
*   Decreases work of breathing
*   Augments tidal volume, minute ventilation, gas exchange

*   Critical care ventilators
    *   Pressure support is the pressure applied at the airway opening above the PEEP
    *   e.g. PEEP 5 and pressure support 10 cm H₂O
    *   During inspiration airway pressure rises 10 cm H₂O above PEEP. Total pressure 15 cmH₂O
*   Bilevel ventilators
    *   IPAP is the pressure relative to atmosphere
    *   The difference between IPAP and EPAP is the Pressure support
    *   E.g. EPAP 5 cm H₂O and IPAP 10 cm H₂O.

# How to set IPAP / pressure support?

*   The difference between IPAP & EPAP should be 4 to 5 cm H₂O
*   If the EPAP is 4, Starting IPAP 8

# Aerophagia

*   During NIV, the ventilation volume distributes between lungs and stomach depending on respiratory system resistance and lower oesophageal sphincter pressure (20-25 cm H₂O).
*   Predisposing factors: large tidal volumes, high pressure setting, high airway resistance, low respiratory system compliance, short inspiratory time, short rise time.
*   Gastric distension compresses the lungs, thereby decreasing lung compliance and requiring higher airway ventilation pressure. The latter is also associated with increased risk of gastric distension, thus generating a vicious cycle.
*   Symptoms-bloating, abdominal distention, flatulence, or excessive belching

*   Increase expiratory time, ensure adequate tidal volumes, and reduce RR
