<!-- Page 11 -->



# Symptoms

*   chronic non-tender lymphadenopathy in a young adult with
    fever
*   most commonly in the cervical region
*   Cough may be a prominent symptom in patients with
    mediastinal lymphadenopathy

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP
FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 12 -->



# Examination

*   Palpable lymphadenopathy - varying size, number and consistency
*   Size of lymph node: Significant if >2 cm diameter in the inguinal region and >1 cm in other regions ⭐
*   Generalized (>3 groups) - (DID) HIV/NHL/TB/Infectious Mononucleosis/SLE. ✔️✔️✔️✔️✔️
*   Lymph nodes - discrete or matted, firm or cystic inconsistency if necrosis and abscess formation ✔️
*   Matted lymph node: Matted lymph nodes are described as a group of nodes that are conglomerated. ✔️ ⭕⭕ 〰️〰️
*   Not tender unless secondary bacterial infection. ✔️

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB, FIP, FADI, EDARU

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



# Differential Diagnosis of Lymphadenopathy

*   **Infectious**
    *   Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    *   NTM
    *   Bacterial: sinusitis, otitis externa, cellulitis, abscess, tonsillitis, pharyngitis
    *   Viral: EBV, CMV, HIV
    *   Others: fungal, parasitological
*   Sarcoidosis
*   SLE
*   Castleman disease
*   Histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis (Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease)
*   Drugs
*   **Neoplasms**
    *   Primary hematologic malignancy: HL, NHL
    *   Melanoma, SCC skin cancers
    *   Solid-organ cancer metastatic
*   Miscellaneous conditions

# WHAT TESTS ?



## ALL
*   CXR ✔
*   HIV Testing ✔

## Selected pts

# Sampling & Investigations

-   FNA: Direct / Usg guided

# Sampling & Investigations- Biopsy

(When)
*   FNA is not diagnostic in the setting of strong clinical suspicion of TB or alternate diagnosis is suspected. => Biopsy
*   Excisional biopsy >> incisional biopsy (TBEB [Trans Bronchial cryo Biopsy])
*   Mediastinal lymph node biopsy - mediastinoscopy/VATS

(Handwritten notes around "Biopsy" title):
(HPE)
-> CBNAAT
-> AFB
-> culture

**Merits:**
*   Highest diagnostic yield / adequacy of sample

**Limitations:**
*   Requires experience
*   Local complications like infection, sinus tract formation

DR. BHARATH RATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARU

---

<!-- Page 17 -->

FNAC > Biopsy
(NAAT +ve)

Note: Finding of a caseating granuloma on histopathology with constitutional symptoms is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, ATT may be initiated in such cases even in absence of microbiological evidence

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
36

---

<!-- Page 18 -->



# Role of radiological imaging in TBLN

*   **USG**: Tuberculous nodes tend to be hypoechoic, round, without echogenic hilus and tend to show intranodal cystic necrosis, nodal matting, and adjacent soft-tissue oedema.
*   **EBUS**: EBUS-TBNA in whom mediastinal TB is suspected
    *   *p. D/t tuberculous inflammation*
*   **CT**: Lymph nodes showing peripheral enhancement with hypodense centres, secondary to caseous and/or liquefactive necrosis. Conglomerate lymph node masses with areas of necrosis secondary to perinodal inflammation.
*   **MRI**: follow-up cases of mediastinal tuberculosis : mostly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
*   During anti-TB treatment, some bacillus-negative tuberculomas do not decrease in size and may even increase, making it difficult for the physician to decide whether to modify treatment.
*   18F-FDG PET/CT imaging may help, as the changes in glycolytic activity within the inflammatory lesion, measured by 18F-FDG uptake, correlate well with the clinical markers of response
    *   *\[X No Metabolic Activity -> It can be dropped]*

Dr. Bharath Kadi MD DNB FIR FACI EDARM
39

---

<!-- Page 19 -->



# CT

CT provides knowledge of the **site, extent and status** of the affected lymph node

“**RIM SIGN**” that consists of a hypodense centres, representing caseous necrosis, surrounded by a peripheral enhancing rim due to granulomatous inflammatory tissue. (not pathognomonic)

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Treatment

LNTB primarily requires medical management, adjunct surgical excision is generally associated with worse outcomes. 6 - ⑨ months
Six months ATT standard first-line regimen is recommended for peripheral lymph node TB

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB, FIP FACI EDARW

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# Assess Response To Treatment At 3- 4 Months



## Response to therapy at 3 months

*   **Yes**
    *   Symptom resolution ✓
    *   Continue ATT ✓

*   **No**
    *   **Increase in size of LN ± signs of inflammation**
        *   Check old culture report
        *   Send new cultures if not available
        *   Susceptible TB (5)
            *   Paradoxical worsening (6)
            *   Refer to higher centre
        *   Drug resistant TB (8)
            *   Therapeutic drug monitoring (7) ✓
                *   *Handwritten note:* sometimes drugs might Not reach to the LN properly [Drugs may Not have properly metabolised & reaching LN]
            *   Refer to DOTS plus centre (9)

    *   **Constitutional symptoms persist** (a)
        *   R/o alternate diagnosis (b)
        *   *Handwritten notes:*
            *   ? DRTB ✓
            *   ? Drug related -> TDM ✓
            *   ? Paradoxical worsening ✓
            *   ? Alternate diagnosis ✓

---
BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 23 -->



# Treatment

⭐ when to stop ATT in patients with persistently enlarged ⭐ mediastinal lymph nodes ?

✓ when there is absence of interval change in CT/MRI of mediastinal lymph nodes for more than 4 months

✓ with a resolution of all other clinical signs and symptoms.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB. FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 24 -->



# Residual lymphadenopathy - at the end of treatment

(Handwritten notes: 6m Rx, >1cm size)

*   **Residual lymphadenopathy > 1cm size**
    *   (Handwritten notes: Inguinal LNs: >2cm? significant, All other LNs: >1cm)
    *   **If clinical features have persisted or reappeared:**
        *   Extend 3m Rx (Handwritten, circled)
        *   Addnl 3 months of RHE
        *   Followed by BIOPSY & culture (Handwritten: sensitivities)
    *   **If clinical features have resolved:**
        *   Residual fibrotic LN
        *   NO NEED TO EXTEND ATT

---
DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAGI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# Paradoxical Reaction

*   Patient on ATT
*   Initial Improvement
*   Clinical or radiological worsening of pre-existing lesions / new lesions are developed (Handwritten: lesions)
*   first 3 weeks to 4 months may be due- Paradoxical Reaction (Handwritten: worsening due to immune system)

self-limiting, serious morbidity and, on rare occasions, death

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Paradoxical Reaction

*   Rule out alternative diagnosis

Management:
*   Continuation of ATT
*   Symptomatic treatment
*   NSAIDs for pain
*   USG guided aspiration in fluctuation For biopsy & culture

*Handwritten notes:*
If you are strongly suspecting something else
↓ an ORTB Alternate cause

---

## Follow up
1, 2, 3-4 and 6 months.
Imaging to be repeated if clinically indicated.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

CONTENT:
# Sleep- Definition

* Lies between the continuum of life and death
* State of partial or complete unconsciousness from which a subject can be aroused by appropriate sensory stimuli
* Physiological circadian inhibition of reticular activation system
* Active or passive- dichotomy?

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# Sleep Functions
* Memory consolidation
* Energy conservation
* Body growth
* Immune regulation
* Behavioural adaptation
* Growth & Hormonal Equilibrium (during sleep more)

---

<!-- Page 23 -->

Circadian rhythm- Sleep wake cycle

① Light
RHT
RGC
② Retino-hypothalamic Rt. Hypothal. tract
SCN
③ Suprachiasmatic nuclei
Pineal gland
④ ↓ Melatonin
SCG
Hypothalamic and brainstem Sleep/wake regulating centers

---

<!-- Page 24 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   Wakefulness is maintained by activation of the ascending reticular activating system (involving several neurotransmitters glutamate, acetylcholine and the monoamines)
*   NREM sleep onset is associated with a reduction in activation of the ascending reticular activating system and an increase in neural activity within the ventrolateral pre-optic area, anterior hypothalamus and basal forebrain.
*   NREM sleep is triggered by activation of cholinergic neurons in the latero dorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei.
*   The suppression of motor activity in REM sleep is generated by glutamate-mediated activation of descending medullary reticular formation.

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   Specifically, there are two ascending pathways: one, a dorsal route from the cholinergic laterodorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei, activates thalamic neurons to promote EEG activity via glutamatergic thalamocortical projections (Saper et al., 2005).
*   The ventral route through the hypothalamus includes the aminergic arousal system that originates from the brainstem with serotonergic (dorsal raphe nuclei), noradrenergic (locus coeruleus), histaminergic (tuberomammillary nucleus) and dopaminergic (ventral periaqueductal grey) neurons
*   Cortical activation during wakefulness is also influenced by orexinergic (hypocretin) neurons originating in the hypothalamus, and cholinergic neurons from the basal forebrain
*   During wakefulness, these pathways allow sensory information to be transmitted to areas of the association cortex via the thalamic gate.

---

<!-- Page 26 -->

The transition between wakefulness and sleep occurs through a process of reciprocal inhibition between arousal- and sleep-promoting neurons by way of a “flip-flop” switch (McGinty et al., 2000).

**Wake**
*   TMN Histamine
*   DR Serotonin
*   LC Noradrenaline
*   LH Orexin
*   VLPO GABA/Galanin (ventrolateral pre-optic nucleus)

**Sleep**
*   TMN Histamine
*   DR Serotonin
*   LC Noradrenaline
*   LH Orexin
*   VLPO GABA/Galanin

**Legend**
*   → Excitatory
*   ⊣ Inhibitory

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   This is an all-or-nothing process that prevents the occurrence of intermediate conscious states. At sleep onset, <u>neurons in the ventrolateral pre-optic area (VLPO), anterior hypothalamus and basal forebrain are activated and inhibit</u> the arousal systems detailed previously.
*   In particular, the <u>VLPO neurons containing the inhibitory neurotransmitters c-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and galanin, project to (and inhibit) the wake-promoting regions of the ascending reticular system</u> (Sherin et al., 1998) and the descending brainstem arousal neurons
*   REM sleep occurs with activation of cholinergic neurons in the laterodorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei.
*   This cholinergic activation occurs when withdrawal of the aminergic arousal systems (noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus and serotonergic neurons in the dorsal raphe nuclei) produces disinhibition.

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   This causes the release of acetylcholine, which triggers the increased neural activity that is a feature of REM sleep.
*   <u>Suppression of motor activity, the other marker of REM sleep, is generated by glutamate-mediated activation of descending medullary reticular formation</u> relay neurons (fig. 1c). T
*   he activity of these neurons is inhibitory to spinal motor neurons via the release of glycine and to a lesser extent GABA (Reinoso-Suarez et al., 2001).

---

<!-- Page 29 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

* Sleep process is regulated by neurons that shut down the arousal systems, thus allowing the brain to fall asleep.
* These neurons are found in the preoptic area of the hypothalamus. These neurons, containing molecules that inhibit neuronal communication, turnoff the arousal systems during sleep.
* Initiation and maintenance of sleep require suppression of activity in the ascending arousal systems. This is accomplished by inhibitory neurons of the ventrolateral preoptic area (VLPO) which remain active throughout sleep

---

<!-- Page 30 -->



# Orexin pathways

*   Input from hypothalamus- Control energy metabolism
*   Input from suprachiasmatic nucleus- Sleep wake cycle
*   Input from limbic system- Emotional control of wakefulness
*   Input from preoptic areas- Initiate and maintain sleep

**Legend:**
*   Orexin neurons
*   Activation
*   Inhibition
*   brain regions
*   humoral factors

*   Leptin Glucose ↑

---

<!-- Page 31 -->



# SLEEP ONSET

Wakefulness drive to breathe and behavioral influences cease with sleep onset.

Movement and excitatory input to breathe from other external sensors become minimal or completely absent.

Chemosensitivity also decreases.

Accordingly, respiratory pump muscle tone is reduced, leading to a reduction in minute ventilation.

An abrupt reduction in upper airway muscle tone and protective reflexes - contribute to increased upper airway resistance.

---

<!-- Page 32 -->



# NREM sleep

*   Ventrolateral pre-optic area(VLPO) – thalamus
*   Anterior hypothalamus
*   Basal forebrain

*   The VLPO neurons containing inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA
*   Inhibit wake promoting regions ARAS and descending brainstem arousal neurons.

---

<!-- Page 33 -->



# REM sleep

*   Cholinergic activation in pons and basal forebrain
*   Disfacilitation of muscarinic receptors-upper airway
*   Inhibitory to spinal motor neurons via the release of glycine and to a lesser extent, GABA (Suppression of motor activity)

---

<!-- Page 34 -->



# Sleep architecture

*   Cycles of NREM and REM sleep alternate throughout the night in a predictable manner.
*   Sleep architecture changes with age, drugs and diseases
*   Infants have more REM sleep
*   Ageing is associated with difficulty in maintaining sleep and more frequent arousals.

**The Sleep Cycle Diagram:**
*   N1
*   N2
*   N3
*   REM
*   Light Sleep
*   Deep Sleep
*   Vivid Dreaming

---

<!-- Page 35 -->



# Sleep architecture

Sleep is divided into 2 states based on three physiologic measurements (EEG, EOG, EMG) according to AASM
* NREM Sleep (N1, N2, N3)
* REM sleep – Awake mind & a paralyzed body (paradoxical sleep)

In ideal situations, NREM and REM alternate in a cyclic manner, each cycle lasting on an average of 90-110 mins.
During normal sleep periods in adults, 4-6 such cycles are noted.
The first two cycles are dominated by slow wave sleep (Stage N3 of American Academy of Sleep Medicine), subsequent cycles contain less slow wave sleep.

(Handwritten notes on the top right: 90-110 min, 4-6 cycles)

---

<!-- Page 36 -->



# Sleep architecture

✓ In contrast, the REM sleep cycle increases from the first to last cycle, and the longest REM sleep episode toward the end of night may last for an hour.
✓ First third is dominated by the SWS and the last third is dominated by REM sleep.
* Older rules had four stages of NREM sleep and the current rules, NREM stage 3 and 4 are combined as stage N3
✓ NREM sleep accounts for 75-80% of sleep time
* According to R-K(Rechtschaffen & Kales) manual, NREM is divided into 4 stages (1-4) and to the recent recent AASM scoring manual, it is subdivided into three stages ( N1,N2,N3), primarily based on EEG criteria

CONTENT:
# N2 sleep

*   Stage N2 comprises of 45-55% of sleep time
*   It begins after approximately 10-12 min of stage 1
*   Sleep spindles(mostly 12-14Hz) and K complexes(negative sharp waves followed immediately by a positive component) intermixed with vertex sharp waves herald the onset of stage N2.
*   EEG at this stage also shows theta waves, muscle tone intermediate
*   No or few slow eye movements
*   Regular respiration and heart rate

---

<!-- Page 43 -->

Stage N2: K complexes (red rectangles) and sleep spindles (green rectangles).

Otolaryngol Clin North Am. 2016 Dec;49(6):1307-1329

---

<!-- Page 44 -->



# N3 Sleep

*   N3 or Slow Wave Sleep comprises of 15-23% of total sleep time
*   After about 30-60 min of N2 sleep, stage 3 sleep begins and slow waves
*   R-K Stages 3 & 4 NREM are grouped together as slow wave sleep and are replaced by stage N3 in the new AASM scoring manual.
*   Body movements are recorded as artifacts in PSG recordings toward the end of SWS as sleep is lightening.

**Handwritten Notes:**
*   N1: 3-8%
*   N2: 45-55%
*   N3: 15-23%

---

<!-- Page 45 -->

Stage N3 or slow-wave sleep: numerous delta waves.

Otolaryngol Clin North Am. 2016 Dec;49(6):1307-1329

---

<!-- Page 46 -->



# REM sleep

*   REM sleep sets the stage for dreams ⭐
*   In 8 hour sleep we will experience 4 or 5 REM sleep STAGES and every time we enter REM, we stay bit longer in it ✓
*   Although the entire nervous system becomes active during REM, movements like walking are absent because the muscles become atonic.
*   REM Sleep is called paradoxical sleep since brain activities during REM are comparable to those during wakefulness ✓
*   REM sleep accounts for 20-25% of total sleep time. (1/4th)
*   Based on EEG, EMG and EOG characteristics, REM can be subdivided into tonic and phasic stages

---

<!-- Page 47 -->

Stage REM.REMs on the top 2 lines and low tone on chin EMG on the bottom line

Otolaryngol Clin North Am. 2016 Dec;49(6):1307-1329

---

<!-- Page 48 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

*   Suppression of respiratory center (neural) control leading to ↓ TV and MV.
*   Normally 10% ↓ in MV in NREM and 20% ↓ in MV in REM, that in COPD is 20% and 40% in NREM and REM respectively ↓PaO₂ & ↑PaCO₂ also ↓ed
*   Circadian changes in airway leading to mild nocturnal bronchoconstriction
*   ↓ ribcage contribution to breathing and ↓ in accessory muscle activity
*   ↓ FRC because of respiratory muscle hypotonia, cephalad displacement of the diaphragm, and a ↓ in lung compliance leading to V/Q mismatch.
*   This leads to drop in PaO₂ by 3–10 mm Hg and elevation in PaCO₂ by 2–8 mm Hg during sleep.

---

<!-- Page 49 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep



## Ventilatory Regulation

*   Central controller
*   Sensors
*   Effectors

# Central controllers



## PONTINE RESPIRATORY GROUP
*   Nucleus parabrachialis medialis- contain expiratory neurons
*   Nucleus parabrachialis lateralis and Kolliker fuse nucleus - inspiratory neurons
*   ⭐<u>Control duration of inspiration</u>



## VENTRAL RESPIRATORY GROUP
*   ⭐<u>Nucleus tractus solitarius</u>(key cardiorespiratory sensory integration site) _(feedback s.r.ch)_
*   receive afferent information from peripheral and central chemoreceptors (retrotrapezoid nucleus)
*   Afferent -phrenic and intercostal nerves



## DORSAL RESPIRATORY GROUP _(DRG, pacemaker q. Resp)_
*   ⭐<mark style="background-color: #FFD700">Prebotzinger complex</mark>
*   ⭐<mark style="background-color: #FFFF00">(inspiratory) Pacemaker</mark>
*   <mark style="background-color: #FFD700">Botzinger complex inspiratory& expiratory neurons</mark>
*   Rostral retroambigualis
*   Caudal retroambigualis
*   NUCLEUS AMBIGUOUS- Motorneuron that innervate muscles of larynx and pharynx

---

<!-- Page 51 -->

Central chemoreceptors- retrotrapezoid nucleus (ventralateral surface of medulla)
Peripheral Chemoreceptors Carotid body and aortic body
Pulmonary Mechanoreceptors- pulmonary stretch receptors, J receptors, Bronchial c fibres
Upper airway receptors- promote airway patency by activation of local mucle including genioglossus

---

<!-- Page 52 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

"Diminished during sleep"
* Peripheral Chemoreceptors (O2, CO2, H+)
* Central Chemoreceptors (CO2, H+)
* Stretch receptors in lungs

"Absent during sleep"
* Wakefulness drive to breathe
* Cerebral cortex voluntary control over breathing

---

<!-- Page 53 -->

Brain

External carotid artery
Internal carotid artery
Carotid body
Common carotid artery
Cranial nerve X (vagus nerve)
Sensory nerve fiber in cranial nerve X
Aortic bodies in aortic arch
Aorta
Heart

---

<!-- Page 54 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

*   Respiratory motor neurons
*   Diaphragm phrenic nerve C3 to C5
*   Accessory muscles of respiration
    *   Inspiration - external intercostal, sternocleidomastoid, scalenes, trapezius, lattismus dorsi, both pectoralis
    *   Expiration- internal intercostal, abdominal muscles
*   Upper airway muscles
    *   Genioglossus (hypoglossal nerve) and tensor palatine (trigeminal), sternohyoid (spinal c1-c3) - pharyngeal dilator

*(Handwritten annotation: E SSILP)*

---

<!-- Page 55 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

*   Postural muscle tone - <mark>highest in wakefulness, decreased in NREM sleep and minimal in REM</mark>
*   Respiratory muscles with respiratory and non respiratory (postural and/or behavioral) functions - **Intercostal and pharyngeal muscles**
    *   Same as in postural muscles, decreases in activity immediately at sleep onset
*   Respiratory muscles with respiratory functions only - **Diaphragm**
    *   <mark>Lesser suppression of activity in NREM and spared the inhibition of REM</mark>
*   **Phrenic motoneuron** - inspiratory drive from neurons of DRG AND VRG
*   **Hypoglossal motoneuron** - <mark>from reticular neurons which provide tonic drive to respiratory system (so particularly affected in sleep)</mark>
    *   This tonic drive to the pharyngeal muscles which contribute to <mark>baseline airway size and stiffness, is most prominent in wakefulness but withdrawn in sleep resulting in an upper airway more vulnerable to collapse</mark>

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

Wakefulness drive to breathe and **behavioral influences** cease with sleep onset.

Movement and excitatory input to breathe from other **external sensors** become minimal or completely absent.

**Chemosensitivity** also decreases.

Accordingly, respiratory pump **muscle tone** is reduced, leading to a reduction in minute ventilation.

An abrupt reduction in **upper airway muscle tone** and **protective reflexes** - contribute to increased upper airway resistance.

---

<!-- Page 57 -->

*During sleep*
*   Control of breathing becomes dominated by chemical input.
*   Ventilatory responses to hypoxia - reduced during N2 and N3. CO2 is the main regulator of breathing during sleep.
*   Though, responses to hypercapnia also reduced lesser extent than for hypoxia. (People can tolerate lower levels of minute ventilation and higher levels of CO2 during sleep than in wakefulness.)
*   Minute ventilation is reduced by 1 to 2 L/ minute, and Paco2 increases by 3 to 8 mm Hg during stable sleep, compared with wakefulness

---

<!-- Page 58 -->

*   NREM sleep - breathing is quite regular
*   REM sleep, by contrast, is characterized by breathing irregularity. Breathing frequency increases, and major variations are seen in breath-to-breath tidal volume.
*   Protective upper airway reflexes also are inhibited. Accordingly, obstructive apnea is common during REM sleep.

---

<!-- Page 59 -->



# Arousals

*   Brief cortical arousals (<15sec) from sleep occur 10 to 20 times / hour in healthy subjects
    *   Frequency increases with age
*   Can occur spontaneously or in conjugation with a sleep disorder(apnea/hypopnea) or periodic limb movement disorder
*   Beneficial - Rapidly resolve blood gas disturbances and alleviate the increased work of breathing during flow-limited breathing.
*   Harmful - Rapid switch from sleep to wakefulness and the subsequent resumption of sleep can be highly destabilizing for respiratory control.
*   Extent depends on - Arousal threshold & Ventilatory response to arousal

---

<!-- Page 60 -->

**AROUSAL THRESHOLD**
* Person with low arousal threshold - repetitive breathing disturbances as the affected person oscillates between wakefulness and sleep.
* Approximately 1/3rd of patients with obstructive sleep apnea has low arousal threshold

---

CONTENT:
# VENTILATORY RESPONSE TO AROUSAL:

*   With arousal, the wakefulness chemical control of breathing is reinstated, and the increased levels of CO2 that were tolerated during sleep suddenly become excessive.
*   Upper airway motoneurons are activated, and sleep-related upper airway resistance is rapidly resolved.
*   Arousal from sleep is associated with a rapid increase in breathing
    *   On the resumption of sleep, the previous ventilatory response to arousal can drive Paco2 levels below a critical level known as the apnea threshold.

---

<!-- Page 62 -->

| Parameters                       | Wakefulness | NREM sleep             | REM sleep                       |
| :--------------------------------- | :---------- | :--------------------- | :------------------------------ |
| Respiratory rate                   | Normal      | Decreases              | Variable, apnea may occur       |
| Minute ventilation                 | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Alveolar ventilation               | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| PaCO$_2$                           | Normal      | Increases slightly     | Increases further slightly      |
| PaO$_2$                            | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases further slightly      |
| SaO$_2$                            | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases further               |
| Hypoxic ventilatory response       | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Hypercapnic ventilatory response   | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Upper airway muscle tone           | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases markedly or is absent |
| Upper airway resistance            | Normal      | Increases              | Increases further               |

---

<!-- Page 63 -->



# Apnea threshold

*   Level of PaCo2 below which respiration stops
*   Ranges between 2 to 6 mm Hg below the stable sleep Paco2 level (Evidently similar to the wakefulness Paco2 level).
*   The difference between the wakefulness PaCO2 level and the apnea threshold is termed the CO2 reserve.
*   The lower the CO2 reserve, the smaller is the ventilation required for reaching the apneic threshold and developing central apnea.

---

<!-- Page 64 -->



# Loop Gain

*   Overall sensitivity of ventilatory control system
*   Controller gain – effectiveness of PCO2 on ventilation
*   Planter gain (effectiveness of ventilation to eliminate PCO2)
*   When FRC and dead space reduced – plant gain is high and apnea threshold is reached fast
*   Cpap – improves FRC and dead space and reduce the plant gain

LOOP GAIN = **VENTILATORY RESPONSE / VENTILATORY DISTURBANCE**
$\checkmark < 1$ - A stable ventilatory system with low respiratory variability because disturbances lead to smaller responses, assuring a rapid return to a stable pattern.
$\checkmark > 1$ - An unstable ventilatory system with high respiratory variability, in which disturbances lead to disproportionately large responses, resulting in a perpetual waxing and waning pattern.

---

<!-- Page 68 -->

Several factors influence each of the gains:

*   1) **Controller gain** -Sensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to changes in partial pressure of gases, sensitivity of central centres to peripheral chemoreceptors, and the excitability and integrity of the lower motor neurons supplying the respiratory muscle;
*   2) **Plant gain** _lung_ -Respiratory cycle frequency, ventilation-perfusion matching, and dead-space ventilation;
*   3) **Mixing gain** - Circulatory delay time, thoracic blood volume, and brain extracellular fluid volume.

## OSA DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA

OSA is the occurrence of an average $\ge 5$ obstructive events (-> NO Air flow + Resp effort) / hour of sleep with sleep related symptoms or comorbidities
or
$\ge 15$ such events without any sleep related symptoms or comorbidities.

*   OSA severity is graded as follows: Apnea Hypopnea Index
    *   normal (no OSA; AHI < 5 /hr)
    *   mild (AHI 5-14 /hr)
    *   moderate (AHI 15-29 /hr)
    *   severe (AHI $\ge 30$/hr)

*   C/o <u>daytime sleepiness</u>, <u>unrefreshing sleep</u>, fatigue, or insomnia
*   Awakening with breath-holding, gasping, or choking

# ① UPPER AIRWAY DIMENSIONS

*   Upper airway dimensions are **reduced in OSA**.
*   \* ↓ **AIRWAY PATENCY** ✔
    *   ✔ ↓ Airway size: small retrognathic mandible, or by *increased volume* of soft tissues (tongue, lateral walls).
    *   ✔ ↑ Airway length predisposing to collapse. ✦
    *   O ↓ **Lung volume** ➔ less tracheal traction and **reduced upper airway patency**.



## Starling resistor

*   Intraluminal ↑ Pcrit
*   -6 cm H₂O ↑↑ **Pcrit**

*(Diagrams illustrating the Starling resistor model and pressure dynamics in the pharynx are present here. The top diagram shows nasal, collapsible, and hypopharyngeal segments with pressure points (e.g., 0 cm H₂O, Rn, Ro, -ve, ++). The bottom diagram illustrates airflow, transluminal forces, and pressure values in different parts of the airway: Atmospheric pressure -0 cm H₂O, Nasal pressure -0 cm H₂O, Pharyngeal pressure -4 cm H₂O, Pulmonary pressure -30 cm H₂O.)*



# ② UPPER AIRWAY COLLAPSIBILITY

*   ✔ Much of the human upper airway is a **collapsible tube**. (No cartilage) pharyngeal
*   ✔ Pharyngeal **Pcrit** is the pressure at which the airway **can no longer stay open and collapses**. It is a measure of the level of **collapsibility of the pharyngeal airway**.
*   ✔ **A more negative Pcrit : less collapsible** airway. ➔ ⓝ
*   ✔ Normal breathing (*Pcrit < -10 cm H₂O*).
*   And obstructive apnea (*Pcrit > 0 cm H₂O*).

---

<!-- Page 81 -->



# ③ NEUROMUSCULAR FACTORS

*Genioglossus*

*   GG plays a very important role in **upper airway patency** during sleep
    *   Innervated by **hypoglossal (XII) nerve** \*
*   Neural mechanisms **modulating arousal** (serotonergic and noradrenergic neurons) have a **tonic** excitatory influence on genioglossus activity.
*   With the onset of sleep, there is a reduction in **arousal-modulated** excitatory output to the upper airway musculature.
*   During episodes of upper airway collapse, arousal from sleep in response to respiratory activation helps to restore airway patency.
*   Although arousals are not always necessary for recovery from upper airway obstruction, patients with OSA have a diminished ability to restore ventilation without cortical arousal compared with non snorers.
*   At the onset of sleep **GG activity falls farther and more quickly in OSA**
    *   → upper airway obstruction
*   Other factors **muscles may be injured** leading to **reduced contractility**
*   There is also evidence for **upper airway neuropathy** in OSA

# Scoring W

Score epochs as stage W when more than 50% of the epoch contains EITHER a or b or BOTH:

a) **Posterior dominant rhythm** (alpha rhythm) over the occipital region (individuals generating posterior dominant rhythm [alpha rhythm] with eye closure)

# Scoring N1 sleep

*   **Slow eye movements (SEM)**: Conjugate, reasonably regular, sinusoidal eye movements with an initial deflection that usually last >500 msec.
*   **Low-amplitude, mixed-frequency (LAMF)**: Low-amplitude EEG activity that is predominantly 4–7 Hz.

*   In individuals who generate a posterior dominant rhythm (alpha rhythm), score stage N1 if the posterior dominant rhythm (alpha rhythm) is attenuated and replaced by low-amplitude, mixed-frequency activity for more than 50% of the epoch.

# Scoring N2 sleep

*   **K complex**: A well-delineated, negative, sharp wave immediately followed by a positive component standing out from the background EEG, with total duration ≥0.5 seconds, and usually maximal in amplitude when recorded using frontal derivations.
*   **Sleep spindle**: A train of distinct sinusoidal waves with frequency 11–16 Hz (most commonly 12–14 Hz), with a duration ≥0.5 seconds, and usually maximal in amplitude in the central derivations.

**Begin scoring stage N2 if EITHER or BOTH of the following occur during the first half of the epoch or the last half of the previous epoch:**
*   One or more K complexes unassociated with arousals
*   One or more sleep spindles

## Wake
*   More than 50% of epoch-Alpha rhythm
*   Blinks, Rapid eye movements or Reading eye movements



## Stage N1
*   More than 50% of epoch-Alpha attenuation and replaced by theta(4-7Hz)
*   Slowing of background frequency by 1-2Hz
*   Slow eye movements
*   Vertex sharp waves



## Stage N2
*   K complexes and sleep spindles
*   K complexes with arousal shouldn't be scored as N2
*   Continued as N2 unless there is a change in EEG

# Scoring N3 sleep

*   **Slow wave activity**: Waves of frequency 0.5 Hz–2 Hz and peak-to-peak amplitude >75 µV, measured over the frontal regions referenced to the contralateral ear or mastoid (F4-M1, F3-M2).
*   Score stage N3 when ≥20% of an epoch consists of slow wave activity irrespective of age.

# Scoring REM

*   **Rapid eye movements (REMs):** Eye movements recorded in the EOG derivations consisting of conjugate, irregular, sharply peaked eye movements with an initial deflection usually lasting <500 msec.
*   **Low chin EMG tone:** Baseline EMG activity in the chin derivation no higher than in any other sleep stage and usually at the lowest level of the entire recording.
*   **Sawtooth waves:** An EEG pattern consisting of trains of sharply contoured or triangular, often serrated, 2–6 Hz waves maximal in amplitude over the central head regions and often, but not always, preceding a burst of rapid eye movements.
*   **Transient muscle activity:** Short irregular bursts of EMG activity usually with duration <0.25 seconds superimposed on low EMG tone.

---

<!-- Page 122 -->



# Scoring REM

Score stage R sleep in epochs with ALL of the following phenomena (definite stage R):
* **Low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG activity** without K complexes or sleep spindles
* **Low chin EMG tone** for most of the epoch and concurrent with REMs
* **REMs** at any position within the epoch

# Scoring Cardiac events

*   **Sinus Tachycardia:** > 90 bpm for adults
*   **Sinus Bradycardia:** < 40 bpm 6 years & up
*   **Asystole:** > 3 seconds 6 years & up
*   **Wide Complex Tachycardia:** Rhythm lasting a minimum of 3 consecutive beats at a rate > 100 bpm with QRS duration of less than 120 msec.
*   **Narrow Complex Tachycardia:** Rhythm lasting a minimum of 3 consecutive beats at a rate > 100 bpm with QRS duration of more than 120 msec.
*   **Atrial Fibrillation:** irregularly irregular ventricular rhythm associated with replacement of consistent P waves by rapid oscillations that vary in size, shape and timing.

---

<!-- Page 131 -->



# Scoring Periodic Limb Movements In Sleep (PLMS)

1. The following define a candidate leg movement (LM) event for possible inclusion in a PLMS series: RECOMMENDED
   a. The duration of the LM event is 0.5–10 seconds.
   b. The minimum amplitude of a LM event is an 8 µV increase in EMG voltage above resting EMG for at least 0.5 seconds.
   c. The timing of the onset of a LM event is defined as the point at which there is an 8 µV increase in EMG voltage above resting EMG.
   d. The timing of the ending of a LM event is defined as the start of a period lasting at least 0.5 seconds during which the EMG does not exceed 2 µV above resting EMG.
   e. A portion of, or the entire, LM event occurs in an epoch scored as sleep.

2. The following define a PLMS series: RECOMMENDED
   a. The minimum number of consecutive LM events needed to define a PLMS series is 4 LMs.
   b. The period length between LMs (defined as the time between onsets of consecutive LMs) to include them as part of a PLMS series is 5–90 seconds.
   c. Leg movements on 2 different legs separated by <5 seconds between movement onsets are counted as a single leg movement. The period length to the next LM following this group of LMs is measured from the onset of the first LM to the onset of the next. (see Figure 6)



## VII. Movement Rules

Figure 6. The first two LMs are counted as one leg movement since the time from onset to onset of the LMs in the left anterior tibial EMG channel (LAT) and right anterior tibial EMG channel (RAT) is less than 5 seconds. The period length to the next LM is measured from the onset of the first LM in the group considered to be a single LM.

# Multiple sleep latency test

**AASM protocol**
*   Adequate sleep- documented
*   PSG should precede MSLT
*   Should atleast be for 6 hours for the MSLT to be valid
*   To minimize confounding effects of sleep deprivation on MSLT

**Method**
*   1.5-3 hours after PSG in a sleep-inducing environment
*   Monitoring with all channels
*   Nap session- Latency noted, Continued for 15 mins to note REM sleep

Positive Airway Pressure Titration Task Force of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine

Task Force Members: Clete A. Kushida, M.D., Ph.D., RPSGT (Chair)¹; Alejandro Chediak, M.D. (Vice-Chair)²; Richard B. Berry, M.D.³; Lee K. Brown, M.D.⁴; David Gozal, M.D.⁵; Conrad Iber, M.D.⁶; Sairam Parthasarathy, M.D.⁷; Stuart F. Quan, M.D.⁸; James A. Rowley, M.D.⁹

Figure 2—CPAP Titration Algorithm for Patients ≥12 years During Full- or Split-Night Titration Studies. Note: Upward titration at ≥1-cm increments over ≥5-min periods is continued according to the breathing events observed until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved.

**CPAP Titration Algorithm:**

1.  **Initial Pressure:** Begin at a minimum of 4 cm H₂O.

2.  **Upward Titration (over ≥ 5 min periods):**
    *   Increase CPAP pressure by ≥ 1 cm H₂O if any of the following breathing events occur:
        *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas
        *   ≥ 3 hypopneas
        *   ≥ 5 RERAs (Respiratory Effort-Related Arousals)
        *   ≥ 3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring

3.  **Maximum Pressure:** The recommended maximum pressure is 20 cm H₂O.

4.  **Achieving Control:**
    *   Continue upward titration until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved.
    *   This leads to "Control of breathing events and ≥ 15 min in supine REM sleep."

5.  **Handling Specific Situations:**
    *   **Transition to BPAP:** The patient may be transitioned to BPAP if there are continued breathing events at 15 cm H₂O. This may involve "Exploration of pressure."
    *   **Patient Discomfort:** If the patient awakens and complains pressure is too high:
        *   A lower pressure that the patient reports is comfortable enough to allow return to sleep should be chosen.
        *   Resume titration from this comfortable pressure.

6.  **Stopping Titration:**
    *   If, after achieving control, breathing events re-emerge (e.g., after a pressure increase of ≥ 1 cm H₂O for ≥ 10 min), stop the titration.

---

*   A higher starting CPAP may be selected for patients with an elevated BMI and for retitration studies.
*   The patient should also be tried on BPAP if the patient is uncomfortable or intolerant of high CPAP.

# Figure 4—BPAP Titration Algorithm for Patients ≥12 years During Full- or Split-Night Titration Studies.



## BPAP Titration Algorithm (Pressure vs. Time)

**Recommended maximum IPAP:** 30 cm H₂O

**"Exploration" of IPAP:**

1.  **Start IPAP at ≥ 5 cm H₂O.**
    *   **If ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved:**
        *   Proceed to **Control of breathing events and ≥ 15 min in supine REM sleep.**
        *   Then, if **IPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O** is maintained for **≥ 10 min**, continue with another **IPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O** step.
        *   **Stop if re-emergence of breathing events.**

2.  **If breathing events occur (or 30 min without events is not achieved):**
    *   **Increase IPAP and EPAP by ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas, or IPAP by ≥ 1 cm for other events.**
    *   **Check for events over ≥ 5 min:**
        *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas, or
        *   ≥ 3 hypopneas, or
        *   ≥ 5 RERAs, or
        *   ≥ 2 (3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring)
    *   **If these events persist, repeat the titration step:**
        *   **Increase IPAP and EPAP by ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas, or IPAP by ≥ 1 cm for other events.**
        *   **Check for events over ≥ 5 min:**
            *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas, or
            *   ≥ 3 hypopneas, or
            *   ≥ 5 RERAs, or
            *   ≥ 2 (3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring)
        *   **Patient Comfort Branch:** If patient awakens and complains pressure is too high, a lower IPAP that the patient reports is comfortable enough to allow return to sleep should be chosen, and resume titration.
    *   **Minimum\* settings:** IPAP 6 / EPAP 4 cm H₂O



## Notes

Note: Upward titration of IPAP and EPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas and IPAP ≥ 1 cm for other events over ≥ 5-min periods is continued until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved. A decrease in IPAP or setting BPAP in spontaneous-timed mode with backup rate may be helpful if treatment-emergent central apneas are observed.

*   A higher starting IPAP and EPAP may be selected for patients with an elevated BMI and for retitration studies. When transitioning from CPAP to BPAP, the minimum starting EPAP should be set at 4 cm H₂O or the CPAP level at which obstructive apneas were eliminated. An optimal minimum IPAP-EPAP differential is 4 cm H₂O and an optimal maximum IPAP-EPAP differential is 10 cm H₂O.

---

<!-- Page 170 -->



## Grading system:

**A good titration** reduces the overnight RDI ≤10 per hour or by 50% if the baseline RDI <15 per hour and should include supine REM sleep that is not continually interrupted by spontaneous arousals or awakenings at the selected pressure (Consensus).

**An adequate titration** is one that does not reduce the overnight RDI ≤10 per hour but does reduce the RDI by 75% from baseline (especially in severe OSA patients), or one in which the titration grading criteria for optimal or good are met with the exception that supine REM sleep did not occur at the selected pressure (Consensus).

**An unacceptable titration** is one that does not meet any one of the above grades (Consensus).

# Leaks

Leakage can occur in several forms.

**Intentional leak** is the controlled leak from the port on mask interfaces that washes out CO2 and prevents rebreathing.

**Unintentional leak** is characterized as a "mouth leak" (i.e., pressurized air escaping via the mouth when a nasal mask is used) or "mask leak" between the mask and the face (i.e., pressurized air escaping between the mask and the face when a nasal mask or full-face/oronasal mask is used).

**Unintentional leak** can be minimized by mask refit or readjustment, and, in the case of "mouth leak", addition of a chinstrap to reduce mouth opening or switching to a full-face/oronasal mask may be beneficial.

It showed improved oxygenation, decreased arousal index, and increased REM sleep when this leak was minimized.

---

<!-- Page 176 -->



# Leaks

*   Leak is an important factor that must be compensated for.
*   Affects aspects of performance including pressure delivered, cycle and trigger thresholds, and respiratory event determination.
*   If leak is high, auto devices may compensate by lowering the pressure, which may seal the mask and reduce leak.
*   Leak should be under 24 L/min in nasal masks and under 36 L/min in full face masks.

*   It is also possible to identify device failure

# Complications of PAP therapy

*   Nocturnal arousals
*   Rhinitis, nasal irritation, dryness
*   Aerophagia
*   Mask & mouth leaks
*   Facial rashes / irritation
*   Nasal irritation and rhinitis are treated with heated humidification and use of a nasal steroid spray.
*   Claustrophobia - relieved in some cases by changing the type of mask.
*   Aerophagia can be tackled by altering body position or mask type

| Asymptomatic (e.g. bed partner notices snoring, atrial fibrillation) | AHI > 15                                          | Equipoise       |
|                             | AHI < 15                                          | No?             |



## How endotypes may guide treatment

| Endotypes                                   | Condition / Measurement                       | Treatment / Recommendation                                  |
| :------------------------------------------ | :-------------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------- |
| Mild upper airway collapsibility            | PAP level < 8 cm H$_2$O*                      | Consider OA, HGNS; weight loss if indicated                 |
| Severe upper airway collapsibility          | BMI < 25 with obvious airway abnormality      | Surgical management                                         |
|                                             | Overweight/obese                              | PAP therapy, weight management*                             |
| Ventilatory control instability (high loop gain) | Concentric collapse seen on DISE*             | Not a candidate for HGNS therapy                            |
|                                             | Central apneas on baseline study              | Not a candidate for HGNS therapy                            |
| Low respiratory arousal threshold           | AHI, fraction hypopneas, O$_2$ nadir*         | PAP therapy, and short-term sedative hypnotic, if needed* |

# Precision sleep medicine



## Case scenario 1-

A woman in her early fifties with obesity and high BP presents with concern for sleep-maintenance insomnia. Her unattended at-home sleep study shows frequent obstructive respiratory events of short duration, usually associated with arousals. Oxygen desaturation is rare. The sleep clinician counsels her on the natural course of her sleep-disordered breathing and the expected cognitive, mood, and cardiovascular outcomes. There was low arousal threshold and high loop gain in the sleep study report.

How would you treat this patient?

---

<!-- Page 199 -->

A combination therapy of acetazolamide and eszopiclone prescribed
The patient asks about CPAP therapy or an oral appliance? – Clinician advises against it

This hypothetical, near-future case evokes the dream of precision sleep medicine, a diagnostic and therapeutic approach to disentangle a given patient's OSA from the disorder's broad heterogeneity.

---

<!-- Page 200 -->



# Therapeutic strategies for patients with OSA

*   Behavioral
*   medical
    *   CPAP
    *   Non PAP options
*   Surgical

Dr. Bharath Kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 201 -->

Patient education : Behavioural Upper Airway
*   Avoid alcohol, sedatives and hypnotics (↑severity of UA obstruction)
*   Alcohol ↓ UA muscle tone, and increases the frequency of respiratory events during sleep.

Weight reduction
*   Excess weight increases the risk for upper airway collapse - higher extraluminal pressures associated with excess soft tissue and/or fat and the encroachment of the tongue and soft palate.✓
*   Studies show that a 10% weight loss was associated with a 26% decrease in AHI.✓

---

<!-- Page 202 -->



# Bariatric surgery:

*   Bariatric surgery is an effective means to achieve **major weight loss** and is indicated in individuals with
    *   BMI $\geq 40 \text{ kg/m}^2$ or
    *   BMI $\geq 35 \text{ kg/m}^2$ with (HTN, DM, OSA) and in whom dietary calorie reduction have been ineffective.
*   The **restrictive procedures** have the intention to restrict food intake by **reducing the total stomach capacity**, such as **gastric banding**, the **gastric balloon** and **gastric sleeve resection** (gastroplasty).
*   A **malabsorptive procedure** is the biliopancreatic derivation technique, also called the **Scopinaro technique** but can cause **severe malabsorption**.
*   Currently, the **Roux-en-Y gastric bypass** is the most commonly done, and combines restrictive and malabsorptive effects.

---

<!-- Page 203 -->

**Positional treatment:**
* Conservative treatment strategies recommend lateral sleeping position. Its observed that the frequency of apnoea and hypopnoea is greater with a supine sleeping position.
* Suggested for OSAS patients with an AHI in the supine posture that is double or greater than that in the non supine postures.
* This therapy could also be advisable for patients who did not succeed with CPAP, an oral device or any surgical treatment, and have breathing abnormalities in the supine posture.
* Also, suitable for patients without OSA but snoring confined mainly to the supine posture.

---

<!-- Page 204 -->

Different methods have been designed for positional therapy:
verbal instructions,
the classical tennis ball technique,
the positional alarm,
- a triangular pillow with space to place an arm and a soft vest attached to a board placed under the pillow.
A small individual cohort study investigated the effects of elevating the upper body by 60 degree and found a moderate reduction of AHI.

---

<!-- Page 205 -->

Oral devices:
*   It includes mandibular advancement devices (MADs) and tongue-retaining devices.
*   It aim to increase the UA size and reduce the risk of sleep apnoeas and snoring in patients with OSAS.
*   work by advancing the mandible
    *   opening the airway by repositioning the lower jaw and pulling the tongue forward.

---

<!-- Page 206 -->



# Utility

*   Useful in patients with primary snoring, or those with mild to moderate OSA who prefer an oral appliance to CPAP or
    *   do not respond to, or fail treatment attempts with CPAP.
*   A recent study identified phenotypic characteristics including
    *   lower age, female sex, lower BMI, smaller neck circumference, lower AHI, a retracted maxilla and mandible, a narrower airway and a shorter soft palate $\rightarrow$ a good response to oral appliance therapy

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAOI FDARM

---

<!-- Page 207 -->

The appliances are worn `only during sleep` and are
`generally well tolerated`.
Limitations: dependence on `oral health`
✓time to `become accustomed` to the device.
Side effects : `pain` in the teeth and jaws,
generally can be [Tolerated]

---

<!-- Page 208 -->



# Surgery of the UA:

Patients unable to tolerate or adhere to CPAP therapy can turn to surgical options as a salvage treatment.
Surgery can also be considered as a first-line treatment in mild OSA and in patients with moderate to-severe disease for whom other noninvasive treatments have failed.
It aims to correct anatomical abnormalities in the UA, contributing to its collapse during sleep.
A discussion between the surgeon and the anaesthesiologist about the pre- and postoperative airway management is required.
The results of surgical procedures for OSAS should be objectively documented by PSG 3-6 months post-operatively.

---

<!-- Page 209 -->



## SURGERY IN OSA

*   UPPP reduces upper airway obstruction by shortening the uvula, trimming the **soft palate**, and suturing back the anterior and posterior pharyngeal pillars
    *   Uvulopalato Pharyngoplasty
*   Maxillomandibular advancement osteotomy advances the **maxilla** and **mandible** to enlarge the **retrolingual** and **retropalatal spaces**
*   Adenotonsillectomy is the first-line treatment in children
*   Electrical stimulation of the **genioglossus** with an implanted pacemaker

Dr. Sharath Kirth MD DNB, DNB (FSCM) (DNB)

# Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty

Dr Bharath Kathi

*   Upper airway surgery for OSAHS is less effective than CPAP and is mostly reserved for the treatment of patients who snore, have mild OSAHS, or cannot tolerate CPAP.
*   Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (removal of the uvula and the margin of the soft palate) is the most common surgery
*   Upper airway surgery is less effective in severe OSAHS and in obese patients

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 212 -->



# Hypoglossal nerve stimulation or HNS

(Image description: A diagram showing a person lying down with an implanted device. A **Pulse Generator** is shown in the chest, connected to a **Breathing Sensor** also in the chest, and a **Stimulation electrode** near the tongue. A remote-controlled device is shown on a table next to the person.)

*   The genioglossus muscle is the **largest airway dilator** muscle. Electrical stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve causes **tongue protrusion** and **stiffening of the anterior pharyngeal wall**.
*   This device is implanted in the chest.
*   An upper airway stimulation device sends an **electrical signal to the hypoglossal nerve** → nudges the tongue to move forward and prevents the tongue from blocking the air passage.
*   Used in **moderate or severe OSA unable to tolerate positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy**.

remote controlled device turned on during sleep

In a large, multicenter, prospective, single-group cohort study of carefully selected patients, **HGNS** was associated with **improvements in AHI** (decreased by 68%), oxygen desaturation index (ODI; decreased by 70%), **subjective sleepiness measured by Epworth Sleepiness Scale**, and quality of life, as well as with high adherence (84%).

---

<!-- Page 213 -->



# DRUGS IN OSA

*   Paroxetine (40 mg), Serotonin reuptake inhibitor tried in OSA but had no impact on AHI compared with placebo, in severe OSA.
*   There was a positive impact on respiratory events in non-REM, but not REM, sleep and no improvement in daytime symptoms.
*   Stimulants such as modafinil can be utilized as adjunctive therapy for residual sleepiness in patients who remain excessively sleepy despite adequate treatment for SDB.
*   Doses ranging from 200 to 400 mg daily have been shown to be effective in improving excessive daytime sleepiness in several randomized trials

Currently no drug is actively recommended as a treatment option in OSA. Pharmaceutical agents might reduce sleep apnoea by increasing respiratory drive, changing sleep structure (in particular, suppressing REM sleep), increasing upper airway muscle tone etc

# EVENTS
(CSA x HF)

*   With the onset of sleep, withdrawal of the wakefulness stimulus occurs and the chemical drive to breathe predominates.
*   Central apneas occur if the arterial PCO2 falls below the “apneic threshold,” or PCO2 level necessary to maintain rhythmic breathing
*   If the magnitude of the increase in ventilation that occurs in response to changes in PCO2 is larger than is needed to achieve eupnea, self-sustaining oscillations in ventilation in which PCO2 is repeatedly driven to the apneic threshold can occur and manifest as periodic breathing
*   Such oscillations in ventilation can also occur when there is a lag between changes in ventilation and detection of the ensuing effects on PCO2 and PO2 by the central and peripheral chemoreceptors, as occurs when arterial circulation time increases. - Happum in CHF
*   Recurrent arousals from sleep can also play an important role in initiating and maintaining central apneas as the state change from sleep to wakefulness re-engages the neurogenic drive to breathe. This can provoke ventilatory overshoot → and help to sustain oscillations in respiration.

ENDOBRONCHIAL TUBERCULOSIS

---

<!-- Page 2 -->

> Endobronchial Tuberculosis is the manifestation of tubercular infection in the mucosa and submucosa of the tracheobronchial tree.
> Infrequently reported until the advent of bronchoscopy



## EPIDEMIOLOGY

> Reported in 10%-20% of patients with active TB (based on bronchoscopic studies)
> Current prevalence rate as low as 0.18% in TB non endemic areas.
> Age : 21-40 years of age, similar prevalence in geriatric population
> Female preponderance [d/t voluntarily suppression of cough socio-cultural, cosmetic issues ,Small airways ]
> *may be because their airways are small & also d/t social stigma, many try to suppress their cough*

---

<!-- Page 3 -->



# Mechanisms of Endobronchial Infection

1.  **Extension from the Lungs by Direct Infiltration:**
    tracheobronchial ulceration is more commonly seen adjacent to areas of extensive and progressive parenchymal TB
2.  **Implantation of Organisms from Infected Sputum:**
    The finding of endobronchial disease on the wall of bronchi opposite the opening of a diseased lobe is likely due to the implantation from infected material passing over the mucous membrane
3.  **Haematogenous Dissemination**
    Uncommon
4.  **Lymphatic Spread:**
    retrograde passage of the tubercle bacilli through lymphatics from bronchioles and subsegmental bronchi to the main stem bronchus
5.  **As Part of the Primary Infection:**
    Lymph node eroding into a bronchus.
    - predominantly seen in children relatively uncommon in adults

Dr. Bharath Kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

*   Bronchiectasis distal to stenosis

<!-- Page 7 -->



## PRESENTATION

In adults, it may occur in primary or Reactivation TB.
In children, usually a complication of primary TB.

*   ACUTE: Resp. failure need MV
*   SUB ACUTE: mimics asthma, pneumonia, FB aspiration
*   INSIDIOUS: mimics lung cancer



### Symptoms
*   Barking cough, Dyspnoea, Chest pain
*   Fever
*   Generalised weakness,
*   Wt loss and haemoptysis
*   Sputum production variable; [None to copious]
*   None → Bronchorrhea [>500 mL/day]

? TB

## PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: diminished breath sounds OR localised wheeze

---

<!-- Page 8 -->

COMPLICATIONS

*   Bronchial stenosis most significant complication: presents with slowly progressive SOB years after the diagnosis and treatment
*   Respiratory failure
*   Difficult endotracheal intubation, & Need for tracheostomy
*   Death by suffocation may occur {consequence of tracheal stenosis}
*   Concomitant intestinal and laryngeal involvement with TB

---

<!-- Page 9 -->



# INVESTIGATIONS

**Sputum Exam:**
*   *Low yield* [**15%-20%**]
*   May be because *expectoration of sputum is difficult* due to mucus entrapment by proximal bronchial granulation tissue

**Chest Radiograph**
*   > coexisting **extensive pul. parenchymal** or intrathoracic LN infection.
*   > **10%-20% normal CXR**

**CT chest**
*   ✓ show **endobronchial involvement** of *large, medium and small airways* (**more seen**).
*   ✓ Findings on CT in small airways may include:
    *   poorly defined nodules,
    *   **centrilobular nodules**
    *   bronchial wall thickening
    *   **tree-in-bud appearance** (D/D miliary TB)

**Bronchoscopy**
*   ✓ **Bronchoscopy**
*   ✓ **Gold standard for the diagnosis**
*   ✓ **Endobronchial biopsies/BAL**, Bronchial brushings, Cryobiopsy

**Additional Note:**
EB Biopsy tissue +ve in m/tb

## DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS

1.  Bronchial asthma
2.  Foreign body aspiration in children.
3.  Endobronchial mass, malignancy
4.  TB coexisting with malignancy
5.  Atypical mycobacterium
6.  Sarcoidosis
7.  Actinomycosis
8.  Papillomatosis
9.  Previous endotracheal intubation, or
10. Crohn's disease and Behçet's syndrome
11. Wegener's granulomatosis,
12. Relapsing polychondritis,
13. Tracheobronchopathia osteochondroplastica,
14. Amyloidosis,
15. Papillomatosis,
16. Rhinoscleroma
17. Anthracofibrosis

<!-- Page 11 -->



## TREATMENT

*   A high clinical index of suspicion and prompt bronchoscopy are essential for the early diagnosis
*   ~~1.~~ Anti-TB Treatment : for 6 months (2HRZE + 4HRE)
*   2. Corticosteroids : have been used empirically with anti-TB medications.
*   USEFUL to prevent bronchial stenosis ( small study )
*   As of now, there is not enough evidence to suggest routine use of corticosteroids in endobronchial TB

Bronchoscopic Modalities:
STENOSIS

1.  **Mechanical Dilatation**: barrel of a **rigid bronchoscope** use of dilators, balloons [**balloon bronchoplasty**]

2.  **Debulking** of tissue obstructing the airway using a rigid bronchoscope to core the tissue.

3.  **Thermal Debulking Using**
    *   **Electrocautery**, **Argon Plasma Coagulation**, **Laser**
    *   (TO prevent bleeding peripherally)

4.  **Bronchoscopic Cryotherapy**: (cold therapy)
    *   **comparatively safe** as the fibrous tissue and cartilage (cryoresistant)
    *   Minimising the risk of airway **Perforation**
    *   Helpful in achieving **haemostasis**
    *   No risk of airway fires.

5.  **Airway stents**: placed in the airways to **maintain patency** of the airway.
    *   The stents also support **weakened cartilage** and can also **close a airway fistula due to TB**
    *   Three main types of stents are available: (**metal stents**, **silicon stents** and **hybrid stents**) [covered metal stents].

Silicon stent

<!-- Page 13 -->



## Surgery

*   Done when no longer considered to have active disease
*   For lesions involving lobar or segmental bronchi, lobectomy may need to be performed.
*   For lesion involving the trachea or main stem bronchus bronchoplastic surgery along with lobectomy [if needed] is performed.
*   Pneumonectomy (Entire Lung) should be left as the last resort when the involved lung has extensive bronchiectasis/damage from recurrent infections
*   Restenosis at the site of anastomosis may occur and repeated bronchoscopic dilatation may be needed

Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) is a homeostatic mechanism that is intrinsic to the pulmonary vasculature.
Intrapulmonary arteries constrict in response to alveolar hypoxia, diverting blood to better-oxygenated lung segments, thereby optimizing ventilation/perfusion matching and systemic oxygen delivery.

The mechanism of hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. Hypoxia causes closure of voltage-gated potassium channel leading to K+ accumulation intracellularly. It leads to depolarization of the cells, opening of voltage-gated calcium channel and calcium-mediated pulmonary vasoconstriction.

*   Hoarseness (dysphonia): compression of the left laryngeal recurrent nerve (cardiovocal or Ortner's syndrome)

## Signs of PH
* Central, peripheral, or mixed cyanosis
* Accentuated pulmonary component of the second heart sound
* RV third heart sound
* Systolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
* Diastolic murmur of pulmonary regurgitation



## Signs of RV backward failure
* Distended and pulsating jugular veins
* Abdominal distension
* Hepatomegaly
* Ascites
* Peripheral oedema

pulm vena occlusive d.



## Signs pointing towards underlying cause of PH
* Digital clubbing: Cyanotic CHD, fibrotic lung disease, bronchiectasis, PVOD, or liver disease
* Differential clubbing/cyanosis: PDA/Eisenmenger's syndrome
* Auscultatory findings (crackles or wheezing, murmurs): lung or heart disease
* Sequelae of DVT, venous insufficiency: CTEPH
* Telangiectasia: HHT or SSc (pulm htn, telangiectasia)
* Sclerodactyly, Raynaud's phenomenon, digital ulceration, GORD: SSc (pulm htn, SSc do.)



## Signs of RV forward failure
* Peripheral cyanosis (blue lips and tips)
* Dizziness
* Pallor
* Cool extremities
* Prolonged capillary refill

# Cardiac Catheterization

Right heart cardiac catheterization is required to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension

measurement of the left ventricular end diastolic pressure (LVEDP) is important to exclude left atrial hypertension

A diagnosis of PAH requires a mean pulmonary artery pressure greater than or equal to 25 mm Hg, an adequately measured PAWP or a directly recorded LVEDP of less than or equal to 15 mm Hg

The PVR = (mean PA pressure - PCWP)/CO.

# Collagen Vascular diseases:

*   ILD is more common cause of PAH
*   Drugs that are efficacious in PAH have not proven effective in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension that accompanies interstitial lung disease
*   Among patients with systemic sclerosis, PAH occurs most commonly in those with limited disease or the CREST syndrome.
*   ✓The prognosis of patients with scleroderma is worse when their disease is complicated by PAH than by pulmonary fibrosis, even when the latter is severe

## Drugs and Toxins:

1.  Anorectic Agents— *Aminorex* and *Fenfluramine* Derivative
    *The pathology produced by aminorex in humans was identical with that of IPAH, including plexiform lesions and intimal fibrosis.*
    *They cause PAH by altering blood levels of serotonin (S-Hτ)*
    *These agents cause the release of serotonin from storage in platelets and inhibit its reuptake*
2.  Toxic Oil Syndrome: *rapeseed oil adulterated with aniline-*
    *outbreak of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema*

<!-- Page 37 -->



# Pulmonary Venoocclusive Disease (PVOD)

a rare form of PAH
Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (PVOD) is characterized by extensive venous involvement, including obstruction of pulmonary venules and veins by loose, fibrous remodeling of the intima that may totally occlude the lumen, in addition to arterial changes.

✓ The diagnosis of PVOD is suggested by the triad of pulmonary hypertension, radiographic evidence of pulmonary edema, and a normal PAWP.
    *T:: no Left heart ds*
Biopsy required but very risky
Lung transplantation is the only therapeutic option for many patients

---

<!-- Page 38 -->



## Pulmonary Capillary Hemangiomatosis

Another rare form of PAH with predominant involvement of the pulmonary veins.
“*Pulmonary microvasculopathy*” marked by angioproliferative capillary lesions that appear to invade the pulmonary vessels, interstitium, and in some cases the airways
Etiology is Unknown

# A Cautionary Note: Non-PAH Forms of Pulmonary Hypertension

PAH is but one form of pulmonary hypertension
The use of drugs approved for treatment of PAH in patients with other forms of pulmonary hypertension has not been found to be beneficial
In Patients with COPD and echocardiographic evidence of pulmonary hypertension found use of Bosentan worsened hypoxemia and quality of life, and failed to improve exercise capacity.

Recommendation Table 22 — Recommendations for pulmonary hypertension associated with left heart



## 2022 ESC/ERS Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary hypertension



### Recommendation Table 22A

| Recommendations | Class\* | Level\* |
|---|---|---|
| In patients with LHD, optimizing treatment of the underlying condition is recommended before considering assessment of suspected PH$^{37,38}$. | I | A |
| RHC is recommended for suspected PH in patients with LHD, if it aids management decisions. | I | C |
| RHC is recommended in patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation with or without LHD prior to surgical or interventional valve repair. | I | C |
| For patients with LHD and suspected PH with features of a severe pre-capillary component and/or markers of RV dysfunction, referral to a PH centre for a complete diagnostic work-up is recommended$^{29,47,142}$. | I | C |
| In patients with LHD and CpcPH with a severe pre-capillary component (e.g. PVR >5 WU), an individualized approach to treatment is recommended. | I | C |
| When patients with PH and multiple risk factors for LHD, who have a normal PAWP at rest but an abnormal response to exercise or fluid challenge, are treated with PAH drugs, close monitoring is recommended. | IIb | C |
| In patients with PH at RHC, a borderline PAWP (13–15 mmHg) and features of HFpEF, additional testing with exercise or fluid challenge may be considered to uncover post-capillary PH$^{13,143}$. | IIb | C |
| Drugs approved for PAH are not recommended in PH-LHD. | III | A |



### Recommendations

| Recommendations | Quality of evidence | Strength of recommendation | Class\* | Level\* |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| No recommendation can be given for or **against** the use of PDE5is in patients with HFpEF and combined post- and pre-capillary PH. | Low | None | - | - |
| The use of PDE5is in patients with HFpEF and isolated post-capillary PH is not recommended. | Low | Conditional | III | C |

ESC/ERS 2022

## 8.3.1.1. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Patients with HFrEF or HFmrEF require guideline-directed treatment including established medical and interventional therapies.27
In patients with advanced HFrEF, implanting an LVAD may significantly reduce or even normalize mPAP,675 although this is not achieved in all patients,676 and an increased DPG emerged as a negative prognostic factor after LVAD implantation.677 With regards to PAH drugs, bosentan was assessed in an RCT of patients with PH associated with HFrEF,678 showing no efficacy but an increase in adverse events compared with placebo, predominantly related to fluid retention. Small studies have suggested that sildenafil may improve haemodynamics and exercise capacity in PH and HFrEF,679–681 but RCTs are lacking.



## 8.3.1.2. Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
tors were assessed in two small RCTs in patients with HFpEF and PH with distinct haemodynamic characteristics. In patients with a predominantly IpcPH profile, sildenafil had no effect on mPAP (primary endpoint) or other haemodynamic and clinical measures vs. placebo.685 In patients with a predominantly CpcPH profile, sildenafil improved haemodynamics, RV function, and quality of life at 6 and 12 months vs. placebo.686 Furthermore, retrospective analyses and registry data suggested improvements in exercise capacity with PDE5i therapy in patients with HFpEF-associated CpcPH and with a severe pre-capillary component (PVR mostly >5 WU).450,687

# Sotatercept

*   Acts by rebalancing between <u>pro and anti proliferative pathways</u> and thereby altering the <u>vascular remodeling</u> seen in PAH
*   Novel 1st in class fusion protein comprising of extracellular domain of Activin receptor linked to Fc domain of human IgG1
*   In animal models inhibited cell proliferation, promoted apoptosis, and alleviated inflammation in the vessel walls, leading to reverse remodeling and restoration of vessel patency

**Pulmonary arterial hypertension**

*   **Antiproliferative Pathway:**
    *   Extracellular BMPs (Bone Morphogenetic Proteins) interact with BMPR-II (Bone Morphogenetic Protein Receptor Type II) and ALK (Activin Receptor-Like Kinase) 1/2/3/6 receptors.
    *   BMPR-II is indicated as impaired (marked with an 'X').
    *   This signaling leads to intracellular pSmad1/5/8 and Smad4 activation.
    *   Extracellular Gremlin-1 and noggin are shown as inhibitors.

ABSTRACT

Treatment with inhaled treprostinil improved exercise capacity through the end of the 16-week treatment period.
In addition, it was associated with a lower risk of clinical worsening, a reduction in NT-proBNP levels, and fewer exacerbations of underlying lung disease.

## **Risk severity recommendations**

*   It is recommended to evaluate disease severity in patients with PAH. CLASS I
*   Achieving and maintaining a low-risk profile on optimized medical therapy is recommended. CLASS I
*   For <u>risk stratification</u> at the time of diagnosis, the use of a three-strata model (<u>low, intermediate, and high risk</u>) is recommended, taking into account all available data, including <u>haemodynamic</u>. CLASS I
*   For <u>risk stratification</u> during follow-up, the use of a <u>four-strata model (low, intermediate-low, intermediate-high, and high risk)</u> based on <u>WHO-FC, 6MWD, and BNP/NT-proBNP</u> is recommended. CLASS I

<!-- Page 84 -->



# Therapy- General measures and prevention

*   ✓ Physical activity and supervised rehabilitation. **CLASS I**
*   *Anticoagulant*- no recommendation for the same as no data.
*   Anticoagulation is not generally recommended in patients with PAH but may be considered on an individual basis **CLASS II**
*   ✓ Diuretics- Right HF is associated with systemic fluid retention, reduced renal blood flow, and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
*   Diuretic treatment is recommended in patients with PAH with signs of RV failure and fluid retention **CLASS I**

---

<!-- Page 85 -->

*   Immunization of patients with PAH against SARS-CoV-2, influenza, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is recommended. Class I
*   Long-term oxygen therapy is recommended in patients with PAH whose arterial blood oxygen pressure is 8 kPa (60 mmHg) (Measured on two occasions) CLASS I.
*   In the presence of iron-deficiency anemia, correction is recommended. CLASS I
*   The use of ACEIs, ARBs, ARNIs, SGLT-2is, beta-blockers, or ivabradine is not recommended in patients with PAH CLASS III.
*   In-flight oxygen administration is recommended for patients using oxygen or whose arterial blood oxygen pressure is 8 kPa (60 mmHg) at sea level CLASS I.
*   Women of childbearing potential with PAH are counseled at the time of diagnosis about the risks and uncertainties associated with becoming pregnant. CLASS I
*   As teratogenic potential has been reported in pre-clinical models for endothelin receptor antagonists and riociguat, these drugs are not recommended during pregnancy III B

<!-- Page 2 -->

# The End TB Strategy: 3 pillars and 4 principles

| VISION                                                              | A WORLD FREE OF TB - zero deaths, disease and suffering due to TB |
| :------------------------------------------------------------------ | :---------------------------------------------------------------- |
| GOAL                                                                | END THE GLOBAL TB EPIDEMIC                                        |
| **INDICATORS**                                                      | **MILESTONES**                                                    |
|                                                                     | **2020** | **2025** | **2030** | **2035** |
| Percentage reduction in the absolute number of TB deaths\* (compared with 2015 baseline) | 35%      | 75%      | 90%      | 95%      |
| Percentage reduction in the TB incidence rate (compared with 2015 baseline) | 20%      | 50%      | 80%      | 90%      |
| Percentage of TB-affected households facing catastrophic total costs due to TB^ (level in 2015 unknown) | 0%       | 0%       | 0%       | 0%       |

## PRINCIPLES

1.  Government stewardship and accountability, with monitoring and evaluation
2.  Strong coalition with civil society organizations and communities
3.  Protection and promotion of human rights, ethics and equity
4.  Adaptation of the strategy and targets at country level, with global collaboration

## PILLARS AND COMPONENTS

### 1. INTEGRATED, PATIENT-CENTRED CARE AND PREVENTION

A. Early diagnosis of TB including universal drug-susceptibility testing, and systematic screening of contacts and high-risk groups
B. Treatment of all people with TB including drug-resistant TB, and patient support
C. Collaborative TB/HIV activities, and management of comorbidities
D. Preventive treatment of persons at high risk, and vaccination against TB

### 2. BOLD POLICIES AND SUPPORTIVE SYSTEMS

E. Political commitment with adequate resources for TB care and prevention
F. Engagement of communities, civil society organizations, and public and private care providers
G. Universal health coverage policy, and regulatory frameworks for case notification, vital registration, quality and rational use of medicines, and infection control
H. Social protection, poverty alleviation and actions on other determinants of TB

### 3. INTENSIFIED RESEARCH AND INNOVATION

I. Discovery, development and rapid uptake of new tools, interventions and strategies
J. Research to optimize implementation and impact, and promote innovations

---

**Pillar 1:** Integrated, patient-centered TB care and prevention
**Pillar 2:** Bold policies and supportive systems
**Pillar 3:** Intensified research and innovation

# Strategies and Initiatives by the programme: NSP 2017-2025

**TB-FREE INDIA WITH ZERO DEATHS, DISEASE AND POVERTY DUE TO TB**



## PREVENT

**Strategies**
1.  TB Preventive Treatment and Programmatic management of Latent TB Infection
2.  Scale up TB - infection control measures at home, community, and health care facilities



## DETECT

**Strategies**
1.  Scale-up free, high sensitivity diagnostic tests and algorithms
2.  Intensify TB case finding efforts through a sector wide approach to cover all programmes within the MOHFW and other ministries



## TREAT

**Strategies**
1.  Strengthen treatment of DSTB
2.  Expand and strengthen treatment and management of DRTB
3.  Address TB in priority populations
4.  Strengthen and expand coverage of patient support mechanisms



## BUILD, STRENGTHEN, and SUSTAIN

*   Fully funded NSP
*   Multi sectoral collaboration
*   Human resource management
*   Governance and programme management mechanisms
*   Empowered and engaged communities
*   Advocacy and strategic communication
*   Research
*   Procurement and supply chain management
*   Surveillance, monitoring & evaluation
*   Private sector engagement
*   Digital information ecosystem
*   Technical assistance
*   Human rights and gender

Reference: NSP-2017-2025

---

<!-- Page 5 -->



# NTEP Aim, Objective, Vision & Strategy



## 01 AIM
interrupt the transmission,
reduce mortality and
prevent emergence of
drug resistance.



## 02 OBJECTIVE
Every facility should notify
patients diagnosed with
TB in public as well as in
private sector viz.,
chemists, labs, clinics etc.,



## 03 VISION
TB free State with Zero TB
deaths, Zero TB disease, and
Zero TB suffering and Zero
catastrophic costs on
patients and their families
affected with TB.



## 04 STRATEGY
1. TB Screening services in Mapped Key
   population/ Vulnerable Groups.
2. To perform doorstep screening by
   implementing sputum sample transportation
   from peripheries to nearest molecular
   testing facility.
3. Establishing referral linkages for diagnosis
   & treatment).

---

<!-- Page 6 -->

What is new in TB?

*   Change in definitions of Drug resistance
*   Universal Drug susceptibility regimen
*   Shorter Oral Bedaquiline regimen
*   Combined use of Bedaquiline and Delamanid
*   Bedaquiline in pediatric age group
*   TB preventive therapy for Contacts of Drug sensitive and Drug resistant TB
*   Implementation of TB services in private sector.

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



## Laboratory Diagnostic Tools for Microbiological confirmation of TB

Under the programme acceptable methods for microbiological diagnosis of TB are:



### Sputum Smear Microscopy
*   Ziehl-Neelsen Staining
*   Fluorescence staining



### Culture
*   Solid (Lowenstein Jensen) media (Backup)
*   Automated Liquid culture systems e.g. BACTEC MGIT 960, BacT Alert or Versatrek etc.



### LC&DST
*   Diagnosis by liquid culture
*   Drug Susceptibility testing using for MGIT 960 system



### Molecular diagnostic tests
*   Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) (CBNAAT/Truenat)
*   Line Probe Assay (LPA) for detection of RIF & INH resistance (FL LPA) and FQ & SLI resistance (SL LPA)

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



# Method of DRT & DST



## Xpert MTB/RIF
*   Cartridge based NAAT (CBNAAT)
*   Simultaneous detection of TB & RR-TB



## Xpert MTB/XDR
*   Follow on test to molecular test
*   Detect resistance towards H, FQ, SLI & Eto



## Truenat
*   Chip based, micro real time PCR-based NAAT
*   comes in Uno-, Duo-, and Quattro
*   Point of Care (POC) test



## Line Probe Assay
*   PCR & reverse hybridization
*   Interpreted based on development / absence of WT & MUT bands



## Solid culture
*   Discontinued due to longer turn around time
*   LJ slope is Inoculated as a backup for every MGIT culture



## Liquid culture
*   DST for first & second-line anti-TB drugs

    *   **Rif resistance not detected**
        *   (Proceed to "Second Sample at CDST lab" section)

    *   LC-DST-Z, BDQ, Dlm, Cfz, Mfx, Lzd
