Dated: 28th August, 2023

Subject: Policy guidelines for TB vaccine trials under NTEP - reg.

Madam/Sir,

The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has planned to introduce the Adult TB Immunization Study (ATIS) of BCG vaccine among vulnerable adult population as a relapsing TB disease, in a programmatic setting with the collaboration of National TB Elimination Programme, International Centre for TB Research (ICMR-NIRT), Chennai, ICMR-National Institute of Epidemiology (NIE), Chennai and Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI). The Adult BCG immunization trial has been envisaged to study its impact on Tuberculosis in a study mode in collaboration with ICMR-NIRT, Chennai.

2. ICMR-NIRT, Chennai has 7 (seven) sites for the Adult BCG immunization trial. The study will be conducted in a study mode in collaboration with ICMR-NIRT, Chennai and Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI).

3. The Adult BCG immunization will be conducted in a programmatic mode similar to Routine Immunization as per the approved protocol in the intervention section.

4. The states participating in the study will be provided trainings on the "Tuberculosis Immunization Guidelines" by MoHFW. MoHFW will provide all necessary support for the conduct of the study and implementation of the Adult BCG immunization trial.

5. This is issued with the approval of competent authority.

Sd/- Dr. Rajendra P. Joshi

# Adult BCG vaccination

*   BCG vaccine is one of the **oldest vaccines** first used in humans in 1921.
*   BCG vaccination became a part of the National **Tuberculosis Programme** (NTP) which started in 1962.
*   Under program implementation study it will be given to select sub cohort of the **adult i.e 18 years plus population** in select study geographies.
*   India launched **Expanded Programme of Immunization (EPI)** in 1978 with the introduction BCG, OPV, DPT and typhoid paratyphoid vaccines.
*   **Adult BCG is not a new vaccine.**

---

<!-- Page 55 -->

Indian studies on Adult BCG vaccination:
*   Re-analysis of the <mark style="background-color: #ADD8E6">Chingleput trial</mark>\* indicated that the BCG vaccination in a community offered modest protection with <mark style="background-color: #FFFF00">36%</mark> efficacy against the development of TB disease at the end of <mark style="background-color: #FFFF00">15 years</mark>.\*
*   Another study too among adults in India cited BCG revaccination to be <mark style="background-color: #FFFF00">immunogenic</mark>.\*\*

Sources:
\*Re-analyzing the Chingleput BCG vaccination trial for the impact of BCG revaccination on the incidence of tuberculosis, a cause. Indian J Med Res. 2023 Feb Mar 157(2&3):1-7.
\*\*Keesari S, Ahmed A, Adiga V, Sundaram M, Selvaraj N, Achimuthu L et al. BCG revaccination boosts adaptive immunological memory and unique effector cell states and IGRA-Indian adults. Sci Rep. 2019;9:10540.

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Rationale for Adult BCG vaccination, India

One of the modelling studies showed that besides accelerating current tools and practices, **17% decline per year in TB incidence can be achieved by introducing vaccine and new treatment regimens***✓
Current NTEP interventions : **2% annual decline** of TB incidence ✓
**Long treatment time and adherence** by the patients pose challenges for **TPT**.
Potential benefits of **BCG revaccination**, or 'boosting' beyond paediatric age group.
For these reasons, there has been increasing recognition of the need for an effective TB vaccine.

---

<!-- Page 57 -->



# BCG Vaccine

*   BCG only diluents to be used for BCG reconstitution
*   Freeze Dried powder
*   Sensitive to light and heat supplied in Amber colour bottle
*   Use only 0.1 ml AD syringe
*   Reconstitution syringe
*   Most sensitive to heat post reconstitution
*   VVM 14 BCG

VACCINE AND COLD CHAIN FOR ADULT BCG VACCINATION

Conducted by:

# Study title
Effect of BCG vaccination amongst vulnerable adult population on reducing TB disease: a programmatic study.



# Study design and objectives
Programmatic stratified cluster randomized parallel arm study

Objective
* To evaluate the effectiveness of a strategy to vaccinate vulnerable individuals older than 18 years with BCG vaccine under programmatic settings
* To determine the effectiveness of adult BCG vaccination against active tuberculosis with annual review.

---

<!-- Page 60 -->



# Study settings

A restricted randomization process followed for the study with -
50% of the NTEP districts of the consenting State/ UT are allocated to intervention arms and rest 50% of NTEP allocated to control arm.

24 states expressed consent for participation.

Out of 547 NTEP districts -
274 are in intervention arm

Study population: Inclusion criteria //BENEFICIARIES
The target population is individuals aged 18 years and above, meeting the following criteria:

1.  Past TB pts notified in last 5 years
2.  Age > 60 yrs
3.  Individuals with a self reported history of smoking tobacco (Current / Past User)-
4.  Close contacts of TB patients enrolled in Nikshay from 1st January 2021
5.  Individuals with history of Diabetes
6.  BMI < 18 Kg / m2 (Malnourished)

# Exclusion criteria

*   Age < 18 X
*   No consent X
*   HIV X

# Special consideration for Adult BCG vaccination

*   Individuals currently on ATT (Anti Tuberculosis Treatment) are NOT eligible for BCG vaccine. One can get adult BCG vaccine 4 weeks after completion of current treatment. (Handwritten: 4 weeks)
*   Sick and hospitalized individuals will be vaccinated after recovery and medical advise.
*   Individuals on TB Preventive Treatment (TPT) would be vaccinated 4 weeks after completion of TPT as per NTEP guidelines.
*   Individuals who received adult BCG vaccine and eligible for TPT to be provided TPT only after 4 weeks post vaccination.

CONTENT:
## (A) Information for the eligible beneficiary

**Greetings.**

(1) The Government of India has set a goal of TB elimination by 2025. BCG vaccination in vulnerable group of adults is an important intervention for potential reduction of new TB cases in the community. BCG vaccine has been historically given to newborn babies in India since 1978, and has proven to be a safe and effective vaccine in preventing severe forms of TB disease and related TB mortality in children. Since the immunity against TB reduces over a period, in order to boost the immunity and give protection against TB in adults, the Government of India is implementing this study. Under the National TB Elimination Programme, the government provides free diagnosis and treatment to all TB patients and is implementing several strategies for preventing TB disease. In order to achieve the national target of ending TB by 2025, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of India along with the State Governments / UTs has decided to give adult BCG vaccine to vulnerable individuals for further decreasing the risk of TB disease.

(2) Under this study, adult BCG vaccination is being offered to all adults over 60 years of age and all adults above 18 years of age with (a) history of TB in last 5 years, (b) close contacts of an active TB case, (c) Body Mass Index less than 18 KG/ meter square, (d) self-reported smokers (current/ past), (e) known case of Diabetes Mellitus.

(3) Under this study, adult BCG vaccination will not be offered to individuals who are (a) pregnancy / lactation, (b) currently on TB treatment / TB preventive treatment, (c) diseases like HIV/ cancer/ on immunosuppressant medications/ transplant recipient, (d) currently sick/ seriously ill/ bed ridden, (e) a history of blood transfusion in last 3 months, (f) a history of known allergy to BCG or any other vaccines, (g) high risk behaviors like intra-venous drug users, sex workers etc.

(4) BCG vaccine is overall safe with a few side effects such as papule, mild ulceration or scare (1 in 10 vaccinated individuals). However, in some individuals with compromised immunity like HIV-AIDS/ cancer/ on immunosuppressant medications/ transplant recipient, seriously ill/ bed ridden, a history of known allergy to BCG or any other vaccines may experience side-effects like, suppurative lymphadenitis (Uncommon to rare ie 1 in 1,000 to 10,000), disseminated BCG disease (very rare ie 1 in 2.3 lakh to 4 lakh), BCG osteitis (uncommon to rare ie 1 per 10 thousand to 1 lakh vaccinated), immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (very rare ie 1 per 6.4 lakhs).

(5) You have been identified as an eligible person for BCG vaccination, since you are above 18 years of age and because of your vulnerability for TB disease as per the above mentioned criteria. BCG vaccination can potentially benefit you by reducing your risk of getting TB disease in future.

Adult BCG vaccine is purely voluntary.

(6) Post vaccination, we will follow up with you every month for first 3 months and thereafter every 3 months till 3 years after the date of vaccination. During the follow up we will check for your wellness and look for any signs/ symptoms suggestive of TB and any side effects of vaccination. If required we will also offer you appropriate treatment and care free of cost.

(7) All your personal information will be kept confidential and will be shared only with the study team. In the process of this study, your Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA) number can be shared for purposes as may be notified by Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM) from time to time including provision of healthcare services.

(8) In case you do not want to get BCG vaccine, it is free and you will continue to receive all usual services by the public health system that you are entitled to. There will be no compensation provided after Adult BCG vaccination to you for your participation or an adverse event. However, if you experience any side effects, we will provide all necessary treatment and care "free of cost" in the nearest and appropriate government health facility.

(9) Your decision to accept or refuse BCG vaccine is completely voluntary. You can say "NO" to getting the BCG vaccine injection or withdraw from the study without giving any reason. If you agree, you will be given an injection in the right upper arm. You will only feel a slight pinch. You will be able to continue with your routine work after injection. If you have any discomfort any time after the injection, please contact us or your nearest public health facility.

If you have any questions, please ask and we will try to answer all of them.



## (B) Undertaking by the beneficiary

*   I have been explained the above information including the potential benefits and risks of BCG vaccination as mentioned in A (4) para in a language that I understand. I do not belong to any of the exclusion criteria as mentioned in A (3).
*   I am aware that my personal identifiable information excluding Aadhaar number / Virtual ID number can be used and shared for purposes as mentioned above. I give my consent to use my data for the study purpose and I reserve the right to revoke the given consent at any point of time for vaccination and subsequent follow up as per government guidelines.
*   I agree to receive BCG vaccine and follow up thereafter. I am willing to take vaccine and sign the register too.

Yes ☐

<!-- Page 65 -->

BCG Trials
DR. BHARATH KATHI, MD, DNB, FIP, FAC, BOARD

---

<!-- Page 66 -->



# 1930 - 50
*   There have been many studies of BCG vaccination since 1930.
*   One of the earliest studies began in Alaska in 1935, where the incidence of tuberculosis in Indians was very high. Almost an equal number of children between one and nineteen years of age, living under the same conditions were vaccinated with BCG.
*   In the study in Puerto Rico started in 1949 the protective effect of BCG assessed in 50,634 vaccines was about 30 per cent (Comstock, 1958, 1974).
*   In another study in Georgia in a population of about 5000 children aged 6 to 7 years, no protective effect was observed.
*   In the third American study in Georgia and Alabama, a very low protective effect of about 14 per cent was observed.

---

<!-- Page 67 -->



## 1950s

*   The British MRC trial begun in 1953, involved 60,000 school children aged 14 to 15½ years.
*   All were X-rayed and tuberculin tested with 3 TU.
*   The children who were tuberculin sensitive were kept under observation.
*   The others were divided at random, into three groups. One unvaccinated, one were vaccinated with BCG and the third with vole bacilli.
*   All were kept under observation and reports issued at regular intervals for 20 years.
*   ⦿ At 10 years the incidence of tuberculosis in non-vaccinated, noninfected was 1.91 per 1000, in the vaccinated 0.40 per 1000.
*   ⦾ This trial has shown that BCG gives 80 per cent protection in the vaccinated group.
*   • Another important study, began in Madanapalli, South India in a general population of about 10,000.
*   ↓ The protective effect at 9-14 years, after vaccination was assessed to be about 30 per cent (Frimodt Moller, et al., 1968).
*   • Similarly

---

<!-- Page 68 -->

*   **Chingleput trial 1963**: ICMR in collaboration with others called it the Tuberculosis Prevention Trial.
*   The intake was started in **1968** and completed in **1971**.
*   A large scale community-based double blind randomized controlled to evaluate the protective effect of BCG against bacillary forms of pulmonary tuberculosis.
*   From among **366,625** individuals registered, **281,161** persons were vaccinated with BCG or placebo by random allocation.
*   Two strains of BCG were used, the French and Danish, with a high dose (0.1 mg/0.1 ml) and a low dose (0.01 mg/0.1 ml) in each strain.
*   The entire population was followed up for **15 years** by means of resurveys every 30 months, and selective follow up every 10 months and continuous passive case finding.
*   **The incidence rates in the three "vaccination" groups were similar confirming the complete lack of protective efficacy, seen at the end of 7 1/2 years.**
*   BCG offered **no overall protection in adults** and a **low level of overall protection in children**.

---

    *   Elevation of anterior longitudinal ligament
    *   Deterioration of anterior cortex
    *   Vertebral collapse and angulation

## Symptoms and Signs

*   **Active stage** – Constitutional symptoms, stiff, painful spine, kyphotic, paraspinal muscle spasm.
    During sleep the muscle spasm relaxes permitting movement between inflamed surfaces resulting in typical night cries.
*   **Healed stage**
    *   No constitutional symptoms
    *   Persistent Deformity
    *   Radiological evidence of bone healing on serial X – rays
    *   ESR falls

*   Persistent backache
*   Referred Abdominal pain
*   Spinal tumor syndrome with neural deficit
*   Ankylosing spondylitis concomitant with pulmonary TB

<!-- Page 6 -->



# ABSCESSES AND SINUSES

*   Cervical Spine – along cervical triangles, brachial plexus in the axilla, intercostal spaces on chest wall.
*   Dorso lumbar and Lumbar Spine – in iliac fossa, lumbar triangle, below inguinal ligament, psoas.
*   What is generally expressed as clinically palpable “psoas abscess” in reality is an iliac abscess contained in the sheath of iliac muscle.
*   The abscess that has tracked down in the psoas sheath penetrates through the iliacus muscle sheath and becomes palpable as a mass in the iliac fossa. The abscess that remains confined to psoas sheath may not be palpable clinically.

# IMAGING

*   Number – 3

*   Most Common
*   X-ray - Decreased disc space
*   CT - Small necrotic foci
*   Bone scan - Hot spot in hyperemic zone.

---

<!-- Page 19 -->



# PARAVERTEBRAL SHADOWS

*   Paravertebral shadow is produced by extension of tuberculous granulation tissue and the collection of an abscess in the paravertebral region.
*   Abscess in the cervical region usually presents as a soft tissue shadow between the vertebral bodies and pharynx and trachea.
*   The upper thoracic abscess in the anteroposterior x-rays cast a V-shaped shadow stripping the lung apices laterally and downwards, or when it is small the superior mediastinum shows only squaring of its borders.
*   Abscesses below the level of fourth dorsal vertebrae produce typical fusiform-shape (bird nest appearance), however, when the size of the abscess is too large it may take the shape of a generalized broadening of the mediastinum. An abscess under tension may assume a globular-shape.
*   Radiological manifestation of psoas abscess is unilateral or infrequently bilateral widening of the psoas shadow.

---

<!-- Page 20 -->



# KYPHOTIC DEFORMITY (ANGULATION OF SPINE WITH CONVEXITY POSTERIORLY)

*   Forward wedging of one or 2 vertebral bodies would produce a small kyphos (knuckle kyphosis), wedge collapse of 3 or more vertebral bodies would produce an angular kyphosis, and moderate wedging of a large number of vertebrae would create a round kyphosis.

---

<!-- Page 21 -->



# CENTRAL TYPE OF LESION (TUBERCULOSIS OF THE CENTRUM)

*   The central disease arises as a result of infection which starts from the center of the vertebral body, the infection probably reaches the center through Batson's venous plexus or through the branches of the posterior vertebral artery.
*   The diseased vertebral body loses the normal bony trabeculae and may show areas of destruction or the body may be expanded or ballooned out like a tumor.
*   Towards the later stages the diseased vertebral body, however, shows a concentric collapse almost resembling vertebra plana. Diminution of the disc space is minimal and paravertebral shadow is usually not well marked.

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# ANTERIOR TYPE OF LESION

This lesion occurs when the infection starts beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament and the periosteum.

A tense paravertebral abscess strips and lifts the anterior longitudinal ligament and the periosteum and thus, causes erosion on the surface of the vertebral bodies. More erosion is caused wherever aorta is in close proximity with the paravertebral abscess (thoracic and thoracolumbar regions) thereby permitting transmission of aortic pulsations to the abscess.

Collapse of the vertebral body and diminution of the disc space is usually minimal and occurs late.

This lesion is relatively more common in thoracic spine in children.

---

<!-- Page 23 -->



# APPENDICIAL TYPE OF LESION

*   Isolated tuberculous infection of the pedicles and laminae (neural arch), transverse processes, and spinous process does occur but uncommonly.
*   Radiographically, these lesions may be appreciated by erosive lesions, paravertebral shadows and intact disc space.

# SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS OF POTT'S PARAPLEGIA ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASE PROXIMAL TO LUMBAR FIRST VERTEBRA

*   Motor functions are almost always affected before and to a greater extent than the sensory functions because the diseased area in the spine lies anterior to the cord thus being nearer to the motor tracts. Besides, probably the motor tracts are more sensitive to compression of the cord.
*   In very advanced cases of compression, bladder and anal sphincters may be involved and there may be a varying degree of sensory deficit. Sense of position and vibration are the last to disappear.
*   Exceptionally the damage to the cord may be so sudden and complete that the patient presents with sudden, complete flaccid paralysis like the clinical picture of "spinal shock". This may later gradually change into spasticity.
*   Sudden complete paralysis may be caused by ischemia of the cord due to thromboembolic phenomenon or transection of the cord due to pathological dislocation or extremely rarely due to rapid accumulation of infected material.

---

<!-- Page 29 -->

*   Tuberculous paraplegia or quadriplegia

            *   Continue medications and allow walking once neurological recovery is complete or 3 months after surgery

            *   Surgical decompression

<!-- Page 30 -->



# MANAGEMENT AND RESULTS

* Excisional surgery evidently evacuates tuberculous pus and debris, removes sequestra of disc and bone, opens up new vascular channels in ischemic areas thus leading to reduction of general toxemia, reduction of total time of healing of the local lesion and probably improves the quality of healing especially in cases with extensive destruction and sequestration.

---

<!-- Page 31 -->



# MANAGEMENT AND RESULTS

* Excisional surgery evidently evacuates tuberculous pus and debris, removes sequestra of disc and bone, opens up new vascular channels in ischemic areas thus leading to reduction of general toxemia, reduction of total time of healing of the local lesion and probably improves the quality of healing especially in cases with extensive destruction and sequestration.

---

<!-- Page 32 -->



# ABSOLUTE INDICATIONS FOR OPERATIVE DECOMPRESSION

* (1) neurological complications which do not start showing signs of 'progressive recovery to a satisfactory level after a fair trial of conservative therapy (three to four weeks),
* (2) patients with spinal caries in whom neurological complications develop during the conservative treatment,
* (3) patients with neurological complications which become worse while they are undergoing therapy with antituberculous drugs and bedrest,
* (4) patients who have a recurrence of neurological complication,
* (5) patients with prevertebral cervical abscesses, neurological signs and difficulty in deglutition and respiration
* (6) advanced cases of neurological involvement such as marked sensory and sphincter disturbances, flaccid paralysis or severe flexor spasms.

*   Abscesses are aspirated when near the surface and one gram of streptomycin with or without INH in solution is instilled at each aspiration. Open drainage of the abscess is performed if aspiration fails to clear them.

<!-- Page 34 -->



# SURGERY

*   Excisional surgery is recommended for posterior spinal disease associated with abscess or sinus formation (with or without neural involvement) because of danger of secondary infection of the meninges if the disease does not come under control under drug therapy within 3 to 4 weeks.
*   Operative debridement is advised for cases who do not show arrest of the activity of spinal lesions after 3 to 6 months of the chemotherapeutic regime or cases with recurrence of the disease.
*   Posterior spinal arthrodesis is recommended for symptomatic unstable spinal lesions in which the disease otherwise seems to be arrested. A lesion is considered mechanically unstable if in spite of the arrest of the vertebral disease the patient gets discomfort in the back on doing normal work. Radiologically such lesions may show significant destruction of more than 2 vertebrae and lack of regeneration of vertebral bodies during the process of healing.
*   Postoperative After decompression or debridement or arthrodesis the patients are nursed on a hard bed, when necessary (for children) a plaster of Paris bed has been used in initial 2 to 3 weeks.
*   In cases with neural complications 3 to 5 months after the operation when the patient has made good recovery, the patient is gradually mobilized out of the bed with the help of spinal braces. In the absence of paraplegia mobilization with spinal braces is started 3 to 5 months after the operation. The spinal brace is gradually discarded about 12 to 24 months after the operation.

# OPERATIVE TREATMENT

*   Cervical spine: Cervical spine is best approached by anterior approach as developed by Smith and Robinson (1958, 1968).
*   The involved region is explored by working between sternomastoid and carotid sheath laterally, and oesophagus and trachea medially. The site is localized under x-ray control.
*   Atlantoaxial region: Fang and Ong (1962) developed transoral approach, and transthyrohyoid approach for such higher lesions.
*   Thoracolumbar region: It has been approached through extra-pleural anterolateral exposure by Kirkaldy-Willis.
*   Lumbar spine: It has been approached through a retroperitoneal approach (similar to kidney, ureter or sympathectomy exposure).
*   Lumbosacral region (L5-S1) - hypogastric paramedian transperitoneal approach. Retroperitoneal approach.

# SURGERY IN SEVERE KYPHOSIS

*   The safest method of preventing severe kyphotic deformity is to identify the potential cases at high risk (active disease in patients younger than 10 years, dorsal lesion, involvement of 3 or more vertebrae (Tuli 1975, 1984) and subject them to a panvertebral operation including fusion of the posterior elements of the diseased vertebrae.
*   The fundamentals of correcting a fixed spinal curve are first to perform an osteotomy on the concave side of the curve and wedge it open. The second step is to remove a wedge on the convex side and close this wedge.

# FOLLOW UP

The protocolized follow up of spinal TB patients is as follows:

1.  Patients with neurological deficits require staging and grading of their deficit on each visit.
2.  Patients without neurological deficit should be assessed weekly for neurological signs.
3.  Repeat X-rays of the spine every 3 months.
4.  Repeat CE-MRI
    a. After 6 months, if there is suspicion of poor treatment response (but is not required in most)
    b. At treatment completion (12 months) it would be prudent to assess healing before discontinuation of therapy.
    c. Findings of quiescent burnt out infection which do not warrant continuation of ATT such as bony/fibrous ankylosis or thin walled cysts without enhancement must be identified.
5.  After completion of treatment, follow up every 6 months for at least 2 years.

# Transmission of NTM



## Likely routes of infection

*   Inhalation of NTM-laden aerosols or dust
*   Ingestion of soil or water
*   Contamination of hospital water supplies and medical equipment
*   Person-to-person transmission extremely rare, but some evidence of this in the CF community
*   Gastroesophageal reflux disease has been indicated as a mediator of NTM-LD

---

**Handwritten Notes:**

<!-- Page 6 -->



# PATHOGENESIS

Abnormal airway clearance allows persistence of pulmonary NTMs that would otherwise normally be cleared
Once infection is established, pulmonary NTMs can persist within biofilms and macrophages, which may shield NTMs from antibiotic therapy
the natural history of disease is generally one of slowly progressive lung destruction over a course of years

*   HRCT: clusters of small nodules associated with areas of bronchiectasis in the lower and middle zones are common.
*   Asymptomatic solitary nodules noted due to MAC (Cavity nodules Bx)

# DRUG SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTING

*In vitro susceptibility to certain agents strongly predicts clinical outcomes.*

*Current recommendations are to test for MAC and MAb susceptibility to <u>macrolides</u> and <u>amikacin</u>.*

*In the case of MAb, molecular methods or a <u>14-day hold</u> for <u>culture</u> may further be necessary to evaluate for an inducible erm gene conferring macrolide resistance.*

*Guidelines also support testing of <u>M. kansasii</u> for susceptibility to <u>rifampin</u>.*

---

*   *(Top right, above the "E A R" box):* sperm abt
*   *(Top right, a box/circle containing):* E A R
    *   *(Below E):* +
    *   *(Below A):* th, ro
    *   *(Below R):* d, m
*   *(To the right of the "E A R" box, connected by a "+"):*
    *   -> Amikaan
    *   -> FQ
*   *(Next to "MAb"):* Abolenus
*   *(Below "rifampin"):* P
*   *(Below "M. kansasii"):* P
*   *(Bottom center):* DR. BHARATH KATHI MD, DNB, FIP, FACI, EDARM

---

<!-- Page 3 -->

# M. avium complex: PD (Pul Disease) (EAR regimes)

Recommend a 3-drug regimen that includes a macrolide

## NTM (Susceptibility Duration)

*   **MAC**
    *   **Test:**
        *   Macrolides
        *   Amikacin
    *   **Duration:**
        *   12 months after sputum conversion (minimum)
        *   *Handwritten:* At least 14 months after sputum conversion
        *   *Handwritten:* EAR + Inj Am [Daily] [Alt day]
        *   *Handwritten:* Refractory
        *   *Handwritten:* Refractory as [Culture (+) after 6 months of Rx]

## Disease Category & Dosing Regimen (Minimum of Three Drugs)

### Nodular-bronchiectatic

*   Dosed thrice weekly (*Handwritten:* Alt day)
    *   Ethambutol 25 mg/kg po
    *   Rifampin 600 mg po
    *   Azithromycin 500 mg po

### Cavitary, extensive, or macrolide-resistant

*   Dosed daily (*Handwritten:* Dosed daily)
    *   Ethambutol 15 mg/kg po
    *   Rifampin 450-600 mg (10 mg/kg) po
    *   Azithromycin 250-500 mg po
*   Dosed thrice weekly (*Handwritten:* Dosed thrice weekly)
    *   Amikacin 15-25 mg/kg

### Refractory

*   Dosed daily
    *   Ethambutol 15 mg/kg po
    *   Rifampin 450-600 mg (10 mg/kg) po
    *   Azithromycin 250-500 mg po
    *   **and**
        *   ALIS 590 mg inhaled daily
    *   **or**
        *   Amikacin 15-25 mg/kg thrice weekly

## Additional Notes

*   Azithromycin >> clarithromycin (↑↑ADRs & BD dosing)
*   Rifampin is preferred over rifabutin
*   Daily dosing of the oral regimen, along with 2 to 3 months of an aminoglycoside, is used for severe or cavitary disease, as well as for macrolide resistance. Clofazimine and Bedaquiline, also may be considered.
*   Refractory disease is defined as remaining sputum culture positive after 6 months of guideline-based therapy.
*   Amikacin liposome inhalation suspension (ALIS) helpful in treatment refractory patients with MAC pulmonary disease.

# NTM-PD SURGERY
*   failure of medical management,

*   drug resistant isolates, or
*   complications such as hemoptysis or severe bronchiectasis
*   The decision to proceed with surgical resection must be weighed against the risks and benefits of surgery.

# Follow-up

## Radiological response

*   A CT scan should be performed \*
    *   Shortly before starting NTM treatment
    *   and
    *   At the end of NTM treatment \*
    To document the radiological response to treatment.
*   CT-directed bronchial wash

## Microbiological response

*   To assess the microbiological response, samples should be sent for mycobacterial culture (e.g., lung lavage, fine needle aspiration)
    *   Every 4-12 weeks during treatment
    *   12 months after completing treatment
*   CT-directed bronchial wash \*
    *   Doubt about persisting NTM infection despite negative sputum cultures ✓
    *   Unable to expectorate sputum (after 6 and 12 months of treatment) ✓
        *   (Handwritten: If we have a reference)
        *   (Handwritten: If we have a reference)

# MANAGEMENT OF COINFECTION

Coinfection with <mark>multiple NTMs</mark> - <mark>MAC</mark>, <mark>M. kansasii</mark>, and/or M. <u>xenopi</u> are treated with a regimen consisting of ethambutol, a rifamycin, and a macrolide. (EAR)

In <mark>MAC</mark> and <mark>Mab</mark> co infection <s>X A X</s>
* When the <mark>MAb</mark> is <mark>macrolide-sensitive</mark>, <mark>initiate treatment for</mark> <mark>MAC and MAb</mark> <u>simultaneously</u> to avoid <u>development of MAb macrolide resistance</u>.
* If the <mark>MAb is macrolide-resistant</mark>, <u>starting with <mark>MAC therapy</mark></u>, which is more likely to be tolerated; subsequently, agents active against MAb are added.

Based on the following medical content from "PNEUMONIA 2" (section: Pathogenesis):

CONTENT:
# Pathogenesis

*   Microorganisms may reach the lungs via the airways (Aspiration / Inhalation), bloodstream, or lymphatics or Direct spread
    *   from Adj. organs.
*   First step in many infections is colonization of the upper airway and reach lung by micro aspiration from the oropharynx.

---

<!-- Page 6 -->

A plethora of microorganisms, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi, are inhaled daily, mainly in dust or aerosol particles.
WHY EVERY ONE IS NOT DEVELOPING PNEUMONIA ???

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



# Pulmonary defence mechanism

*   OPD's done
*   OPD → Alveolar Epithelium
    *   Alveolar Macrophage
    *   mucociliary escalator

---

<!-- Page 8 -->

**Diagram 1: Mucociliary Clearance**
*   Foreign particles
*   Gel layer
*   Sol layer
*   Mucus
*   Cilia
*   Bronchial wall epithelium

**Diagram 2: Epithelial Cells and Receptors**
*   Cilia
*   Epithelial cells
*   TLRs (Toll-like Receptors)
*   PAMPs (Pathogen-Associated Molecular Patterns)

**Diagram 3: Alveolar Space and Immune Cells**
*   Alveolar space
*   IL-1R (Interleukin-1 Receptor)
*   (Shows macrophages and lymphocytes within the alveolar space)

---

\* **Muco- ciliary blanket :**
Microorganisms in large particles are trapped -> transported to the back of the throat, where they are swallowed and cleared.

• **Respiratory epithelial cells :** -> defensins and cathelicidins have antimicrobial activity -> prevent adherence and colonization by potential bacterial pathogens

**LUNG INNATE & ACQUIRED IMMUNITY**
: either kill or infected ones are eliminated via either the mucociliary elevator or the lymphatics

---

<!-- Page 9 -->

HOW WILL BODY FIGHT ?? : IMMUNE CELLS ASSEMBLE

(Image: A scale with "Body's Defences" on the left pan and a finger pressing down on the right pan, labeled "Pathogen load".)
(Image: A dark, blurry image of a crowd of people, possibly representing immune cells assembling.)

Immune cells initiate the inflammatory response that triggers the clinical syndrome of pneumonia.

---

<!-- Page 10 -->



# IMMUNITY



## Innate Immunity
*   [Acute inflammation]
*   Inherent, nonspecific ✓
*   Immediate & first line ✓
*   Components:
    1.  Neutrophils *
    2.  Macrophages *
        *   (Neutrophils and Macrophages are indicated for) => Bacterial infection
    3.  Dendritic cells
*   [NMD]



## Acquired Immunity
*   [Chronic]
*   **Adapts** to infectious agent
*   & generates specific mechanism to neutralise them
*   Components:
    *   T cells
    *   B cells



## Other Components
*   NK cells (Natural Killer cells)
    *   *(Implied connection to both Innate and Acquired immunity)*
*   (⊗ clearance of pathogen by lung)

---

<!-- Page 11 -->



# Immunity -> ACUTE INFLAMMATION



## Vascular events
*   ↑ Vascular permiability [MOST Characteristic]
*   Leakage of fluid & proteins into tissue to facilitate mediator reach to tissue
*   Mediators:
    *   PGs
    *   Histamine
    *   Bradykinins (PAF)
    *   => vasodilation => ↑ Vascular Permiability



## Cellular events
*   (Phagocytosis)
*   IL8 ↑ in response to inflammation (pulls neutrophils to reach tissue)
*   Immune cells from blood reach to tissue
    *   (Visual representation: Blood vessel -> Tissue)
*   Binding of Neutrophils to endothelium mediated by Selectins & Integrins
*   Diapedesis [move into tissue] & get activated
    *   => ↑ IL1, TNFα

---

<!-- Page 12 -->

*   **Most important defence => Phagocytosis by innate immunity**

I. Recognition of Infection by
    *   TLR (Toll Like Receptor)
    *   NLR (Nodd Like Receptor)
    *   RLR (Rig Like Receptor)
    *   CLR (C-type Lectin Receptor)

Identified by molecular Pattern:
    *   **PAMP**
        *   Pathogen
        *   Associated
        *   Molecular
        *   Patterns
    *   **DAMP**
        *   Damage
        *   Associated
        *   Molecular
        *   Pattern
        *   *(Molecules Released by infected cells)*

*(Image content: Apoptotic cells and TLR ligands, PAMPs)*

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



# Receptor Families

*   **TLR**: Toll Like Receptor
*   **NLR**: Nodd Receptor
*   **RLR**: Rig Receptor
*   **CLR**: C-lechn Receptor



## Identified by Molecular Pattern

| PAMP (Pathogen Associated Molecular Patterns) | DAMP (Damage Associated Molecular Patterns) |
| :-------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------ |
| Pathogen                                      | Damage                                      |
| Associated                                    | Associated                                  |
| Molecular                                     | Molecular                                   |
| Patterns                                      | Pattern                                     |
| Example: Bacteria $\Rightarrow$ LPS           | Example: Necrotic cells                     |

---



## Diagram Labels

*   PAMPs
*   Apoptotic cell bodies
*   MHC II
*   Apoptotic cells and TLR ligands
*   DC
*   Immunological outcome?

---

*FIP FACI EDARM*

---

<!-- Page 14 -->



## II Pathogen engulfment $\Rightarrow$ Phagosome formation

Infection by S. aureus $\rightarrow$ Neutrophil activation $\rightarrow$ Phagocytosis $\rightarrow$ Engulfment



## III Pathogen killing \* Phagolysosome formation
$\downarrow$
Reactive Oxygen Species Enzymatic killing
$\leftarrow \rightarrow$
ROS oxygen independent

*Diagrammatic element:* L (circled in red)

---

<!-- Page 15 -->



### III Pathogen killing

*   **Phagolysosome formation**
    *   (Illustration: A cell (phagocyte) engulfing a pathogen (labeled 'L') into a phagosome, which then fuses with a lysosome to form a phagolysosome.)

    *   **Enzymatic killing**
        *   **Reactive Oxygen species (ROS\*)**
            *   [Effective killing]
        *   **Oxygen independent**
            *   Cathepsin
            *   Defensin
            *   Cathsedins

Dr. bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 16 -->



# Why Pneumonia happens in few ???



## HOST FACTORS
*   ↓↓ local defense mechanisms
*   ↓↓ the systemic resistance of the host is lowered.



## PATHOGEN FACTORS
*   ↑ virulence of organism
*   ↑ infectious load

---

<!-- Page 17 -->



# ↑ Pneumonia



## LOCAL DEFENCE

*   ↓ cough reflex
*   Dysfunction of the mucociliary apparatus → cigarette smoke / viral diseases / immotile cilia syndromes
*   Accumulation of secretions : cystic fibrosis and bronchial obstruction
*   ↓ phagocytic activity of alveolar macrophages by alcohol / tobacco smoke | silicosis
*   Pulmonary congestion



## THE SYSTEMIC RESISTANCE

*   chronic diseases : DM, CKD, CLD
*   Immunologic deficiencies : HIV, common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), X-linked agammaglobulinemia (inherited),
*   treatment with immunosuppressive agents, and leukopenia.
*   organ transplant

---

<!-- Page 18 -->

*   Dysfunction of the mucociliary apparatus
    *   → cigarette smoke / viral diseases / immotile cilia syndromes
*   Accumulation of secretions: cystic fibrosis and bronchial obstruction.
*   ↓ phagocytic activity of alveolar macrophages by alcohol /tobacco smoke
*   Pulmonary congestion and edema

*   Immunologic deficiencies: HIV,
*   common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), X-linked agammaglobulinemia (inherited),
*   treatment with immunosuppressive agents, and leukopenia.
    *   ↓ steroid (long term) / organ transplant / chemotherapy

---

<!-- Page 19 -->

FEW SPECIAL EXAMPLES OF Pathogen factors

*   *Streptococcus pneumoniae*: contains multiple adhesions, binds to the receptor for platelet-activating factor on epithelial cells, enhanced by cigarette smoke
*   *Staphylococcus aureus*: multiple adhesins that bind host extracellular matrix proteins
*   *Influenza viruses*: hemagglutinins that bind to sialic acid on the surface of epithelial cells.
*   *SARS CoV2*: binds to ACE2 receptor of nasal and alveolar epithelial cells.
*   *Mycoplasma pneumoniae*: release toxins to impair ciliary activity.
*   *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*: survives within the phagocyte.

Handwritten notes:
*   V. (virus) binds to epithelial cell strongly
*   MAB
*   Spike protein
*   ACE2
*   ACE2
*   2. Mtb resist killing by phagocyte

---

<!-- Page 20 -->

*   **Staphylococcus aureus**: multiple adhesins that bind host extracellular matrix proteins
*   **Influenza viruses**: hemagglutinins that bind to sialic acid on the surface of epithelial cells.
*   **SARS CoV2**: binds to ACE2 receptor of nasal and alveolar epithelial cells.
*   **Mycoplasma pneumoniae**: release toxins to impair ciliary activity.
*   **Mycobacterium tuberculosis**: survives within the phagolysosomes of macrophages.
    *   (fusion of phagolysosome / incompletely formed phagolysosome)
*   Mtb resists killing by phagocytes.

*(From the diagram)*
*   Spike protein
*   ACE2
*   MAB (Monoclonal Antibody)

---

<!-- Page 21 -->



# PATHOLOGICAL TYPES



## Lobar pneumonia
Diffuse consolidation involving the entire lobe of the lung.
Four stages of lobar pneumonia have been described.
MC pattern in CAP



## Bronchopneumonia
Patchy neutrophilic inflammation in is centered in bronchi and bronchioles, with centrifugal spread to the adjacent alveoli may be due to aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
MC Noscomial pneumonia pattern



## Interstitial pneumonia
Inflammation involving the interstitium is characterized by infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
The alveoli do not contain a significant exudate.
Ex Viral pneumonia

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# Lobar pneumonia
*   Diffuse consolidation involving the entire lobe of the lung
*   Four stages of lobar pneumonia have been described
*   MC pattern in CAP
*   Ex: Streptococcus pneumonia



# Bronchopneumonia
*   *more aggressive*
*   Patchy neutrophilic inflammation in is centered in bronchi and bronchioles, with centrifugal spread to the adjacent alveoli may be due to aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
*   MC Noscomial pneumonia pattern
*   Ex: Staph pneumonia
*   *Bronch -> Staph*

## Aspiration pneumonia

*   **Chemical injury pneumonitis (Mendelson syndrome)** - posterior segment of the right upper lobe and superior segment of the right lower lobe
*   High concentrations of amylase or pepsinogen in BAL fluid
*   Anaerobic infection - 1 to 2 weeks after aspiration
*   Segmental opacification with multiple small areas of necrosis that evolve into cavities (<2 cm in diameter), usually without air-fluid levels
*   Organisms: *E. exsiccans*, *Prevotella*, *Porphyromonas*, *Peptostreptococcus*, microaerophilic *Streptococcus* species, *Veillonella* species. (Handwritten additions: *Bacteroides*, *Prevotella*, *Peptostreptococcus*, *F. nucleatum*)



## Chronic pneumonias

*   Persistence of symptoms for at least **6 weeks**
*   **Actinomyces**
*   Chest wall lesions and draining sinuses
*   Direct extension of a cavity or mass through an interlobar fissure
*   Diagnosis: **sulfur granules** containing a mass of mycelial elements in a protein and polysaccharide matrix, and granulomatous-like reactions



## Pulmonary Anthrax

*   Gram-positive spore-forming
*   Contaminated animal hides, wool, meat, bones or drug injection
*   Types: Cutaneous, Gastrointestinal, Injectional, Inhalational
*   **Inhalational (wool-sorter's disease)** - most severe
*   Incubation: 4 days
*   Characteristics: Diffuse edema of the neck and anterior chest
*   Radiology: widened mediastinum and bilateral pleural effusions
*   Clinical triad: Mediastinal widening, confusion, and a raised hematocrit



## Pulmonary Anthrax - Treatment

*   Diagnosis: Culture - "**boxcar**" chains, IHC, PCR
*   Treatment
*   Initial Phase: Ciprofloxacin, doxycycline + clindamycin 600 mg, penicillin G, meropenem, rifampin. **Raxibacumab** - Monoclonal antibody
*   Continuation phase: ciprofloxacin or doxycycline
*   About 60 days - eliminate spores

# CRB65

*Note: Used where Blood Investigations (Ix) not possible*

**Criteria (each scores 1 point):**

*   U: Urea > 40 mg/l (or) > 7 mmol/l

# FOLLOW UP

# Severe CAP / sCAP

*   If available, we suggest sending a **lower respiratory tract sample** (either sputum or endotracheal aspirates) for *multiplex PCR testing* (virus and/or bacterial detection) whenever *non-standard sCAP antibiotics* are prescribed or considered
*   **sCAP** + **acute hypoxaemic respiratory failure not needing immediate intubation** → *high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO)* > **standard oxygen**
*   Addition of **macrolides** (R: immunomodulatory property extra), not **fluoroquinolones**, to *beta-lactams as empirical antibiotic* therapy in *hospitalised patients with sCAP*

Biomarkers in pneumonia



# ROLE OF PROCALCITONIN IN sCAP

We suggest the use of PCT to reduce the duration of antibiotic treatment in patients with sCAP. The recommendation of using PCT must be considered together with clinical assessment. PCT might not be useful when clinical stability is achieved, and duration of antibiotic therapy is between 5 and 7 days.

Procalcitonin is produced by the neuroendocrine cells of the lung and intestine.

released as an acute-phase reactant in response to inflammatory stimuli, especially those of bacterial origin (endotoxin) and inflammatory cytokines.

serum procalcitonin in response to Viral infections and noninfectious inflammatory stimuli such as autoimmune disease and chronic inflammatory processes are much less pronounced, rarely exceeding 0.5 ng/ml.

<!-- Page 71 -->



# Biomarkers in pneumonia



## Procalcitonin (PCT)
*   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection
*   Need for antibiotic therapy
*   Prediction of severity of CAP (ICU admission/ triaging emergency room patients)
*   Prognosis of pneumonia patients
*   Duration of antibiotic treatment



## C-reactive protein (CRP)
*   Prediction of severity of CAP
*   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection

Serum CRP is an acute phase protein synthesized exclusively in the liver. Its secretion is initiated 4 to 6 h after an insult (effect mediated by cytokines namely interleukin-6).



## Pro-adrenomedullin (Pro-ADM)
*   Severity of CAP

Mid-regional proadrenomedullin (MR-proADM) is a new biomarker of endothelial damage and its clinical use is increasing in sepsis and respiratory infections and recently in SARS-CoV-2 infection.



## B-natriuretic peptide (BNP)
*   Severity of CAP

Proinflammatory cytokines might increase plasma BNP from ventricles. A high BNP level ($\ge 200 \text{ pg/mL}$) at admission was a predictor of CAP-related death.



## Troponin I
*   Degree of hypoxemia: severity of illness

In response to infection, soluble TREM-1 (sTREM-1) is either secreted or shed. sTREM-1 levels can then be measured in body fluids.

In response to infection, soluble TREM-1 (sTREM-1) is either secreted or shed. sTREM-1 levels can then be measured in body fluids like BAL. BAL fluid sTREM-1 has been suggested as a biomarker to differentiate VAP positive from VAP negative patients.

ERS/ESICM/ESCMID/ALAT guidelines for the management of severe community-acquired pneumonia : 2023

We suggest the use of oseltamivir for patients with sCAP due to influenza confirmed by PCR. When PCR is not available to confirm influenza, we suggest the use of empirical oseltamivir during the influenza season.

In patients with sCAP, we suggest the use of corticosteroids if shock is present. Based on common exclusion criteria from clinical trials, this recommendation does not apply to patients with viral sCAP (influenza, SARS, and MERS), uncontrolled diabetes and corticos-teroid treatment for other reasons.

When corticosteroid therapy is considered, methylprednisolone (0.5 mg/kg-1 every 12 h for 5 days) is a reasonable option.

## WHEN TO SUSPECT NOSOCOMIAL PNEUMONIA ?? [Simplest]

*   Any patient with new or progressive radiographic opacities and clinical signs or symptoms indicative of infection : fever, leukocytosis or leukopenia, purulent sputum, or worsening oxygenation.

*   The bacteriologic strategy uses **quantitative cultures** of the **LRT** via **endotracheal aspirate**, **protected specimen brush**, or **bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)**.
*   The thresholds differ depending on the method of respiratory sampling and are as follows:
*   $\ge 10^5$ colony-forming units (CFU)/mL for an endotracheal aspirate.
*   $\ge 10^4$ CFU/mL for a BAL.
*   and $\ge 10^3$ CFU/mL for a protected specimen brush.
*   Results of these procedures guide decisions such as when to initiate or stop antibiotics and the drug(s) to be used against the offending agent.
*   There are no **definitive data** to support the use of one sampling technique over another; however, **cellular analysis of BAL fluid** may provide an advantage, as a sample **containing <50% neutrophils produced excellent negative predictive value** in one study.

*   Extrapulmonary manifestations of CMV infection (e.g. **gastrooesophagitis**; **hepatitis**) may suggest the diagnosis
    *   **Leukopenia**, **thrombocytopenia**, and **abnormal liver function tests (LFTs)** are characteristic.

**NEUROLOGIC**

*   Myelitis
*   Polyradiculopathy
*   Peripheral Neuropathy

**EYE**
*   Retinitis
    *   (Most common cause of blindness in AIDS)

**LIVER**
*   Hepatitis
*   Portal vein thrombosis

**ENDOCRINE**
*   Infectious Adrenalitis
*   Pancreatitis

**PULMONARY**
*   Pneumonitis
    *   (In association with PJP/TB)

**CARDIOVASCULAR**
*   Myocarditis
*   ↑ Cardiovascular risk
*   DVT

**GASTROINTESTINAL**
*   Esophagitis
*   Enteritis
*   Colitis

# Imaging

*   CXR typically bilateral $\underline{\text{diffuse interstitial}}$ infiltrate, although $\underline{\text{lobar consolidation}}$ and localized haziness also described
*   CT Features include $\underline{\text{localized}}$ or $\underline{\text{diffuse}}$ $\underline{\text{ground-glass}}$ and $\underline{\text{nodular shadowing}}$ that may progress to airspace $\underline{\text{consolidation}}$
*   Dx: $\underline{\text{PCR in serum or BAL}}$, $\underline{\text{histologic evidence}}$ of $\underline{\text{viral inclusions on biopsy}}$
*   Rx: Reduce immunosuppression where possible.
    *   $\checkmark$ $\underline{\text{Ganciclovir 5 mg/kg IV bd for 2-4 weeks}}$ (1 month)
    *   $\checkmark$ $\underline{\text{Anti-CMV hyperimmune globulin}}$ or prolonged oral valganciclovir in cases of severe or relapsed disease.
*   Alternative Rx: $\underline{\text{Foscarnet 60mg/kg tds for}}$ 2-3 weeks $\checkmark$
*   Recently, $\underline{\text{letermovir}}$ has been introduced for $\underline{\text{prophylaxis}}$; $\checkmark$

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 161 -->



# Adenovirus

A denovirus
↳ ds DNA → DIC, Disseminated
↳ Cidofovir
↳ Meningo Encephalitis, myocarditis
Dr @Bharath Kathy

*   non-enveloped dsDNA viruses
*   Most common symptoms are those of self-limiting upper airways infection, which frequently mimics group A streptococcal infection, particularly in childhood
*   Can cause pneumonia and ARDS in adults
*   Occasional complications—myocarditis, hepatitis, nephritis, ❤️ 🤎 🫁
    meningoencephalitis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
*   Disseminated disease may occur in the immunocompromised ✓
*   Diagnosis is from nasopharyngeal fluid, sputum, or BAL fluid viral culture, antigen testing or PCR, or quantitative PCR on blood
*   Rx : supportive, but severe cases may be treated with cidofovir ± IV immunoglobulin.
    A-C

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 162 -->



# RSV

RSV
↳ ssRNA
↳ Ribavirin

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA virus; subtypes A and B. Subtype A (more severe disease)
*   Very common cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children.
*   Role in adult respiratory disease is more significant than previously
*   Clinical features in adults are usually of URTI or tracheobronchitis, but this may progress to pneumonia, particularly in the setting of underlying cardiac or respiratory disease, malignancy, or immunosuppression;
*   outbreaks affecting adults in hospitals and nursing homes also occur.
*   Dx: nasopharyngeal secretions and BAI fluid are often diagnostic; detection of RSV antigen / PCR-based test / serology
*   Bacterial superinfection may be a frequent complication
*   Rx: supportive. Ribavirin and steroids in the treatment of severe disease in adults is unclear *R-R*
*   Reports of successful outcomes in bone marrow transplant recipients following treatment with ribavirin and immunoglobulin.

---

<!-- Page 163 -->



# Varicella pneumonia

*   Caused by varicella-zoster virus (an enveloped dsDNA virus)
*   Pneumonia occurs in a small proportion of adults with chickenpox or shingles but can be severe
*   Risk factors: smoking, increased number of skin spots (>100), pregnancy (third trimester), steroid treatment and immunocompromise ⭐
*   CF: H/O recent exposure to a contact infected with chickenpox or shingles with rash (erythematous macules progressing to papules and then vesicles) f/b Cough and breathlessness, pleuritic pain and haemoptysis may occur
*   CXR typically shows a diffuse small nodular infiltrate; hilar lymphadenopathy and pleural effusions may uncommonly occur. Nodules may subsequently calcify and persist (to look like TB nodules (may))
*   Diagnosis: H/O exposure, presence of rash, and CXR features. Cytological examination of smears from skin lesions, serology, or viral culture or PCR on BAL fluid may confirm the diagnosis
*   Rx: aciclovir 10-12.5mg/kg IV tds for 7-10 days
*   Consider early administration of varicella zoster immune globulin for immunocompromised and pregnant patients ⭐

# KAPOSI SARCOMA

*   Kaposi sarcoma is the most common HIV-associated malignancy
*   Multicentric neoplasm consisting of multiple vascular nodules appearing in the skin, mucous membranes, and viscera.
*   The immune system damage caused by HIV allows cells harboring HHV-8 to multiply. Through unknown mechanisms, the characteristic lesions form.
*   Treatment : ART Antiretroviral therapy

# Chlamydia

*   C. pneumoniae (formerly Chlamydia pneumoniae) accounts for 5% to 15% of cases of CAP
*   asymptomatic: an acute, mild respiratory tract infection is observed in only 10% of infected adolescents and young adults.
*   Sore throat with hoarseness is often severe and may precede pneumonia by up to a week and resolve before pneumonia onset, resulting in a biphasic illness.
*   C. pneumoniae cannot be visualized by Gram stain, and tissue culture is required to grow the pathogen.
*   Although direct fluorescent antibody detection of C. pneumoniae is available, PCR if available

# Assessment of severity of Pneumonia

The CRB65 score is used to assess the severity of pneumonia. One point is awarded for each of the following criteria present:

*   ① **C**onfusion
*   ② **U**rea > 40mg/dL (or) > 7mmol/L
    *   *(BUN: 20mg%.)*
*   ③ **R**espiratory rate > 30/min
*   ④ **B**lood pressure: SBP < 90 (or) DBP < 60
*   ⑤ **65**: Age > 65 years

*(These criteria collectively form the CRB65 score)*

---

**Risk Stratification based on CRB65 Score:**

*   **0, 1 points:** Outpatient treatment (OPRx)
*   **2 points:** Ward treatment (WARD Rx)
*   **3, 4, 5 points:** Inpatient treatment (IPRx)

# WHEN TO SUSPECT NOSOCOMIAL PNEUMONIA ?? [Simplest]

*   Any patient with **new or progressive radiographic opacities** and clinical signs or symptoms indicative of infection: **fever, leukocytosis or leukopenia, purulent sputum, or worsening oxygenation.**
*   These clinical findings are neither sensitive nor specific, and there is **no gold standard** for the diagnosis of HAP or VAP

Modified Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) criteria for diagnosis of HAP/VAP

*   Chest radiographic opacities (new, progressive or persistent infiltrate or cavitation)
    AND
*   At least two of the following:
    1.  Fever >38 °C or >100.4 °
    2.  Leukopaenia (<4000 WBC/µL) or leukocytosis (≥12000 WBC/µL)
    3.  Altered mental status with no other recognised cause in the elderly
    4.  New onset of purulent sputum, or increased respiratory secretions,
    5.  Worsening gas exchange
    6.  New onset or worsening cough, or dyspnoea, or tachypnoea
    7.  Rales or bronchial breath sounds

# VAP

\* ETA VS BAL VS PSB
  10^5   10^4   10^3

* The bacteriologic strategy uses quantitative cultures of the LRT via endotracheal aspirate, protected specimen brush, or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).
* The thresholds differ depending on the method of respiratory sampling and are as follows: ≥10^5 • colony-forming units (CFU)/mL for an endotracheal aspirate,
* ≥10^4 • CFU/mL for a BAL,
* and ≥10^3 • CFU/mL for a protected specimen brush.
* Results of these procedures guide decisions such as when to initiate or stop antibiotics and the drug(s) to be used against the offending agent.
* There are no definitive data to support the use of one sampling technique over another; however, cellular analysis of BAL fluid may provide an advantage, as a \*sample containing <50% neutrophils produced excellent negative predictive value in one study.

## SEVERE
*   SpO2 < 90% or RR > 30/min
    *   Admit in ICU
    *   High flow Nasal Oxygen (HFNO) or NIV
    *   Steroids \*
    *   Anticoagulation \*
    *   Remdesivir, Anti IL6
    *   If not improving → Invasive mech ventilation & Ventilate as per ARDS Protocol

EUA/Off label use (based on limited available evidence and only in specific circumstances):

*   **Remdesivir (EUA)** may be considered **ONLY** in patients with
    *   Moderate to severe disease (requiring **SUPPLEMENTAL OXYGEN**), **AND**
    *   **No renal or hepatic dysfunction** (eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times ULN (Not an absolute contradiction)), **AND**
    *   Who are **within 10 days of onset of symptom/s.**
    *   **Recommended dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 f/b 100 mg IV OD for next 4 days.**
    *   **Not to be used in patients who are NOT on oxygen support or in home settings**

**Tocilizumab** (Off-label) may be considered when **ALL OF THE BELOW CRITERIA ARE MET** => 2 doses
*   Presence of severe disease (preferably within 24 to 48 hours of onset of severe disease/ICU admission).
*   Significantly raised inflammatory markers (CRP &/or IL-6).
*   Not improving despite use of steroids.
*   No active bacterial/fungal/tubercular infection.
*   **Recommended single dose: 4 to 6 mg/kg (400 mg in 60kg adult) in 100 ml NS over 1 hour.**

# POST COVID FATIGUE

The decrease in physical and/or mental performance that results from changes in central, psychological, and/or peripheral factors due to the COVID-19 disease

MINIMISE ENERGY EXPENDITURE



## POST COVID FATIGUE

*   **Central factors**: neurotransmitter levels (e.g., dopamine and serotonin), intrinsic neuronal excitability, inflammation, demyelination (resulting in changes in axonal conduction velocity)
*   **Peripheral factors**: COVID-19 may directly impact skeletal muscle → pain, skeletal muscle weakness, and injury occurrence
*   **Psychological factors**: Stress, anxiety, depression, and fear

# RESPIRATORY FOLLOW UP OF COVID 19 Pts \*

Cared for in ICU¹ or HDU² or ward care with severe pneumonia\*
*(Handwritten: High dependency unit)*

Assessment at 4 – 6 weeks after discharge.



## BLOOD TESTS :
Ordered selectively after a careful H/O and examination
*   CBC, CRP

# Influenza

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA viruses
*   Commonest cause of viral pneumonia in immunocompetent adults. It is transmitted via respiratory secretion



## Types

*   **Influenza A**
    *   (Influenza virus types A&B cause most human illness and the flu season)
    *   **Subtypes:**
        *   A(H1N1)
        *   A(H3N2)
*   **Influenza B**
    *   **Lineages:**
        *   B(Victoria)
        *   B(Yamagata)



## Surface Antigens

*   Surface antigens (Proteins) haemagglutinin and neuraminidase determine influenza serotype.
*   Genetic mutations may result in **antigenic shifts** (major genetic rearrangements between strains, associated with **pandemics** of influenza A—1918 (H1n1), 1957 (H2n2), & 2009 (H1n1))
*   **Antigenic drifts** (more minor genetic variations associated with epidemics) -H3N2 subtype of influenza A virus in india



## Functions of Viral Proteins

*   Haemagglutinin helps the virus invade a target cell.
*   Neuraminidase helps new virus particles break out of that cell.
